This word is quite old, appearing already in poem 779 of the Man'yōshū, one of the oldest pieces of written Japanese dating to 759, with parts that appear to be older still.  The age of this term might point to its origins: houses in ancient Japan were dugouts, where the roof came right down to the ground:  </div><div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > Noun </div> </div>

"covering futon").<sup>[1]</sup>&nbsp;Both elements of a futon bedding set are pliable enough to be aired, folded and stored away in a large closet&nbsp;(押入れ,&nbsp;oshiire)&nbsp;during the day allowing the room to serve for purposes other than as a&nbsp;bedroom.<sup>[2]</sup> </div><div class="sub all-b"> 当て字 </div><div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > Noun </div> </div>

While some kanji/radicals are ⟮c1;pictographs/ideographs⟯, most aren't. Since most kanji are phonosemantic compounds, not all radicals contribute to the meaning of the kanji. Most kanji can become radicals in even bigger kanji. ((h:2;::<img src="sm_６.jpg">))⟮c1;　形（けい）　声（せい）(　文（も）　字（じ）)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;phonosemantic compound⟯ Where does <ruby> 館 <rp>(</rp><rt class="force">かん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby> get its reading from? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;官⟯ The vast majority of chinese characters are what kind? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Phono-semantic compounds⟯ The semantic component of a phono-semantic compound is known as a... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;determinative⟯ Since <ruby> 館 <rp>(</rp><rt class="force">かん</rt><rp>)</rp></ruby> get its reading from 官 and its meaning (mostly) from 食, that makes it what in japanese terminology? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　形（けい）　声（せい）(　文（も）　字（じ）)⟯ Phono-semantic compound characters contain what, besides a semantic component? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a phonetic component⟯ Phono-semantic compound characters contain what, besides a phonetic component? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A semantic component⟯ How often can phono-semantic compounding occur on the same item? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Recursivevly⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> 劇 (豦 = 虍 + 豕, 劇 = 刂 + 豦). </div> </div> How much meaning does the phonetic element of a phono-semantic compound contribute most often? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Often, at least a little⟯ What are 林, 森, 休, 信, 明 examples for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Compound Ideograms⟯ Compound ideogram characters are made up of 2 or more... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Idea- or pictographs⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> yes, even despite the name </div> </div> Chinese characters made up of two or more ideo/pictograms are called (in english) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Compound ideograms⟯
<table>   <thead>     <tr><th>Reading</th>     <th>Is used in</th>   </tr></thead>   <tbody class="cloze-group-children hide-if-inactive-children">     <tr><td>((c:1;::音読み))</td> <td>((c:2;::熟語))</td></tr> <tr><td>((c:3;::訓読み))</td> <td>((c:4;::one-kanji words)), some ⟮c5;熟語⟯, most words with ⟮c1;送り仮名⟯, and many 　固有名詞（こゆうめいし）</td></tr>   </tbody> </table> <span class="cloze-dump">⟮c1;⟯⟮c2;⟯⟮c3;⟯⟮c4;⟯</span> 
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-496fe08890fcff58d78e408f08b2622f88d901ee.jpg">))⟮c1;雨 (あめ)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;⟯<br/><div class="sub">  </div>
How do you spell this word: あめ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;雨⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >  </div><div class="sub c2-b" > Just the kanji </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-aafc07ee1b3b8c7a03ca2fddac8bd7d85cf48479.jpg">))⟮c1;学生 (がくせい)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;(🎓)⟯<br/><div class="sub">  </div>
<div class='c2-f'> How do you pronounce this word? </div><div class='c1-f'> How do you spell this word? </div><br/>((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-aafc07ee1b3b8c7a03ca2fddac8bd7d85cf48479.jpg">))⟮c1;学生⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;がくせい⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > Learning, Knowledge + Life, Birth </div><div class="sub c2-b c1-f" >  </div> </div>
How do you mark the topic of a sentence? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;は（わ）⟯ Can, must, or mustn't the subject and the topic of the sentence be the same? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;they can be the same⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > However, it'll still just be marked with は only </div> </div>
What does the particle も express? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;inclusion/'too'⟯
⟮c1;Ru-verbs⟯ are also called ⟮c2;Ichidan verbs⟯, ⟮c3;V verbs⟯, and ⟮c4;Group II verbs⟯<br/><div class="sub"> Understand this:&nbsp;<a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/LearnJapanese/comments/27xf3z/why_are_ichidan_verbs_called_ichidan_verbs_and/">https://www.reddit.com/r/LearnJapanese/comments/27xf3z/why_are_ichidan_verbs_called_ichidan_verbs_and/</a> </div>
The term ⟮c1;particle⟯ is often used in descriptions of ⟮c2;Japanese⟯ and ⟮c2;Korean⟯, where they are used to mark nouns according to their ⟮c4;grammatical case⟯ or ⟮c5;thematic relation⟯. Linguistic analyses describe them as ⟮c8;suffixes⟯, ⟮c9;clitics⟯, or {{c10::postpositions}}.

⟮c1;アリス⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Alice (in Katakana)⟯ ⟮c1;ジョン⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;John (in Katakana)⟯ ⟮c1;ボブ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Bob (in Katakana)⟯
<div>ボブ：アリスは学生？</div><div>アリス：うん、アリスは学生。</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;アリスは⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What should you probably leave out here, since it's repetitive and not required? </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > No need for アリスは a second time, the topic has already been established </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is the gist of this conversation? </div><br/><div>アリス：今日は試験だ。</div><div>ボブ：ジョンは？</div><div>アリス：ジョンは明日。</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>Alice: Today is exam.</div><div>Bob: What about John?</div><div>Alice: John is tomorrow. ((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-311302601b0add4890c4e588438f36144e883a30.jpg">))⟮c1;　 暇 （ひま）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;free (not busy)⟯
<img class="c2-f c1-b" src="sm_paste-311302601b0add4890c4e588438f36144e883a30.jpg"><br/>⟮c1;暇⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;ひま⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > free(not busy), spare time </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>How do you mark something as "The thing up to which something is going"? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;まで⟯ How do you mark something as "The thing where sth. is coming from"? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;から⟯ アリスは、アメリカ___きた。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;から⟯ アリスは、アメリカからきた。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Alice came from America.⟯ 宿題を今日___明日までする。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;から⟯ 宿題を今日から明日<i>___</i>する。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;まで⟯ 宿題を今日から明日までする。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Will do homework from today to tomorrow.⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > casual-ish, 2 kana </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Alice came from America. </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Will do homework from today to tomorrow. </div> </div>
When giving the ⟮c1;location⟯ of something/one with ⟮c2;ある⟯ or ⟮c2;いる⟯, use ⟮c3;に⟯ for the ⟮c4;place⟯.
In general, the idea of targetness for に is ___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;very general⟯ The 「⟮c1;へ⟯」 particle is used to express the fact that one is setting out ⟮c2;towards⟯ <i>the </i>⟮c2;direction⟯ of the target. As a result, it is only used with directional motion verbs. It also does not guarantee whether the target is the ⟮c3;final⟯ ⟮c3;intended⟯ ⟮c3;destination⟯, only that one is ⟮c4;heading⟯ ⟮c4;towards⟯ that ⟮c4;direction⟯. What is the difference between に and へ as particles as concerns targeting? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;に」 goes <i>to</i> a target as the final, intended destination, while へ only claims that one will go in the direction of the target⟯ When using ⟮c2;へ⟯, the ⟮c4;verb⟯ ⟮c1;has to⟯ be one related to ⟮c3; physical direction⟯, the ⟮c4;thing⟯ being marked ⟮c1;does not have to⟯.<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > but actually somewhat more complicated </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> how is this read? </div><div class='c1-f'> in kanji? </div><br/>⟮c1;<div>何で</div>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;<div>なんで</div>⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > with the meaning of "why?" </div> </div>
<div>What do you do when the location, which you would mark with に」、「へ」、「で」, is also the topic?</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>You attach the location particle, and then the topic particle.</div>⟯
<div>ボブ：学校に行った？</div><div>アリス：行かなかった。</div><div>ボブ：図書館____？</div><div>アリス：図書館____行かなかった。</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>には, にも</div>⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> think </div> </div>
<div>Can you use the direct object particle with other particles?</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>no</div>⟯
<div>If you want the topic to also be the direct object, what do you do?</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>just mark it with the topic marker</div>⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Transitive (insert) or intransitive (enter)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (insert) or intransitive (enter)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (take out) or intransitive (leave)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (take out) or intransitive (leave)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (extract) or intransitive (be extracted)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (extract) or intransitive (be extracted)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (erase) or intransitive (disappear)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (erase) or intransitive (dissapear)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (drop) or intransitive (fall)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (drop) or intransitive (fall)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (close) or intransitive (be closed)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (close) or intransitive (be closed)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (open) or intransitive (be opened)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (open) or intransitive (be opened)? </div> <div class='c1-f'> Transitive (attach) or intransitive (be attached)? </div><br/>((h:1;::<img src="sm_paste-2c1fbb68b9e9a09ddbda08f0b40a2e351af593d8.jpg">)) <img class="c1-b c2-f" src='ContraPoints_(cropped).jpg'/><br/>　入（はい）る <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Intransitive (enter)⟯ 　入（い）れる <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Transitive (insert)⟯ 　出（だ）す <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Transitive (take out)⟯ 　出（で）る <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Intransitive (leave)⟯ 　抜（ぬ）く <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Transitive (extract)⟯ 　抜（ぬ）ける <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Intransitive (be extracted)⟯ 　消（き）える <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Intransitive (disappear)⟯ 　消（け）す <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Transitive (erase)⟯ 　落（お）ちる <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Intransitive (fall)⟯ 　落（お）とす  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Transitive (drop)⟯ 　閉（し）まる <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Intransitive (be closed)⟯ 　閉（し）める <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Transitive (close)⟯ 　開（あ）く <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Intransitive (be opened)⟯ <ruby>開<rt>あ</rt><ruby>ける</ruby></ruby> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Transitive (open)⟯ つく <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Intransitive (be attached)⟯ つける <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Transitive (attach)⟯ What is the P mnemonic for a intransitive verb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Jordan Peterson (because he's transphobic)⟯ What is the P mnemonic for a transitive verb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A trans person⟯ Many japanese verbs have ___ and ___ versions <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;transitive and intransitive⟯ What particle is somewhat rarely used with intransitive verbs (and why)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;を⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (Probably) no rule </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Jordan peterson enters a RUm full of Nazis - his home! </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (Probably) no rule </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > A trans person inserts RERU metals into her orifices. </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (Probably) no rule </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > A trans person takes out the SUperman from their vagina. </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (Probably) no rule </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Jordan peterson leaves because his colon RUptured </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (Probably) no rule </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > A trans person extracts CUm from her 27 sex slaves. </div> <div class='sub f'> think </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (Probably) no rule </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Jordan peterson is extracted to be placed in rehab, where he will get the KERU he needs </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (Probably) no rule </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Jordan peterson disappears, leaving only his KId and ERUpting colon. </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (Probably) no rule </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > A trans person erases the SUn. You can modify a ⟮c1;noun⟯ with an ⟮c2;arbitrary⟯ (non-polite) ⟮c2;verb⟯ ⟮c2;phrase⟯ (including ⟮c3;conjugations⟯ of the ⟮c4;copula⟯) by placing the ⟮c2;VP⟯ in ⟮c5;front⟯ of it - except for ⟮c6;だ⟯。
You can string together nouns without particles if they are  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;not modyifying each other.⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > e.g. 国際教育センタ </div> </div>

(The most natural translation is that someone likes puppies very much but there is not enough context to rule out that the puppies like something very much.) </div> </div>

neg + ka as invitation
In ⟮c2;casual⟯ ⟮c2;speech⟯, the question marker ⟮c1;か⟯ is used for ⟮c3;true⟯/⟮c3;false⟯ ⟮c3;questions⟯, ⟮c4;sarcasm⟯, ⟮c5;rhetorical⟯ ⟮c5;questions⟯.
What does adding か to the end of some question words mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Creates the meaning of "Some..." (Somebody/Something/...)⟯ What does adding でも to the end of some question words mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Creates the meaning of "Any..." (Anybody/Anything/...)⟯ What does adding も to the end of some question words mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Creates the meaning of "Every/all..." (Always/Everywhere/...)⟯ ⟮c1;　何（なん）でも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Anything⟯ ⟮c1;いつか⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Sometime⟯ ⟮c1;いつでも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Anytime⟯ ⟮c1;どこか⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Somewhere⟯ ⟮c1;どこでも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Anywhere⟯ ⟮c1;どこも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Everywhere⟯ ⟮c1;どれか⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;A certain one from many⟯ ⟮c1;どれでも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Whichever⟯ ⟮c1;どれも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Any and all⟯ ⟮c1;何か⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Something⟯ ⟮c1;何も⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Nothing (negative only)⟯ ⟮c1;誰か⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Someone⟯ ⟮c1;誰でも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Anybody⟯ ⟮c1;誰も⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;nobody (with negative), sometimes everybody⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 4 kana </div> </div>

The positive て form can not just be used on casual verbs, but also with ___ and ___. <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;です, ます⟯ What do you attach to positive (nouns and  na-adjectives), to make it part of a sequence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;で⟯ What do you do with negative nouns and na-adjectives as well as i-adjectives, to make it part of a sequence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1; Replace the 「い」 with 「くて」⟯ What do you do to a <b>negative </b>verb to chain it together? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;take the simple negative form, replace 「い」 with 「くて⟯ What do you do to a <b>positive </b>verb to chain it together? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Conjugate the verb to its past tense and replace 「た」 with 「て」 or 「だ」 with 「で」.⟯ What is chaining clauses with the て-form usually interpreted as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;As a sequence of events⟯ する negative te-form <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;しなくて⟯ 行く negative te-form <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;行かなくて⟯ 行く te-form <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;行って⟯ 食べる negative te-form <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;食べなくて⟯ 食べる te-form <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;食べて⟯ What is the tense of chained verbs determined by? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The last verb in the chain⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > not incredibly common tho </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not the adverbial て </div> </div>
<div>What is similar to から <q>because</q>, but more soft and slightly politer?</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>ので</div>⟯ <div>When using から for giving reasons, if the reason is a non-conjugated noun or na-adjective, you have to add ___ after the ___</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>だ after the reason</div>⟯ What does から between sentences indicate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a reason⟯ When using <b>から</b> to imply a <b>reason</b> for a <b>result</b>, the sentence is ordered ___ ___ ___.  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;reason から result⟯ When omitting the result with から, but speaking politely, what would you do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;add です after the から⟯ When using から with the pattern reason から result, what can sometimes be omitted? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;both the reason and the result⟯ <div>When you omit the reason using から, what do you have to include?</div> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>だ or です</div>⟯ Between から　and　ので, which is used to give a reason that is considered discourteous? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ので⟯ What is ので similar to, in function? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<div>から</div>⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Maybe a better way to say this would be that you can't use the implied copula in this case. </div> </div>

How is 々 pronounced, e.g. 色々？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Repeat the previous kanji⟯
What often happens when a kanji is repeated with 々? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;The initial consonant in the repeated part will have dakuten(=~ be voiced) ⟯

((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-639a3eb313c5bf7ac4e875ae123ca4914e6b08a7.jpg">))⟮c1;　怠（なま）ける⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to neglect, be lazy about⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> NAH MAn, I don't KERU, I'm neglecting it. </div> </div>
How head-final is japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;incredibly⟯ What do relative clauses in Japanese always do, as regards where they appear? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;before the thing they are modifying⟯ What kind of language is Japanese, as relates to phrase heads? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;head-final⟯ Why do relative clauses in Japanese always appear before the thing they are modifying? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because the thing they are modifying is the head of that phrase, and japanese is head-final⟯
Why do い-Adjectives not take だ when used as a plain predicate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because い-adjectives already form a predicate on their own, without a copula (Kinda like the い at the end already includes the copula)⟯
If a particle, sound, etc. seems to be missing in casual speech, what probably happened? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;people were lazy⟯
Counterintuitively, the meaning of 行っている and 来ている is something like having ___ and now ___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;completed the motion, and now you exist in that state.⟯
What does te-form + 来る or 行く imply? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That an action is oriented torward or from someplace⟯ What does 持つ + 行く or 来る mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Taking or bringing something⟯ With which verb is teform + 行く or 来る most often used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;持つ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>How do you conjugate a ru-verb into the potential form? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;Replace the 「る」 with 「られる」.⟯ How do you conjugate an u-verb into the potential form?  <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;replace the last u sound to an e sound and add ru⟯ How would you indicate that an action is possible? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;the potential form⟯ Potential form of 寝る <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;寝られる⟯ Potential form of 書く <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;書ける⟯ Potential form of 話す <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;話せる⟯ Potential form of 食べる <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;食べられる⟯ The potential form indicates that an action is ___. <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;possible⟯ What can you add to create the potential form, aside from られる？(Casual pattern) <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;れる⟯ What do all potential verbs end up becoming? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;ru verbs⟯ What is the potential verb form of する? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;出来る 【で・き・る】⟯ What is the potential verb form of 来る? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;こられる⟯ What particle (case marker) would you not want to use with the potential from? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;を⟯ When can you use the potential form of 見る and 聞く? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;When you were given the opportunity to see or hear something⟯ When would you use 見える and 聞こえる? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;If something <b>is</b> visible or audible⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Since they all end with eru </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (mostly) </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > exception </div> <div class="sub c1-f" > general potential form 食べられる (ru verbs)　遊べる (u verbs) </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > exception </div> <div class="sub c1-f" > not sure why not あれる - actually I do, I judt don't know why I never flashcardified that grammar. although I might have in-between, so check the japanese new cards first </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Was able to climb Fuji-san. </div> <div class="sub all-b"> potential form does not take direct object </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Am able to hold heavy baggage. </div> </div>
How do you count years in japanese? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;just add 年 to the end⟯

What is the fundamental goal of slang? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To reduce mouth movement⟯
What often happens in spoken japanese, as regards the verb and sentence order? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;You say the verb first, and then glue the rest of the sentence on as a second, incomplete sentence⟯

What can なんか be used as in casual japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;As a filler word⟯
What english word is なんか similar to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;like, kinda (As in "I was, like, sooo hungry")⟯
What is the sentence-ending particle さ be seen to be similar to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;よ⟯
What has happened to さ, due to overuse, in some context? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;lost almost all meaning⟯
What is さ similar to, in its overuse and almost-meaninglessness (in some contexts)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;"like"⟯

What does （こう／そう／ああ／どう）＋　いう　gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;(this/that...) way/kind of⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Replace the bolded thing and as much as possible with the relevant casual pattern! </div><br/>来年留学する<b>という</b>のは、智子のこと？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;来年留学するって智子のこと？⟯
((h:all;::<img src="sm_favordiag.gif">))<p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">   Japanese has <span class="c1-cloze">two distinct verbs</span> for <span class="c2-cloze">giving</span>, <span class="group-before-hide">depending on <span class="c3-cloze">who is giving to whom</span></span>:    <span class="c1-3-scr">     <span class="c6-7-hide line"><span class="c4-cloze">あげる</span> is <span class="c5-cloze">giving from the perspecitve of the giver</span>,</span>     <span class="c4-5-hide line"><span class="c6-cloze">くれる</span> is <span class="c7-cloze">from the perspective of the reciever (but stil means to give, not to recieve)</span>,</span>     <span class="all-hide c8-show">this applies in <span class="c8-cloze">all gramattical persons (1, 2 and 3)</span>.</span>      <span class="c4-8-hide">The word for <span class="c9-cloze">recieving</span> has <span class="c10-cloze">no such distinction</span>, it is <span class="c11-cloze">もらう</span>. <span class="c11-14-scr">You don't <span class="c12-cloze">use this so often</span> when <span class="c13-cloze">describing other people</span>. Appropriate particles are <span class="c14-cloze">から</span> and <span class="c14-cloze">に</span>.</span></span>   </span> </p> <p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">Examples:    <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">これは先生に<span class="c15-cloze">あげる</span> "<span class="c16-cloze">I’ll give this to teacher.</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">学生がこれを先生に<span class="c17-cloze">あげる</span>。”<span class="c19-scr"><span class="c18-cloze">The student give this to teacher.</span></span> (<span class="c18-scr">looking at it from <span class="c19-cloze">the student’s point of view</span></span>)"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">千円を貸して<span class="c20-cloze">くれる or もらえる</span>？ "<span class="c21-cloze">Will you give me the favor of lending 1000 yen?</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">それをくれる？ "<span class="c22-cloze">Can you give me that?</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">先生がこれを学生に<span class="c23-cloze">くれる</span>。"<span class="c24-cloze">The teacher give this to student. (looking at it from the student’s point of view)</span>"</span> </p> <p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">   When <span class="c25-cloze">using a verb</span> (≈ <span class="c25-scr"><span class="c26-cloze">giving a favor</span></span>), the grammar is <span class="c27-cloze">て+verb</span> (<span class="c27-cloze">てあげる・てくれる・てもらう</span>).    <span class="all-hide c28-33-unhide">When <span class="c28-cloze">asking for a favor / requesting something</span>, {{29::もらう becomes もらえる (so てもらえる)}} (but {{30::not in other cases}}).</span>   <span class="all-hide c31-33-unhide">てもらえる can also mean "<span class="c31-cloze">to have sbd. do sth.</span>". To <span class="c32-cloze">make the request softer</span>, use <span class="c33-cloze">the negative</span>.</span> </p> <p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">   <span class="line">Examples:</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">車を<span class="c34-cloze">買ってあげる</span>よ。"<span class="c35-cloze">I’ll give you the favor of buying a car.</span>" </span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">代わりに<span class="c36-cloze">行ってあげる</span>。"<span class="c37-cloze">I’ll give you the favor of going in your place.</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">車を<span class="c38-cloze">買ってくれる</span>の？ "<span class="c39-cloze">You’ll give me the favor of buying a car for me?</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">代わりに<span class="c40-cloze">行ってくれる</span>？ "<span class="c41-cloze">Will you give me the favor of going in my place?</span>"</span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">あなたが、私に千円を<span class="c42-cloze">貸してくれる</span>？ "<span class="c43-cloze">Will you give me the favor of lending 1000 yen?</span>"</span> </p> <p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">   Besides to individual people, <span class="c43-cloze">the あげる・くれる distinction</span> <span class="c44-cloze">also applies to ones 外・内</span>.    <span class="cloze-group hide-if-inactive">     That is, <span class="c45-cloze">your 外</span> gives to <span class="c45-cloze">your 内</span> with <span class="c46-cloze">くれる</span>   </span>    <span class="cloze-group hide-if-inactive"> and <span class="c47-cloze">your 内</span> gives to <span class="c47-cloze">your 外</span> with <span class="c48-cloze">あげる</span>.    </span>   <span class="line cloze-group hide-if-inactive">     Within your 内, <span class="c49-cloze">everything works as normal, you give with あげる and they give with くれる</span>.   </span>  </p> <p class="all-scr c50-53-unscr"><span class="c50-cloze">やる</span> is a(n) <span class="c51-cloze">humbling</span> version of <span class="c52-cloze">あげる</span>, -<span class="all-hide c53-unhide">it is used for <span class="c53-cloze">animals</span> or <span class="c53-cloze">people one wants to insult</span>.</span></p> <p class="cloze-group scr-if-inactive">The <span class="c54-cloze">honorific</span> form of <span class="c55-cloze">もらう</span> is <span class="c56-cloze">頂く</span></p> <span class="cloze-dump">⟮c1;⟯⟮c2;⟯⟮c3;⟯⟮c4;⟯⟮c5;⟯⟮c6;⟯⟮c7;⟯⟮c8;⟯⟮c9;⟯{{c10::}}{{c11::}}{{c12::}}{{c13::}}{{c14::}}{{c15::}}{{c16::}}{{c17::}}{{c18::}}{{c19::}}{{c20::}}{{c21::}}{{c22::}}{{c23::}}{{c24::}}{{c25::}}{{c26::}}{{c27::}}{{c28::}}{{c29::}}{{c30::}}{{c31::}}{{c32::}}{{c33::}}{{c34::}}{{c35::}}{{c36::}}{{c37::}}{{c38::}}{{c39::}}{{c40::}}{{c41::}}{{c42::}}{{c43::}}{{c44::}}{{c45::}}{{c46::}}{{c47::}}{{c48::}}{{c49::}}{{c50::}}{{c51::}}{{c52::}}{{c53::}}{{c54::}}{{c55::}}{{c56::}}</span>

How do you create negative polite requests? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;negative verb form + で + ください⟯ How do you make a polite request in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Verb in te form + ください⟯ How do you make more manly, commanding requests? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;くれる form with the る removed⟯ What connotation does ちょうだい as a replacement for ください have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;slighlty feminine, slightly childish⟯ What do to make a negative request, that is asking someone not to do something? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1; attach 「で」 to the negative form of the verb⟯ What is the slightly more feminine and childish version of ください? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ちょうだい⟯ When making requests with te-form + ください、what can you do for a shorter casual form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;drop the ください⟯ ここにこ___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ないでください。⟯ ここに名前を書___。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;いてちょうだい⟯ ゆっくり話___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;してください。⟯ スプーンを___。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ちょうだい⟯ 日本語で話___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;して。⟯ 日本語で話___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;してくれ。⟯ 消しゴムを貸___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;して。⟯ 消しゴムを貸___。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;してくれ。⟯ 漢字で書___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;いてください。⟯ 落書きを書___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;かないでください。⟯ 遠い所に行___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;かないで。⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please don’t come here. </div> <div class='sub f'> slighly Feminine, Childish </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please write your name here. </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please speak slowly. </div> <div class='sub f'> slighly Feminine, Childish </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please give me the spoon. </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please speak in Japanese. (casual) </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Speak in Japanese. (manly, rough) </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please lend me the eraser. (casual) </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Lend me the eraser. (manly, rough) </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 「Please write it in kanji.」 </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please don’t write graffiti. </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please don’t go to a far place. ((h:2;::<img src="sm_450-2017080521511061152.jpg">))⟮c1;　年（ねん）　功（こう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;long service⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The&nbsp;seniority-wage system&nbsp;(年功序列,&nbsp;Nenkō joretsu)&nbsp;is the&nbsp;Japanese&nbsp;system of promoting an employee in order of his or her proximity to&nbsp;retirement.<sup>[1]</sup>&nbsp;The advantage of the system is that it allows older employees to achieve a higher&nbsp;salary&nbsp;level before retirement and that it usually brings more experience to the executive ranks. The disadvantage of the system is that it does not allow new talent to be merged with the experience and those with specialized skills cannot be promoted to the already crowded executive ranks. It also does not guarantee or even attempt to bring the "right person for the right job". The labor turnover rate in Japan is less than half the US level. The seniority-wage system can also be seen in Japanese government.&nbsp;Japanese parliament&nbsp;seats are usually filled with the older members from each party. </div> </div>

<div class='c1-f'> Causative Passive Shortened/Casual form </div> <div class='c1-f'> Causative passive form </div> <div class='c1-f'> Causative Passive Shortened/Casual form </div> <div class='c1-f'> Causative passive form </div><br/>How do you conjugate something to the shortened causative passive form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;First conjugate to the shortened causative form. Then conjugate to the passive form.⟯ How often is the shortened/casual causative passive form (e.g. 行かされる) used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;rarely⟯ What does Causative + Passive gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To be made to do⟯ What form does "to be made to do" correspond in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Causative + Passive⟯ What verbs cannot be used with the shortened causative passive form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Ones that would end up including さされる⟯ When marking a verb as causative and passive, what is the order? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stem　causative　passive⟯ 行く <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;行かされる⟯ 行く <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;行かせられる⟯ 食べる <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Illegal!⟯ 食べる <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;食べさせられる⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> think </div> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > 行く → 行か → 行かす → 行かされる </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > To be made to go. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > 行く → 行かせる → 行かせられる </div> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > 食べる → 食べさす → <span class="highlightMain bad-element">食べさされる</span> </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > To be made to eat. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > 食べる → 食べさせる → 食べさせられる </div> </div>
What is the basic rule when to use honorific and when to use humble forms of words? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Use honorific forms when the things appertain to the other person ,(or the outgroup generally) and humble forms when the things appertain to yourself (or your ingroup)⟯
⟮c1;　下（くだ）さる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to give (honorific)⟯ ⟮c1;　伺（うかが）う⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to ask, hear (humble)⟯ ⟮c1;　召（あ）し　上（あ）がる        ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to eat, drink (honorific)⟯ ⟮c1;　存（ぞん）じる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;know (humble)⟯ ⟮c1;　差（さ）し　上（あ）げる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to give (humble)⟯ ⟮c1;　拝見（はいけん）する⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to see (humble)⟯ ⟮c1;　申（もう）し　上（あ）げる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to say (humble)⟯ ⟮c1;　申（もう）す⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to say (humble)⟯ ⟮c1;いらっしゃる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to go, come, be (honorific)⟯ ⟮c1;おいでになる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to go, come, be (honorific)⟯ ⟮c1;おっしゃる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to say (honorific)⟯ ⟮c1;おる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to be (humble)⟯ ⟮c1;ご　存知（ぞんじ）（です）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to know (honorific)⟯ ⟮c1;ご　覧（らん）になる/です<br>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to see⟯ ⟮c1;なさる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to do (honorific)⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> I give you a barraKUDA that I killed with the help of SARUman. </div><div class="sub c2-f"> think, what might be similar but mean something different </div><div class="sub c2-b c1-f"> Honorific form of くれる<br> </div> <div class="sub all-b"> U hear that KAGA cheated on U? If you want to conjugate a verb into its humble/honorific form, should a equivalent vocabulary item exist, you use that (in general), if not, you ⟮c1;conjugate⟯ it into a humble/honorific form.

What often happens to the ている form in spoken japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It's shortened to てる⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What happened to the verb here? </div><br/>あなたのことが愛してる。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It was shortened from ている to てる⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What form is する in here? </div><br/>あなたのことが愛してる。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ている⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > It was shortened </div> </div>

For what kind of things can you use 悪い to apologize for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Minor things⟯
⟮c1;Colloquialism of 悪い⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;　悪ぃ（わりぃ）⟯
お前が⟮c1;悪い⟯んだよ! <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It's your fault. </div> </div>
What can 悪い mean, besides bad and being used a s an apology? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Fault⟯
<div>朋子：三時間もあんたを待ったよ！</div> <div>けい：⟮c1;悪かった.⟯</div><br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Sorry. (using the word for bad) </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>悪かったから謝る <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That was my fault, so I'm going to apologize.⟯
どう考えても、私は⟮c1;悪くない⟯ <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > No matter how you look at it, it's not my fault. </div> </div>
What does 悪いけど gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Sorry, but...⟯
⟮c1;悪いけど⟯時間がない <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Sorry, but I don't have time. </div> </div>
⟮c1;彼には悪いけど⟯、行こう<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > We'll be wronging him, but let's go. /  He won't like it, but let's go. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > why には - something that imabi will at some poit explain </div> </div>

3 Kana variant of いいえ<br/>「疲れたか」「⟮c1;いいや⟯、ちっとも」 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > "Are you tired?" "No, not at all." </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_180.gif">))<p class="c5-7-scr">Both ⟮c1;いえ⟯ and ⟮c1;いや⟯ are two-character variants of ⟮c2;いいえ⟯, <span class="c1-2-scr"> a different three-character version is ⟮c3;いいや⟯. </span> <span class="c3-scr">All these (and any variant) can also mean ⟮c4;well..., err...⟯ </span> </p> <p class="c1-4-scr">Based on these, <span class="c6-scr">⟮c5;いえいえ⟯</span> or <span class="c5-scr">⟮c6; いやいや ⟯</span> can mean ⟮c7;No, no⟯</p><br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b" > also いやいや </div> </div>

What often happens to /ai/, /ae/, and /oi/ in casual speech, especially male casual speech・下町言葉<br>? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;They get reduced to <span class="ipa">eː</span>⟯
Which gender do people who reduce /ai/, /ae/, and /oi/ to <span class="ipa">eː</span> more frequently have (at least stereotypically)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;males⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What has happened here? </div><br/>すげー、あの爆発！ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<span class="ipa phoneme">oi</span> has been reduced to <span class="ipa">eː</span>⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > as is common in male slang&nbsp;≈ 下町言葉 </div> </div>
What can happen to い in 'feminine' speech? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It can sometimes be dropped⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > feminine i-deletiomn </div> </div>
Name an example where い is often dropped in feminine speech <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;いや -&gt; や⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > feminine i-deletiomn </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>やです！ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I don't want to!, No!⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Feminine い-deletion </div> </div>

What is the long <span class="ipa">eː</span> sound written as in native japanese words? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ええ⟯
What is the long <span class="ipa">eː</span> sound written as in sino-japanese words? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;えい⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Note that this does not imply that えい in sino-japanese words is always pronounced <span class="ipa">eː</span>, just that if there is an <span class="ipa">eː</span> in sino-japanese words, it will be written えい. it is in fact the choice of the speaker wheter to pronounce えい <span class="ipa">eː</span> or ei in sino-japanese words. </div> </div>
What sound does えい represent in sino-japanese words? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1; <span class="ipa">eː or ei</span>⟯
What sound does えい represent in native japanese words? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1; <span class="ipa">ei</span>⟯

It is a relatively cheap type of chocolate women give to male co-workers, casual acquaintances, and others to whom they have no strong attachment. Giri choco is lower-quality than honmei choco (more expensive chocolates women give to their romantic partners). On what does it depend whether えい in sino-japanese words is pronounced as <span class="ipa">eː</span> or ei? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The speakers choice⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > As alsways, singers etc. often prefer ei </div> </div>
How is おう pronounced in Sino-Japanese words? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;long o⟯
How is おう pronounced in native japanese words? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;long o⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > unless at the end of a verb (obviously) </div> </div>
⟮c1;<ruby> 長音符 <rp>(</rp><rt>ちょうおんぷ</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Katakana long vowel mark⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 3 kanji </div> </div>

Why is the use of the ～がる for yourself more restricted? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Since you don't have to guess about your own state⟯
What does the ～がる grammar gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;acting something⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > acting scared, acting embarrassed, etc. </div> </div>
With what word classe(es) can the ～がる grammar be used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;adjectives (both na and i)⟯
How does ～たい/欲しい + がる sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;relatively impersonal⟯
What does verb (properly conjugated)) + ばかり gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;As if to verb⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not the one that one has just done something </div> </div>
What verb is the most commonly used with ばかり meaning as if to... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;言う⟯
for the non-negative, non-past ばかり meaning as if to..., what do you need to conjugate it to before attaching ばかり <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The negative ん form (the one used, for example, in suman)⟯
for  ばかり meaning as if to..., in which forms do you need to modify the verb before attaching ばかり? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Non-negative, non-past⟯
What does Noun/Na-adjective + め<b>く</b> gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;x-like⟯
What is めく to indicate 'like' attached to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Nouns/Na-Adjectives⟯
What does xざるを得ない imply about x? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That one doesn't really want to do x⟯
To what is ～ざるを得ない attached, to indicate that one can't not not do something? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To the 未然形<div><br></div>⟯
To what is ～を得ない attached, to indicate that one can't not not do something, for する? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;せざる⟯
To what is ～を得ない attached, to indicate that one can't not not do something, for くる? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;こざる⟯
can't not not eat <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;食べざるを得ない⟯
can't obtain not going <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;行かざるを得ない⟯
can't not not do <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;せざるをえない⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > Incl obtain </div> </div>
can't not not come <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;こざるをえない⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > talk about pressure! </div> </div>
For the can't not not grammar, how do you read 得? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;え⟯
What phrase is やむを得ない the more formal equivalent of? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;しょうがない⟯
When indicating that something cannot be done, what is かねる attached to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The stem⟯ When indicating that something bad might happen, what is かねない attached to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The stem⟯ What might you gloss stem + かねない as in english? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;There's a risk that/There's a fear that⟯ What is the implication when using stem + かねない to indicate that something might happen? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That that thing is bad⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Gloss? </div><br/>決めかねる <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Can't decide⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Gloss? </div><br/>しかねる <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Can't do⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Gloss? </div><br/>しかねない <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Could be&nbsp;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > (something bad) </div> </div>
What kind of tendencies is がち used for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Ones that are bad/undesirable⟯
⟮c1;病気がち⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Prone to illness⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the error here? (negative volitional) </div><br/> なりまいます <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;it should be  なりますまい⟯
<div class='c1-f'> negative volitional </div><br/>見る <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;見るまい/見まい⟯
⟮c1; 食べようが食べまいが⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Whether or not (someone) eats⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > using volitionals </div> </div>
How formal is であろう, compared to でしょう <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;More formal⟯
What is であろう a formal version of? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;でしょう⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Gloss`? </div><br/>困難であろう <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Probably difficult/would be difficult⟯
<div class='c2-f'> Gloss`? </div><br/>⟮c1;早かろうが遅かろうが⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Whether it's early or late⟯
⟮c1;間違いだらけ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Riddled with/full of mistakes⟯
⟮c1;埃だらけ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Riddled with dust⟯
⟮c1;ゴミだらけ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Riddled with trash⟯
What word class is だらけ attached to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Nouns⟯
What kind of covering does まみれ express? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;covering by sticking⟯
What kind of thing does ずくめ attach to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;nouns⟯

⟮c1;だから(何/なんだ/etc.)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;So what?⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 4 or more characters </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_46aba2911ff3bc1c8c2d428386c451b2.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby> 運命 <rp>(</rp><rt>うんめい</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;fate, destiny, lot⟯
When using verb + や or や否や, what does having the second verb in the clause in the past tense imply? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That the event actually happpened (and happened once)⟯
What is the literal meaning of verb + や否や? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;whether the action was taken or not⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" >  In other words, the second action is taken before you even take the time to determine whether the first event really happened or not. </div> </div>
When using verb + や or や否や, what does having the second verb in the clause in the present tense imply? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That the event occurs regularly⟯
What do you attach や / や否や to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;verbs⟯
Verbs in what form do you attach や / や否や to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;dictionary form⟯
What does the そばから grammar imply? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That the events are part of a recurring pattern⟯
What form of the verb do you attach そばから to (more commonly)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The dictionary form⟯
What form of the verb do you attach そばから to (less commonly)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The past⟯
What form is the second verb in the clause in, if you use そばから (most of the time)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Non-past⟯
What do you attach と思いきやto? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The quotation⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > That is, the thing you thought would happen, but didn't </div> </div>
When using と思いきや, what was the thing that happened? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;unexpected⟯
If you use がてら with a noun and nothing after it がてら, what is implied? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;がてらする⟯
If you use がてら with a verb as in clause1 verb(stem)  がてら clause2, what is the primary action? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The first one (the one followed by がてら)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > http://www.guidetojapanese.org/learn/grammar/other </div> </div>
When using 挙句, what is the result like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Negative⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > usually </div> </div>
When using 挙句, how did you get to the result? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;After a great deal of effort⟯
Why is 挙句 used with the past tense? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because it's used for actions that are already completed⟯
Why is の needed when using the 挙句 grammar with nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Since 挙句 is a regular noun⟯

((h:2;::<img src="sm_70bde594.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_お仕事アニメ.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_1_3-520x300.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_wysiwyg_b5e98d4b114e6a3d582f.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby> 社会人 <rp>(</rp><rt>しゃかいじん</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;working adult; full-fledged member of society⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > ___ is a very interesting categorization of people, which likely exists only in Japan. It is a very broad category for people in workforce, although it literally means people who are part of society.  The term is often used in contrast to gakusei (学生), which means students. The precise definition of ___ does not really exist. For example, how should we categorize shufu (主婦) i.e., housewives? Housewives may not be in the workforce, but they do often play important functions for society, such as raising children. Using the broader categorization, you could also say housewives are ___ (as well as students who really are part of the society).  What's interesting is that the term is often used to mean that people become first-class citizens only after they start working and join the labor force. In that sense, the usage of the term connotes that non-____ like students and housewives are second-class citizens. </div> </div>

Such terms are generally written using kanji and read according to the on'yomi pronunciations of the characters. While many words belong to the shared Sino-Japanese vocabulary, some kango do not exist in Chinese while others have a substantially different meaning from Chinese; however some words have been borrowed back to Chinese. </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_800px-Shibuya_District_at_Night_2015_(17810219251).jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_800px-Shibuya_Station_Toyoko_Line_Platform_4_&amp;_5_2018.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-a53f09ff3ffca2f13138aabff3a1053cb3968204.jpg">))⟮c1;　渋谷駅（しぶやえき）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Shibuya station⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> On the surface, this one is a total freaking mystery.  The 2 characters used today are 渋 shibu (this character has many nuances that range from “astringent” to “refined” to “distasteful” to “diarrhea”) and 谷 ya/tani (valley). Unlike Hibiya, which also uses the kanji 谷 ya (valley), Shibuya is an actual valley. It borders Daikanyama (Daikan Mountain). The name Shibuya is also a family name.  </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_compressed_thumbnail_square_normal.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby> 生 <rp>(</rp><rt>なま</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Fresh, raw, live (performance)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Normally a single kanji alone like this would mean the same thing as its parent kanji, but in the case of 生 it's a little different (but still related). When you think of something that has life, it's fresh or raw. Think sashimi or sushi, for example. You want that to be as close as possible to life as you can, so you eat it when it's fresh and raw. This word can also be used to describe a live event, like a concert or sporting event. </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_795316b92fc766b0181f6fef074f03fa.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby>外<rp>(</rp><rt>はず</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>れ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;end; verge; extremity; tip; outskirts​⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The kanji 外 alone means "outside." This word means extremity. How can you remember this? Just think of the れ as a "ray of sunshine." Where you are, in the extremity of space, even the れs of the sun cannot be seen. So, when 外 is combined with れ just think of this. Let's continue the previous story: You're off in the extremity of space and your friend is running low on Vitamin D. He has (はず) to get some sun れs on his skin! How's that supposed to happen with those spacesuits on, though? </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-a6cf2d689a10471df97136b5eadd180b20c793f0.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby>丸<rp>(</rp><rt>まる</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>ごと⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;entirely, wholly, completely⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Even though the koto is never spelled in kanji in this word, this is still the etymology </div><div class="sub all-b"> If you go to (ごと) a circle, you need to go to it in its entirety. That means you have to circle around the whole thing. Otherwise, it isn't even a circle. ((h:2;::<img src="sm_2213b64e9891002fc96055aaceed5df3.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby>生<rp>(</rp><rt>は</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>える⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to grow; to spring up; to sprout が⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 生きる means "to live?" Well this is what happens right after it starts to live. It begins to grow! </div><div class="sub all-b"> When something starts to grow it also learns to laugh. Imagine a little plant growing out of the ground laughing. "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" it says, as it sprouts out of the ground. </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_img_612caf096017b8df9a4cfa1c69c60373305760.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_トレードを学ぶ.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby>学<rp>(</rp><rt>まな</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>ぶ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to learn, to study⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kanji 1 kana </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_mazeru.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby>交<rp>(</rp><rt>ま</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>ぜる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to mix (transitive)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb version is to mix.  There are similar words to this one, including 交じる which means "to be mixed" and 交わる which means "to intersect." This one is when you're doing the mixing. Like 交じる, the connotation is that the things being mixed are distinguishable from each other, like two types of fish, or books being mixed together. They don't become homogenous like paint or something would. </div><div class="sub all-b"> Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the ま portion. Who would mix things for you (like cakes and other goodies) growing up? That would be your Ma (ま). </div><div class="sub all-b"> I mix MA ZERU sugar coke with some pudding. </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_o0712055214680476141.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby> 熟語 <rp>(</rp><rt>じゅくご </rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;idiom, compound word⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_500_F_218745608_aR0yJG0XobGFl0XRBielJFQ0Gxa20IDR.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby> 四字熟語 <rp>(</rp><rt>よじじゅくご </rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;a four-kanji set phrase⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Opinions on what qualifies as a 四字熟語 vary considerably. The word 四字熟語 itself may be considered a 四字熟語 in a broader sense, but may not be so in a more narrow sense. Generally, a word is more likely to be considered a 四字熟語 if it is more idiomatic or has a longer history of usage. </div> </div>
What does 四字熟語 refer to, in the broad sense? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;All four-kanji compounds⟯
What does 四字熟語 refer to, in the narrow sense? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Four character compounds with idiomatic meaning (cannot be inferred from the parts)⟯
From which word does the かっこう of かっこういい come from? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;格好⟯
What does かっこ悪い mean, literally? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Bad-shape, ugly figure⟯

Another way to say America in Japanese is アメリカ, but this is another more formal (and older) way. "Rice Country" aka United States Of America, United States, America, or USA. </div><div class="sub all-b"> The second kanji character in 亜米利加 (Amerika, “America”) + 国 (koku, “country”). The reason the second character is used instead of the first is because 亜 is already in use as the abbreviation for 亜細亜 (Ajia, “Asia”). </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_company-fired.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_kubi_kaiko_risutora_man-300x300.jpg">))⟮c1;　首（くび）になる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;To get fired⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The になる part means "to become," so literally this means "to become neck." If you think about it, when something becomes neck, it has to do with you getting your head cut off (at the neck). But, in today's modern society we don't do that too often. That's why this verb means to be finished.  </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-bcd3b9f11cf42b52b2e48f3f7f392cb99d950305.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-feb7035543bfceaa8d7e799178f65d3754abee85.jpg">))⟮c1;　交/混（ま）じる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;To be mixed, be blended with, to associate with が⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> You know that 交ぜる means to mix and that the kanji means mix as well. So, this probably has something to do with mixing things. This word means to be mixed. This is when something is mixed but it's not mixed by you. It's just being mixed. Think of it this way - the じ in 交じる is Jesus, who just uses Jesus magic to mix something. So, you're not mixing it. It's just when something is to be mixed. </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_shutterstock_676488793-e1526785396717.jpg">))⟮c1;　当（あ）てる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Hit, expose, guess を⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_20180315182017.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_53bfb49c.jpg">))⟮c1;　交（まじ）わる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Intersect, cross, mingle, have sex　が⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The reading is almost the same as 交ぜる which you should be familiar with by now. It has the ま but it also has an extra じ in there. That じ is there because you intersect with a group of mages (まじ) that catch you on fire as you walk past. </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_LP_20160405_01.jpg">))⟮c1;　見直（みなお）す⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;reevaluate, look again, reassess⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> You know the word 直す from a couple levels ago. It means "to fix." So, when you fix what you see, what are you doing? You're reevaluating something. That's why this word means to reevaluate.  </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-0097519848bbf86f70fd34832369b044f544010d.jpg">))⟮c1;　走（はし）り　回（まわ）る⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Run around⟯

In order to support them, you grab two saws. One saw and another saw. A saw saw (ささ combination good enough to do all the supporting you need - and maybe cut some supports too). </div> </div>

This is the way to describe them.<br><br> </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji made up of 4 kana, s... </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_800px-Nagoya_Night_View.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-a3c09f146ee3e2fcd0129bb8765c38d668b70798.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-f2d86ea98ded18cfd9c19b10f56d83ceb26b73f0.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-02c4a454b910b79b769712942b6e335f2881aea3.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_Screenshot 2020-10-02 at 20.35.54.jpg">))⟮c1;　名古屋市（なごやし）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Nagoya (city)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The place that's famous for old roofs. I don't know why, but it's the city of Nagoya. Just associate the two things together and it'll be hard to forget (so long as you've heard of Nagoya before - if not, read up about it!).  </div><div class="sub all-b"> Nagoya&nbsp; is the largest city in the Chūbu region of Japan. It is Japan's fourth-largest incorporated city and the third most populous urban area. Located on the Pacific coast on central Honshu, it is the capital of Aichi Prefecture and is one of Japan's major ports along with those of Tokyo, Osaka, Kobe, Yokohama, and Chiba. It is also the center of Japan's third-largest metropolitan region, known as the Chūkyō metropolitan area. As of 1 October 2019, 2,327,557 people lived in the city, part of Chūkyō metropolitan Area's 10.11 million people,[4] making it one of the 50 largest urban areas in the world.  In 1610, the warlord Tokugawa Ieyasu, a retainer of Oda Nobunaga, moved the capital of Owari Province from Kiyosu to Nagoya. This period saw the renovation of Nagoya Castle. Nagoya was proclaimed a city in 1889, during the Meiji Restoration; it became a major industrial hub for Japan. The traditional manufactures of timepieces, bicycles, and sewing machines were followed by the production of special steels, chemicals, oil, and petrochemicals, as the area's automobile, aviation, and shipbuilding industries flourished.[5] Nagoya was impacted by bombing from US air raids during World War II.  After the war, Nagoya developed into a major port and transport center. The Shinkansen high-speed line connecting Tokyo and Osaka converges on Nagoya. Nagoya is served by two airports: Chubu Centrair International Airport in nearby Tokoname, and Nagoya Airfield, home to Mitsubishi Aircraft Corporation. Nagoya remains an important center for the automotive, aviation, and ceramic industries, hosting the headquarters of Brother Industries, Ibanez, Lexus, and Toyota Tsusho, among others.  Nagoya is home to Nagoya University, the Nagoya Institute of Technology, and Nagoya City University. It is also the location of numerous cultural institutions, including the Tokugawa Art Museum, Atsuta Shrine, Higashiyama Zoo and Botanical Gardens, Aichi Arts Center, and Misono-za. Nagoya TV Tower is the oldest TV tower in Japan. </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-f3c7b2fb51f98d731d4d4c579f8f27983bdd5eac.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-9591cfbfb62bbec9f28a082e73ff07403b9eca3a.jpg">))⟮c1;　付近（ふきん） ::f..., 2 kanji⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Neighborhood, vicinity, nearby⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> If you attach things near you, they end up being in the same neighborhood as you. They're attached nearby so they can't go much further.  Your neighborhood is full of fools (ふ). Fools everywhere. You're probably one too, since you live nearby. </div><div class="sub all-b"> he's in the neighborhood? Well, FUKIN (fuck him)!&nbsp; </div> </div>
⟮c1;〜　県（けん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;~Prefecture⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-c3045ba6d323f0187a7a9b76d29258df83d05140.jpg">))⟮c1;　発音（はつおん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Pronunciation⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-83a05fa6ed1ef5921667b0c40c4b4b474b5b1cc6.jpg">))⟮c1;　部首（ぶしゅ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Radical⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Picture the part of your body that makes up your neck. Are you picturing it? That's a building block that makes up your body. A really important one. If you didn't have that neck, you wouldn't look like a person at all. Sound familiar? It should! Because that part of your neck is a radical! Just like part of your neck is a building block of your body, the radical is a building block of kanji. Get it? I sure hope so!  </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-c4ed29ada782b66569f51aaf328685f2d80f9b93.jpg">))⟮c1;　保持（ほじ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;retention; maintenance; preservation⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> When you hold on and preserve something you are doing the act of retention or maintenance on it. Many things that most people would consider "green" are actually "blue" in their eyes. So, things like plants and street lights are "blue" even though you may think of them as green. Remember that for this word, where we talk about a blue leaf. In your head, though, think "green leaf." Now think of all things that have green leaves. This is greenery.  </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-71a8e145337dd2afce08d2d386404aa209defb21.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-f8fb88dcba3f6fb572421f4b5f77ce80c32ffc98.jpg">))⟮c1;　短刀（たんとう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Short Sword, Dagger&nbsp;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> A tantō (短刀, "short sword")[1][2] is one of the traditionally made Japanese swords[3] (nihonto)[4][5] that were worn by the samurai class of feudal Japan. The tantō dates to the Heian period, when it was mainly used as a weapon but evolved in design over the years to become more ornate. Tantō were used in traditional martial arts (tantojutsu). The term has seen a resurgence in the West since the 1980s as a point style of modern tactical knives, designed for piercing or stabbing. </div> </div>

What does adding an ん to the end of (mostly female) names do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Makes them sound more cute⟯
What one 平仮名 can you add to the end of names to make them sound more cute? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ん⟯
What does changing みのり to みのりん do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Make it sound more cute⟯

Just think about promises. When you promise something you really need to follow through... but only about as much as you need to for the other person to be happy. Someone asks for a puppy for Christmas, and you get them a stuffed animal puppy. It's approximately the promise you made. Close enough. *wink*  </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-a1e30084faf105a686eb4c014ba3a0211f3ad030.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-e69777a91008dbb8f1c9dae61cfd572788f8df09.jpg">))⟮c1;　輪（わ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Ring, wheel, loop, circle⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You put on the ring you found, hoping it will be the one ring to rule them all (invisibility!). Instead, it turns out it's a special Walken ring, made out of Christopher Walken's bones. It talks up to you, telling you how he kept this ring in his (*ahem*) butt during the war so he could get it to you. First of all, why is this ring talking? Second, why is it talking like Walken. Third, eww, gross, it was in his anus.<br><br> </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kanji </div> </div>

What 'case' does よ after something (e.g. a name) indicate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;vocative case⟯
How do you indicate something similar to vocative case? (e.g. addressing 神) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;よ, e.g. 神よ⟯
What is a gloss for vocative よ in english? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;'O' (As in: O gentle Romeo...)⟯

⟮c1;　我（わ）が⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;My, our (old-fashioned, positive connotataion)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Originally a compound of 我 (wa, “I, me”, archaic) +‎ が (ga, particle). Now fossilized into a single term.[1] Note that が in modern Japanese is used as the nominative or subject particle; in ancient Japanese, it was used as a possessive particle between two nouns, a usage still seen in some limited phrases, particularly in place names. </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-0c5ea08aaac091f5e2a077b51010db8211528078.jpg">))⟮c1;　以外（いがい）の　何者（なにもの）でもない。⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;is entirely..., nothing but...⟯

６時間⟮c1;以内⟯に着くはずです<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It should arrive within six hours. </div> </div> 面会人は午後１０時⟮c1;以降⟯病院にとまることはできません。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Visitors are not allowed to remain at the hospital at or after 10:00 PM. </div> </div> 私の体温は今朝は３７度⟮c1;以下⟯でした。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > My temperature was less than 37 degrees this morning. </div> </div> 期待⟮c1;以上⟯でした。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It exceeded my expectations. / It was more than I expected. </div> </div> 彼女は先々週風邪を引いて、⟮c1;以後⟯ずっと寝込んでいます。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >  She caught a cold two weeks ago and has been in bed ever since. </div> </div> 二百字⟮c1;以内⟯でまとめられるのか?<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Can you sum it up in 200 words or less? </div> </div> これ⟮c1;以外⟯に方法はありませんよ。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     There is no method other than this.  </div> </div> このグループには１２歳⟮c1;以上⟯の子供が含まれている。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       Children twelve and over are included in this group.  </div> </div> ⟮c1;以後⟯はもっと注意します。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'll be more careful from now on.  </div> </div> ⟮c1;以上⟯の説明でご理解をいただきたい。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The above explanation should help you to understand. </div> </div> ⟮c1;以上⟯です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > That's all. </div> </div> ⟮c1;　以降 （いこう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;hereafter, thereafter, on and after⟯ ⟮c1;　以西（いせい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;west of⟯ ⟮c1;　以東（いとう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;... and eastward; east of⟯ ⟮c1;　以南（いなん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;south of⟯ ⟮c1;　以北（いほく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;north of⟯ When using 以+cardinal direction, what specifically are you talking about? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;everything in that cardinal direction⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f"> That is, 'everything east/west/... of' </div> </div> What type of word are all the 以* words? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;Adverbial nouns⟯ The japanese adverbial nouns starting with 以 all have a property that can be glossed with the german mathematical term <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;halboffenes intervall⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f"> 以内 = everything within, 以上 = everything more/above etc. </div> </div> ⟮c1;　以内 （いない）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Inside of; within; less than⟯ ⟮c1;2 kanji::以前⟯よりずっとよく見えます。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It looks much better than before. </div> </div> ((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-b094024184f49caf5139ec535ff4f30166b2c988.jpg">))⟮c1;　以外（いがい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Other than, except for, excepting⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f" > not 意外！ </div> </div> ((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-13c925585e1fa901c490438818d64ab0a2222169.jpg">))⟮c1;　以遠（いえん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;beyond, further than⟯ ((h:2;::<img src="sm_et_05_225_T2-1-1280x720.jpg">))⟮c1;<ruby> 以後 <rp>(</rp><rt>いご</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;From now on, after this, since⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji </div> </div> ((h:2;::<img src="sm_eruwkx0je0zruqlwiu3w.jpg">))⟮c1;　以前（いぜん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;previously, before ⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji, starts i </div> </div> ((h:2;::<img src="sm_9624f4e8447fb70c164105ac25f16e45-733x353.jpg">))⟮c1;　以下（いか）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;not exeeding, below, the following⟯ ((h:2;::<img src="sm_5621deba8a18b839c7a4321764bb05e8-43.jpg">))⟮c1;　以上（いじょう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;more than, not less than (greater or equal), beyond ... 気づかないと⟮c1;でも⟯思もった？<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f"> starts with d </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b"> Did you think I wouldn't notice or something? </div> </div> でも can just be created how, at its most morphologically obvious? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;で＋も⟯ ⟮c1;いつでも⟯いい。<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f"> i... </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b">       Anytime is OK.  </div> </div> ⟮c1;　是（ぜ）(が)　非（ひ）でも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;by all means, absolutely must, one way or another⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f"> May contain が </div> </div> ⟮c1;　意地（いじ）でも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;at all costs, by any means⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f"> 2 kanji 2 kana, i... </div> </div> when でも is just で＋も, what does it gloss as? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;also in⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b"> does not work for ても </div> </div> when following something でも・ても can mean '⟮c1;even⟯', '⟮c2;even if/even though⟯' , '⟮c3;or⟯', and '⟮c4;or something⟯'. additionally, でも&nbsp; can mean '⟮c5;also in⟯'. the <b>word</b> でも derived from what?&nbsp; <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;the pattern て・でも⟯ most of the time, how do でも and ...ても&nbsp; relate? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;realizations of the same pattern⟯ When used in a list like AでもBでも..., what sort of feeling does this have? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;a sort of vagueness⟯ When used in a list like AでもBでも..., what does でも・ても gloss as? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;or&nbsp;⟯ Extrapolated from the list use, でも・ても mean 'or something', implying...&nbsp; <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;alternatives⟯ Extrapolated from the list use, what can でも・ても mean? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;or something (implied alternatives)⟯ As a sister meaning to でも as a word, what does でも・ても also mean? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;even if, even though⟯ <div class="c1-f"> what use of でも・ても is this here? </div><br>彼でも合格した！ <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;'even'⟯ <div class="c1-f"> what use of でも・ても is this here? </div><br>先生でも分からないな。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;'even'⟯ <div class="c1-f"> what use of でも・ても is this here? </div><br>この世界に、冬になっても、雪が降らない。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;'even'⟯ <div class="c1-f"> what use of でも is this </div><br>彼は貧乏でも幸せだ。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;even if, even though⟯ <div class="c1-f"> What use of でも・てもis this? </div><br>食べなくても飲まなくても一日生きれる。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;or (listing function)⟯ <div class="c1-f"> What use of でも・てもis this? </div><br>お茶でも、コーヒーでも、どうですか？  <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;or (listing function)⟯ <div class="c1-f"> What use of でもis this? </div><br>酒でも飲もうよ。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;or something (implied list)⟯ <div class="c1-f"> What function is でも fulfilling here? </div><br>日本でも英語を勉強する <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;also in (で+も)⟯ ⟮c1;どうでもいい⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;whatever; whichever; I don't care⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b"> Expression </div> </div> ⟮c1;どうでもいい⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;inconsequential; indifferent; not worth worrying about; trivial​⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b"> i-adjective </div><div class="sub c1-f"> 6 kana </div> </div> What is the verb/adjective form of でも? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;~ても⟯ What form of what word is the で in でも? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;て-form of だ⟯ <div class="c1-f"> What does でも gloss as in this sentence? </div><br>酒でも飲もうよ。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;'or something'⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f"> Let's have a drink or something </div> </div> 先生⟮c1;でも⟯分からないな。<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f"> contains no s sounds </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b">     Even the teacher doesn't understand it. </div> </div> 全部飲ん<i>___</i>よ。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;でも構わない⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b"> I don’t <b>mind</b> if you drink it all. (lit: Even if you drink it all, I don’t mind, you know.) </div> </div> 全部飲ん<i>___</i>だよ。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;でも大丈夫⟯<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b"> It’s ok if you drink it all. (lit: Even if you drink it all, it’s OK, you know.) </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f"> でもいい is also ok </div> </div> ⟮c1;でも⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;but⟯ For the okay not to do form, what does ～てもいい or ～でもいい sometimes get shortened to in casual speech? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;～ていい or ～でいい⟯ <div class="c1-f"> What does this gloss as? </div><br>全部飲んでも構わないよ。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;I don’t mind if you drink it all. (lit: Even if you drink it all, I don’t mind, you know.)⟯ <div class="c1-f"> What does this gloss as? </div><br>全部飲んでも大丈夫だよ。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;It’s ok if you drink it all. What is the phenomenon of が being replaced by の in relative clauses known as in the academic world? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ga/no (nominative/genitive) conversion (GNC)⟯ In which relative clauses can you replace が with の? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Most, but it's unclear where the exceptions are exactly⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> which of these ga's could be replaced by no? </div><br/>ジョンが背が高い理由  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;both of them⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> Why is this no and not ga? </div><br/>太郎は昨日花子<b>の</b>読んだ本を借りた <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ga/no conversion (GNC)⟯ <div class='c1-f'> Why can't you use の to mark the subject here? </div><br/>太郎が映画を見た <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because it's a main clause⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ga/no conversion (GNC) </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> Why can you replace ga with no here? What is the less polite version of てあげる? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;てやる⟯
<img class="c1-f c2-b" src="sm_Screenshot 2020-11-24 at 22.54.10.jpg"><br/>⟮c1;殺してやる⟯！<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'll kill you! (lit. I'll do you the favor of killing you (derogatory)) </div> </div>
With てやる, what is the person you're giving whatever to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;inferior status⟯
How do てあげる and てやる relate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;てやる is the less polite version of てあげる⟯
