((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-8ce11f27df936998c49c922101136c9ceea01240.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-9b1d86990a7fccd03947364bc2131019f05d79f3.jpg">))⟮c1;　幸福（こうふく）の　科学（かがく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;___ formerly known as <span class="all-scr">The Institute for Research in in Human Happiness</span>, is a controversial new religious and spiritual movement, founded in Japan on 6 October 1986 by Ryuho Okawa, which has been characterized as a cult.⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Happy Science worships a deity named El Cantare who they believe is the "Highest God of Earth, the Lord of all gods". They believe that the being was first born on Earth 330 million years ago and that it is the same entity that has been worshipped at different times as Elohim, Odin, Thoth, Ophealis (Osiris) Hermes and Shakyamuni Buddha, with Okawa himself as the current incarnation.[2][13]  </div><div class="sub all-b"> The group sold "spiritual vaccines" claimed to prevent and cure COVID-19, advertised virus-related blessings at rates from 100 to over US$400, and sold coronavirus-themed DVDs and CDs of Ryuho Okawa lecturing, which are claimed to boost immunity, as of April 2020. After initially defying physical distancing measures, it later closed its New York temple, and administered spiritual vaccines remotely.[19]  </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-dc72508f25271094b70238073878cefcf2d76835.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-775bf4c31118b3be1112702b45b8d95cd54a5e19.jpg">))⟮c1;　愛知県（あいちけん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Nagoya is the capital and largest city of Aichi Prefecture, and the fourth-largest city in Japan, with other major cities including Toyota, Okazaki, and Ichinomiya. Aichi Prefecture and Nagoya form the core of the Chūkyō metropolitan area, the third-largest metropolitan area in Japan and one of the largest metropolitan areas in the world.[1](p685) Aichi Prefecture is located on Japan's Pacific Ocean coast and forms part of the Tōkai region, a subregion of the Chūbu region and Kansai region. Aichi Prefecture is home to the Toyota Motor Corporation, the world's largest automotive manufacturer, the largest listed company in Japan by market capitalization, and sixth-largest company in the world by revenue, with its headquarters in the city of Toyota. Aichi Prefecture features the Higashiyama Zoo and Botanical Gardens, Chubu Centrair International Airport, and Legoland Japan Resort. </div><div class="sub c1-f" > prefecture </div> </div>

What kind of archaic form is the き-form of い-adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the adnominal form⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> both of ク and of シク　形容詞, although the former would have ended just in き and the latter would have ended in しき </div> </div>
What kind of archaic form is the し-form of い-adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the sentence-final form/終止形⟯
What is the archaic sentence-final form of い-adjectives <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the し-form⟯
Where is the difference between the (now archaic) き-form and the し-form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the き-form is archaic adnominal, and the し-form is archaic sentence-final&nbsp;⟯
How do you get back to the し form from modern い-adjectives (non-しい)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;replace the い with a し⟯
How do you get back to the し form from modern い-adjectives, for ...しい adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;remove the final い⟯
き form of ない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;なき⟯
⟮c1;なし⟯ (<span class="c1-scr">in kanji: ⟮c2;無し⟯</span>) is ⟮c3;the classic 終止形⟯ of ⟮c4;ない⟯, meaning <span class="c1-scr c2-scr c3-scr c4-scr"> either ⟮c5;without⟯ (examples: <span class="c5-scr">⟮c6;休日なしで働く 'to work without holiday'⟯</span>) , ⟮c7;not/nothing⟯ (⟮c7;the same as ない⟯, e.g. <span class="c7-scr">⟮c8;ルールなし。 '(there are) no rules'⟯</span>), or (colloquially) ⟮c9;unsatisfactory/unaccetable&nbsp;⟯.</span>

In english, a 　可（か）　能（のう）　動（どう）　詞（し） is often called what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a verb in the potential form⟯
夏から秋にかけて、このトマトには特別な⟮c1;甘み⟯が出てくる。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > As summer turns to fall, the special quality of sweetness of these tomatoes comes through. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > due to subjectivity </div> </div> バブルティーの⟮c1;甘さ⟯はどうしますか？１から１０を選んでください。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What amount of sweetness (=how sweet) would you like in your bubble tea? Please choose from 1 through 10. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > due to objectivity </div> </div> み form of 面白い <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;面白み⟯ あの映画には⟮c1;重み⟯がある。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > That movie has some weight. (= That movie conveys an important message.) </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > due to subjectivity/metaphoricity </div> </div> When used for flavors, how is the み of the み form sometimes (often) written?  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;味⟯ What sort of nuance does the み form of adjectives (turning them into nouns) have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a subjective quality⟯ What sort of nuance do む verbs that stem from い-adjectives have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a subjective quality⟯ What is the nounification form of adjectives that expresses a subjective quality? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the み form⟯ Via which form did the み form of adjectives happen? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;via the む verb forms of these adjectives⟯ Theoretically, to which set of adjectives should み nouns be limited to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the ones that have む verb forms⟯ How do you form the み form of い adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;-い +み⟯

⟮c1;もしか⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;more emphatic version of もし⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 3 kana, ...k... </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-69541ee3084eca1b092b9608145875b3c0eba595.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-ba5a715a0afd0e167d4be2bf182890a24b15bd26.jpg">))⟮c1;　万（まん）(が)　一（いち）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;(noun) unlikely event​, (adverb) by some chance⟯
⟮c1;もしか(して/したら/すると)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;perhaps, maybe, possibly⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 3 possibilities, 5-6 kana </div> </div>
Besides defining something, what is とは often used as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a more emphatic version of と⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What would using "とは" do here? </div><br/>あいつともう関係ない。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Add more emphasis⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why are we using とは instead of と here？ </div><br/>過去とは違う自分 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To add more emphasis⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What are we asking for here? </div><br/>「原子力」とは？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The definition/meaning of 原子力⟯
Besides a more emphatic version of と, what is とは also often used as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To define a word/phrase⟯
What is the particle most often used for defining something? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;とは⟯
When used alone with a word/phrase, what is とは doing? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;asking for the definition of that word⟯
素数⟮c1;とは⟯何かを学んだ。
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-15c49d09c4405e6bc84cf9d8fc96e266eef73a32.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-c3bf914155badb56a5cef7d3c198663a4e5a0911.jpg">))⟮c1;とは思わなかった⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Did not think that (expression)⟯
What can とは be short for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;とは思わなかった⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this sentence gloss as? </div><br/>まさかじ殺するとは <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I never would have thought that he/she would kill himself/herself...⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > とは as とは思わなかった </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-65b5fa60637221b03f9b0889a0f75427eeeaea5d.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-759dba6ed4d731c0636eaa7f5e3525d0d801a109.jpg">))⟮c1;　破（やぶ）く⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;tear, rip を⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> in the case of 破, the ones with k as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, く and ける)&nbsp; are (generally) semantically restricted to tearing, while those with r as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, る and れる) can either have a tearing meaning, but also a meaning of breaking or defeating. The ones ending -u with one kana (that is, く and る) are intransitive (が), the ones ending -eru (that is, ける and れる) are transitive (を) </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-11d8fc7c51102d5b27890b60910d3d2055909969.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-b0d287f18499dfcd7c70162e3c6a03a710538eb5.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-3f2c1ddabca2a03f52a646debb17aedccb1d9180.jpg">))⟮c1;　破（やぶ）ける⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;be torn, get worn out が⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> in the case of 破, the ones with k as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, く and ける)  are (generally) semantically restricted to tearing, while those with r as the first letter of the okurigana (that is, る and れる) can either have a tearing meaning, but also a meaning of breaking or defeating. The ones ending -u with one kana (that is, く and る) are intransitive (が), the ones ending -eru (that is, ける and れる) are transitive (を) </div> </div>

For onomatopoeia, besides the root and root+ん, what can also get reduplicated? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;root+り⟯
When used as a quotation, what particle is used with the onomatopoeia (generally)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;と⟯
みんなにアハハ⟮c1;と⟯笑われた。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Quotation onomatopoeia </div> </div>
When used as an adverb (but not for changes of state), what particle do onomatopoeia take, if not と? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;no particle⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > more casual </div> </div>
When used as an adverb (but not for changes of state), what particle do onomatopoeia take, if not no particle? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;と⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > less casual </div> </div>
When using onomatopoeia as adverbs (but not for changes of state), when is と omitted? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;more casual speech⟯
When using onomatopoeia as adverbs (but not for changes of state), when is と included? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;less casual speech⟯
雷がごろごろ⟮c1;と⟯鳴り始めた。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> と or nothing (adverb) </div> </div>
When being used as an adverb for changes of state, what particle does an onomatopoeia take? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;に⟯
シャツがびしょびしょ⟮c1;に⟯濡れてしまった。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> change of state </div> </div>
この道、がたがた⟮c1;に⟯なってるね。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> change of state </div> </div>
お気に入りのシャツがぼろぼろ⟮c1;に⟯なってしまった。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> change of state </div> </div>
If we want to express the idea of doing an onomatopoeia, what do we add after the onomatopoeia？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;する/やる⟯
汗で下着がじめじめ⟮c1;して⟯いて気持ちが悪い。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> perhaps also やって, although probably not </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > My underwear is soaked in sweat and it feels gross. </div> </div>
なんだか、喉がいがいが⟮c1;する⟯。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> probably also だ and perhaps perhaps, やる, although probably not </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > My throat feels a little sore. </div> </div>
たまにはこうやってみんなで集まってわいわい⟮c1;やる⟯のもいいよね。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> perhaps also する </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It's nice to get together with everyone and be raucous like this sometimes. </div> </div>
How would we express that something <b>is</b>&nbsp;a onomatopoeia? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;as normal with the compula⟯
このまくら、ぐにゃぐにゃ⟮c1;だ⟯よ! <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > This pillow is so squishy! </div> </div>
徹夜続きでくたくた⟮c1;だ⟯。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> general predication </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'm exhausted from being up all night. </div> </div>
「ニコニコ⟮c1;する⟯なっ！ここは陸軍だ！マクドナルドじゃねえぞっ！」<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> perhaps also やる </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > "Don't be smiling! This is the Army, not McDonald's!" </div> </div>
What is sometimes used together with an onomatopoeia, to express some kind of reaction? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;来る⟯
ぼくにはしっくり⟮c1;来ない⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> onomatopoeia 来る reaction </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       It doesn't fit well with me./It doesn't feel right to me. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > implication of reaction </div> </div>

When using onomatopoeia+と, what are we using it for, besides slightly more formal adverb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;quotation⟯

What can you attach to a stem/noun to indicate 'a touch of'or 'looking like'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　気味（ぎみ）⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as, if not looking like stem/noun? </div><br/>stem/noun + 　気味（ぎみ） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;&nbsp;a touch of stem/noun⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > e.g. 風邪気味 = a slight cold, a touch of a cold </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as, if not a touch of stem/noun? </div><br/>stem/noun + 　気味（きみ） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;looking like stem/noun⟯

More formal version of ほかない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;よりほかない⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > is also longer </div> </div>
What does よりほかない mean in comparison to ほかない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the same thing, just more formal⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> this is not parallel to より仕方がない, because ほか already means other than, which make よりほかない and ほかない synonymous. On the other hand e.g. 食べるより仕方がない emphasises the exclusion more than just 食べる仕方がない. </div> </div>

⟮c1;ナースコール⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;nurse's call⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> A nurse call button is a button or cord found in hospitals and nursing homes, at places where patients are at their most vulnerable, such as beside their bed and in the bathroom.[1]. It allows patients in health care settings to alert a nurse or other health care staff member remotely of their need for help. When the button is pressed, a signal alerts staff at the nurse's station, and usually, a nurse or nurse assistant responds to such a call. Some systems also allow the patient to speak directly to the staffer; others simply beep or buzz at the station, requiring a staffer to actually visit the patient's room to determine the patient's needs. </div> </div>

<span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;出す⟯ What connotation does stem + 出す have, when it means to begin sth? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;sudden⟯ To what do you add 出す to imply begin doing something suddenly? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;to the stem⟯ What do you often add to the stem to indicate that a verb ends/completes? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;上げる/上がる⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > starts w a sound </div> </div> What do you add 終わる&nbsp;to to indicate that you finish doing verb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the stem⟯ What do you add 始める to to indicate that you begin doing verb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the stem⟯ What do you add 上げる/上がる after to indicate completion? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a stem⟯ What do you add to the stem to indicate that you finish doing verb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;終わる⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > starts w back vowel </div> </div> What do you add to the stem to indicate that you begin to do verb? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;始める⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > more gradual </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> What does this indicate? </div><br/>stem + 上げる(trans)/上がる(intrans) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That something is made to end / has come to an end⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What does this grammar roughly translate as? </div><br/>stem+終わる <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Finish doing verb⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What does this grammar roughly translate as? </div><br/>stem+始める <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Begin to do verb⟯

When attached to nouns, what does 　達（たち） act as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A pluralizing suffix⟯
When attached to animate nouns, what does 　等（ら） most often act as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A pluralizing suffix⟯
When attached to things, but not acting as a pluralizing suffix, what does 　等（ら） do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;soften the strength⟯
When attached to things, what does 　等（ら）&nbsp;gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;or so/around⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> often as ら辺 (but according to wiktionary, not always: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%AD%89) </div><div class="sub c1-f" > not the plural marker </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>今日　等（ら）  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Around today⟯
そこ⟮c1;等⟯辺<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Around here, hereabouts (softer than without) </div> </div>
What is the most common way of pluralizing 彼? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;彼ら⟯
What is the most common way of pluralizing 彼女? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;彼女たち⟯
What is the most common way of pluralizing 私? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;私たち⟯
Between ら and たち, which is more formal? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ら⟯
僕⟮c1;ら⟯は強くないさ<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > <b>We </b>aren't strong. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 1 kana </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> Kanji spelling for this pluralizing suffix? </div><div class='c1-f'> Kana for this pluralizing suffix? </div><br/>⟮c1;ども⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;共⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> is rarely spelled in kanji though </div> </div>
What connotation does 　共（ども） as a plural marker have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Humble⟯
Why shouldn't you use 　共（ども） for 2nd or 3rd person pronouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because it's humble and thus would be insulting⟯
私⟮c1;　共（ども）⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > We (humble) </div> </div>

In some words, what has happened to the plural markers? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;They have become a calcified part of the word (and thus don't make it plural anymore)⟯

⟮c1;~　方（がた）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Honorific rare pluralizing suffix⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > suffix </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is derived from and identical to in meaning? </div><br/>みな <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;みんな⟯
The distinction between in-group and out-group is the distinction between ___ and ___ in japan <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ウチ and ソト⟯
When speaking with someone from an outgroup (外), whom do you kenjougo? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;everyone in your 内⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> even your boss! </div> </div>

How do some dictionaries distinguish 音読み and 訓読み? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;They write the 音読み in katakana and the 訓読み in hiragana⟯

<span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A form of suru⟯ (How) can you create the negative form of たり? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;neg past + り⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > as you would expect </div> </div> たり form of だ? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;attach り⟯ To create the たり form, to what form do you conjugate first? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;past⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > positive or negative </div> </div> In a list of past tense + り, what do you need to put at the end of the sentence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;する (or a conjugation of する)⟯ What do you attach to what to create an "and/or/etc." list for verbs? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;り to the past tense⟯ What is the ～たり-する construction the noun/adjective equivalent of, but for verbs? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It is unpronounced (but still implied)⟯

Across most of it's varied uses, what effect does なんて have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;emphasis⟯

<div class='c2-f'> Alternative for? </div><div class='c1-f'> Alternative for? </div><br/>⟮c1;くらい⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;ぐらい⟯
What does stem + 切る gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To do completely, to use up⟯ To indicate "to do completely/use up", you use what form + 切る? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stem⟯ To indicate "to do completely/use up", you use stem + what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;切る⟯ In the stem + 切れない construction, what is sometimes substituted for 切れない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;しきれない⟯ As a derivative of the stem + 切る form, what is used for 'unable to finish sth'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stem + 切れない⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> just pot + neg </div> </div>
お肉が売り⟮c1;切った⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The meat has sold out. </div> </div>
本を⟮c1;読み⟯切った。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I read the book all the way through. / from front to back </div> </div>
命⟮c1;短し⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The first line of the ballad ゴンドラの 唄 , a popular  大正  era romantic ballad later used as the theme song for the 1952 movie  生 きる , one of the most famous movies by director  黒澤 明 </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 終止形, classical jp </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Life is brief </div> </div>
Where does the じゃ in the sense of e.g. じゃ, 始めましょうか？ come from? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Contraction of では⟯

What are the items listed by や (and similar particles, e.g. とか) implied to be semantically? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;In the same category⟯
⟮c1;　彼（か）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Distal demonstrative (similar to あれ)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> generally archaic </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kanji made up of one kana </div> </div>
⟮c1;　彼（かれ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Distal demonstrative (similar to あれ)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The sense development seems to have proceeded from "that thing over there" to "that person over there [of indeterminate gender]". The specifically male sense of "he" only arose later during the late Edo period and early Meiji period, influenced by translations of texts from European languages. </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > not the person meaning </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kanji made up of 2 kana </div> </div>
⟮c1;かの⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Distal demonstrative&nbsp; determiner (similar to あの)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> As an adnominal, kano must be followed by a noun or noun phrase.  The term kano has been mostly replaced by あの (ano) in modern Japanese. Kano is still in use, but is viewed as more formal and archaic.[2]  Most often written in kana. </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > not the person meaning </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > also spelled 彼の </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kana </div> </div>

What does や to indicate emphasis attach to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Adverbs⟯
What adverbs can you attach や to to indicate emphasis? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;only a limited set⟯

How strong does し come on? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Relatively strong⟯
What does し as a particle follow, for verbs, when not being polite? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形)⟯

What does し as a particle follow, for い adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形)⟯
What does し as a particle follow, for な adjectives? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形 + だ)⟯
What does し as a particle follow, for nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the 終止形 (which is the 辞書形 + copula)⟯

When listing with し, what can it sometimes indicate, in addition to reason? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;contrast⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What could you optionally add here? </div><br/> お金もないし、車もない <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a second し⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> as with all list particles, the last instance is optional </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > or a から </div> </div>
お金もない⟮c1;し⟯、車もない⟮c1;し⟯…<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I don't have any money, I don't have a car (,  so)... </div> </div>
綺麗だ⟮c1;し⟯、広い⟮c1;し⟯、いいね、このアパート<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It's clean, it's spacious, this appartment is nice! (,  so I want to buy it) </div> </div>
 彼氏は、タバコも吸｛⟮c1;う⟯・⟮c1;います⟯｝し、お酒も飲みます。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　My boyfriend smokes and drinks.  </div> </div>
その映画は見たい⟮c1;し⟯、お金はない⟮c1;し⟯、どうしよう。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> し as contrast </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　 I want to watch that movie, but I don't have the money...what am I going to do...  </div> </div>
歯は痛い⟮c1;し⟯、歯医者には行きたくない⟮c1;し⟯、困ったよ。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> し as contrast </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     My teeth hurt, but I don't want to go to the doctor, I'm in a rut!  </div> </div>
台風は来る⟮c1;し⟯、仕事はある⟮c1;し⟯、本当に困ったよ。  <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> し as contrast </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     The typhoon's coming, but I got my job. And so, I'm really at a loss.   </div> </div>
職は失うし、妻とは別れるし（⟮c1;で⟯）、彼はひどく元気がない。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >      Losing his job, splitting up with his wife, he is really depressed.  </div> </div>
When し is used as a sentence-final particle, what is doing? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Giving a reason (for something that was said before or implied)⟯
荷物が多いし、雨も降ってきた(⟮c1;し⟯・⟮c1;から⟯・⟮c1;ø⟯)、どこかで休もうか。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > We've a lot of luggage, and it's started to rain, so shall we take a break somewhere? </div> </div>
せっかくパリまで来たんだから、観光でもしよう。天気もいい⟮c1;し⟯。
<div class='c1-f'> What is the second sentence doing here? </div><br/>このお店はすごくおいしいですよ。かなり安いですし。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Providing additional justification&nbsp;⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is the し doing here? </div><br/>上海の不動産価格は去年1年間で24％増加し、今では中国で1番高くなっています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;formal connective of する⟯
What occurrence of し might be easy to confuse with the particle し? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;し as formal connective&nbsp;⟯

In traditional japanese grammar, what part of u-verbs is considered to be part of the 　語（ご）　幹（かん）? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Everything besides the final consonant + u⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > e.g. の for 飲む </div> </div>

What kind of connotation does で<b>は</b>ある have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;contrastive⟯
What does ではある roughly mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the same as である = copula⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > although it has a contrastive implication, due to the contrastive は </div> </div>
What does ではない work nearly parallel to？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;じゃない⟯
女性⟮c1;ではある⟯が、彼女はこのバーベルを持ち上げられる。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Woman as she is, she can lift this barbell. </div><br><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > strong contrastive implication </div> </div>
彼女はせんさく好き⟮c1;ではある⟯けれども私は彼女が好きだ。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > She is inquisitive, but I like her none the worse. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > strong contrastive implication </div> </div>
学者⟮c1;ではある⟯が、彼は信頼されていない。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Scholarly as he is, he can't be relied on. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > strong contrastive implication </div> </div>

How do you turn の-adjectives into adverbs? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;add に as with な-adjectives⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this become? </div><br/>の-adjective + に <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;An adverb⟯
how many adjectives can use both な and の to modify nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;probably most な/の adjectives⟯
What is a way to look at (at least some) long compound nouns coming into being in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;の-phrases where the の is dropped⟯
What is the difference between の and な-adjectives, in terms of how they are used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;only that one uses の and the other uses な to modify nouns⟯
For nouns that can use both な and の, what does changing from one to the other change? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the nuance/feel⟯
If both are possible, what is the difference between な and の, in particular? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;な is somewhat more softer, more personal, casual⟯
What might happen to the variability between な and の in some set phrases? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;In some set phrases, the use of な over の or v.v. may have become mandatory⟯
Besides a corresponding な-adj/な-based 連体詞, what adjective(al) form do some い-adjectives also have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a の-based adjective/連体詞⟯
What do most の-based 連体詞 sound like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;archaic/literary⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What kind of 連体詞 is this? </div><br/>　長（なが）の <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;one based on の⟯
How are 連体詞 generated from い adjectives (when they are), as to what gets removed? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the い gets removed⟯
How are most (?) 連体詞 generated from い adjectives, after the い was removed? (two options) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;な/の gets attached⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What kind of thing is 青 acting as here? </div><br/>青の時間  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a ノ形容詞⟯
What could we say 青い, 青(の), 青(な) as well as e.g. 青空 share? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a 'root'  青⟯
What is 青 doing in 青い, 青(な), 青(の), 青空?&nbsp; <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;being realized in different ways⟯
Adjective stems like 青 can be realized in a number of different ways, of which I currently know 4 (though not all adjectives can be realized in all of these ways): ⟮c1;青い⟯, ⟮c2;青(の)⟯, ⟮c3;青(な)⟯ as well as ⟮c4;青 based- compound (e.g. 青空)⟯
Negative + raised intonation =&nbsp; <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;question which presumes a positive answer⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>遅くない？ + raised intonation <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Aren't you late?⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> cf. https://ameblo.jp/hachi-yellow-rug/entry-12569681239.html for real world examples </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div><br/>多い人 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;多い can't be in the adnominal position as-is⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div><br/>少ない人  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;少ない can't be in the adnominal position⟯
Where can 多い and 少ない not appear? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;In the adnominal position⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> https://www.imabi.net/ooisukunai.htm https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%B0%91%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84#Japanese </div><div class="sub all-b"> except rarely, and of course as part of modifying vps </div> </div>
Which two common words indicating amount cannot generally appear in the adnominal position? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;多い and 少ない⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> https://www.imabi.net/ooisukunai.htm https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%B0%91%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84#Japanese </div> </div>
In what way <b>can</b>&nbsp;and are 多い and 少ない often used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;as a predicate⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Where's the problem? </div><br/>公園にはベンチが<mark>多い</mark>です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;There is no problem, one can use 多い as a predicate⟯
When <b>can</b>&nbsp;多い and 少ない precede nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;if they're part of a modfying adnominal phrase⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since they are then acting as a predicate </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > also rarely on their own </div> </div>
Why can 多い and 少ない precede nouns when part of a modifying verb phrase? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because they are then acting as a predicate⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Where's the problem? </div><br/>私はお金が<mark>少ない</mark>です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;There is no problem⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Is part of modifying VP and thus predicate </div> </div>
私はお⟮c1;金が少ない⟯です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Okay since predicate&nbsp; </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I have little money </div> </div>
What is the rare exception that allows 少ない to work in the adnominal position proper? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;When indicating sheer scarcity⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is adominal position 少ない okay here? </div><br/>少ない給料でお金を貯める。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because it's indicating the sheer scarcity⟯
When used in the context of quantities, where we in english would use 'little' or 'large', what words are often used in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;少ない/多い⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is this grammatical, despite the literal translation of: "Small children have few vocabulary"? </div><br/>幼い子供は語いが少ない。  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because in the context of things which are quantifiable, 少ない is used even where we would say small in english⟯
ヨーロッパはアジアより人口が⟮c1;少ない⟯。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> 少ない for quantifiable things where we use ’small' in english </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Europe has a smaller population than Asia. </div> </div>
For what kind of things do you use 少ない, where in english you would use 'small'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Things that are quantifiable⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > vocabulary (=amount of voc items), portion (=amount of food in a portion), ... </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is 多い being used here? </div><br/> シアトルでは雨が多いです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because 多い/少ない is often used for frequency⟯
テキサス州では雨が⟮c1;少ない⟯です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> 多い/少ない for frequency </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >      There is little rain in Texas.  </div> </div>
Besides たくさん, what is often used to quantify rain? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;多い/少ない⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> in line with the usage of 多い/少ない for amounts </div> </div>
What kind semantic idea&nbsp; must the thing have that 多い / 少ない predicate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Something quantifiable⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div><br/>ムンバイは多い街です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ムンバイ is not quantifiable⟯
ムンバイは⟮c1;人口が⟯多い街です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >        Mumbai is a town with a large population.  </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since 多い must quantify something quantifiable </div> </div>
Besides using 同じ construction, what is also often used to indicate "the same"? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;同 as a prefix morpheme⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > morphology </div> </div>
What kind of adjective is 同じ?&nbsp; <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<br>It's a hybrid!⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > but mostly な </div> </div>
What kind of adjectives is 同じ most often like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;な-adjectives⟯
Onaji as predicate/終止形 (nonpolite present) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;同じだ⟯
Onaji as 終止形 (polite past) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;同じでした⟯
Why is it 同じだ, 同じです etc.? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because 同じ most often behaves like a な-adjective⟯
How does 同じ connect to nouns? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Without a particle!⟯
What sort of form of 同じ is 同じに? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Adverbial⟯
What sort of form of 同じ is 同じく? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Adverbial⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> reminiscent of the time when 同じ was similar to other adjectives that today are い-adjectives </div> </div>
What does 同じく gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;same as..., ditto⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What form of onaji is 同じくhere, and is that okay? </div><br/>彼と同じく私もイギリス出身です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;&nbsp;legitimate adverbial of 同じ⟯
The two most common adverbials of 同じ are... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;同じに and 同じく⟯
What does 同じよう (often + に) gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the same way as/similarly/like⟯
ほぼ⟮c1;同じ⟯意味です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It has almost the same meaning.  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it 同じ here, and not 同じな? </div><br/>僕たちは同じ学校に通っています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because 同じ goes before nouns without any modifiers⟯
Why is it weird that な goes between 同じ and の? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because there is no な when modifying nouns (for 同じ)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's missing here? </div><br/>同じのです <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a な⟯
日本語と同じ⟮c1;です・だ⟯ね。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> な-adj-like conjugation </div> </div>
 昨日とおんなじ⟮c1;です・だ⟯よ。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> <br>な-adj-like conjugation </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It’s the same as yesterday.  </div> </div>
⟮c1;　無声化（むせいか）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;devoicing⟯

One or more radicals make up what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A kanji⟯
Internally, in what direction are kanji generally written? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;left to right⟯
⟮c1;　偏（へん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;left-hand radical of a character⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > e.g. 他の人 </div> </div>
⟮c1;　旁（つくり）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;right-hand radical of a character⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > e.g. 鳴の鳥 </div> </div>

⟮c1;　脚（あし）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;bottom radical of a character⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > e.g. 思の心 </div> </div>

How do 　新（しん）　字（じ）　体（たい） and simplified chinese characters relate? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Signficant differences, but some are the same⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > In Chinese, many more characters were simplified than in Japanese; some characters were simplified only in the one language, but not in the other; other characters were simplified in the same way in both languages, others in different ways. This means that those who want to learn the writing systems of both Chinese and Japanese must sometimes learn three different variations of one character: traditional Chinese, simplified Chinese, and modern Japanese. </div> </div>
In japanese, simplified characters are called? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　新（しん）　字（じ）　体（たい）⟯

⟮c1;　象（しょう）　形（けい）(　文（も）　字（じ）)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Pictogram/graph⟯ ⟮c1;　指事（しじ）(　文（も）　字（じ）)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Ideogram/graph⟯ What kind of grapheme is 川? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Pictogram⟯ What is the relationship between an ideogram and the thing it represents, in contrast with the relationship between thing and pictograph? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A few steps removed, not direct⟯ What are some examples for ideographic kanji? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;一  二  三  上  下  天  今  母  音  立⟯ The writing system in which <b>letters</b>/graphemes and phonemes correspond <b>1 to 1 </b>(at least in theory) is called? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;An alphabet⟯ In theory, in an alphabet, what should a grapheme/letter correspond to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a phoneme⟯ In an alphabet, what does a phoneme theoretically correspond to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a grapheme/letter⟯ In a writing system, what must people use in representing something pictographically? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The same pictograph = a conventional form⟯ Characters in which a grapheme represents an idea/concept by association are called what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Ideograms/graphs⟯ Characters in which a grapheme represents a real physical thing by resemblance are called what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Pictograms/graphs⟯ A pictogram is a grapheme used to represent what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;something that can be directly sensed, is 'real'⟯ <div class='c2-f'> In an alphabet, what is this called? </div><div class='c1-f'> In an alphabet, what is this the name for (More universal concept)? </div><br/>⟮c1;Grapheme⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Letter⟯

⟮c1;　大和（やまと）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;The country of japan, esp. ancient japan⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> From older 邪馬台 (yamatai). <div class='c1-f'> In this pitch pattern, which morae is/are high? </div><br/>((h:1;::<img src="sm_odakagata.jpg">))　尾（お）　高（だか）　型（がた） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The final mora (not suffix)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> In this pitch pattern, which morae is/are low, besides the first mora? </div><br/>((h:1;::<img src="sm_odakagata.jpg">))　尾（お）　高（だか）　型（がた） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;any suffix mora⟯
<div class='c1-f'> In this pitch pattern, which morae is/are low? </div><br/>((h:1;::<img src="sm_heibangata.jpg">))　平（へい）　板（ばん）　型（がた） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The first mora&nbsp;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > theoretically, this doesn't reach the height of the accented mora on the other three </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> In this pitch pattern, which morae is/are high? </div><br/>((h:1;::<img src="sm_heibangata.jpg">))　平（へい）　板（ばん）　型（がた） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Everything but the first⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > theoretically, this doesn't reach the height of the accented mora on the other three </div> </div>
How does the pitch-accent system behave across japan? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It varies⟯
How many japanese dialects have pitch accent? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Most but not all⟯
When humans change pitch, how does it happen? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;(somewhat) gradually⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > physiological necessity </div> </div>
What must any pitch change be, by necessity of biology? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;(somewhat) gradually⟯
<div class='c1-f'> In this pitch pattern, which mora is low, besides the last+suffixes? </div><br/>((h:1;::<img src="sm_nakadakagata1.jpg">))((h:1;::<img src="sm_nakadakagata2.jpg">))　中（なか）　高（だか）　型（がた） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the first⟯
<div class='c1-f'> In this pitch pattern, which morae is/are low, besides the suffix morae? </div><br/>((h:1;::<img src="sm_odakagata.jpg">))　尾（お）　高（だか）　型（がた） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the first mora⟯

Plural of mora <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;morae⟯
How useful is the concept of a mora outside of japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Of limited use, and kind of blurry⟯
How many kanji does the 漢字能力検定一級 (the most comprehensive kanji proficiency test) cover? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;6000⟯
What word order is japanes traditionally said to have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;SOV⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Reorder so this reflects the general tendency for japanese word order! </div><br/>LOCATION TIME TOPIC  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;TOPIC TIME LOCATION⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > + SUBJECT + INDIRECT OBJECT + DIRECT OBJECT + VERB </div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >Word order is alphabetical, not indicative of goal</div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Reorder so this reflects the general tendency for japanese word order! TOPIC + TIME + LOCATION + </div><br/> <q>DIRECT OBJECT</q> <q>INDIRECT OBJECT</q> <q>SUBJECT</q> <q>VERB</q> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;<q>SUBJECT</q> <q>INDIRECT OBJECT</q> <q>DIRECT OBJECT</q> <q>VERB</q>⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >Word order is alphabetical, not indicative of goal</div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Reorder so this reflects the general tendency for japanese word order! </div><br/><q>INDIRECT OBJECT DIRECT OBJECT</q><q>LOCATION SUBJECT</q><q>TOPIC TIME</q><q>VERB</q>  <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> <span class="empty-cloze-generation-only">⟮c1;⟯</span><br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >Word order is alphabetical, not indicative of goal</div><q>TOPIC TIME</q><q>LOCATION SUBJECT</q><q>INDIRECT OBJECT DIRECT OBJECT</q><q>VERB</q> </div>
Japanese general sentence order: ⟮c1;TOPIC⟯ + ⟮c2;TIME⟯ + ⟮c3;LOCATION⟯ + ⟮c1;SUBJECT⟯ + ⟮c2;INDIRECT OBJECT⟯ + ⟮c1;DIRECT OBJECT⟯ + ⟮c3;VERB⟯ 
Japanese general sentence order: ⟮c2;TOPIC⟯ + ⟮c2;TIME⟯ + ⟮c2;LOCATION⟯ + ⟮c1;SUBJECT⟯ + ⟮c1;INDIRECT OBJECT⟯ + ⟮c1;DIRECT OBJECT⟯ + VERB 
In japanese names, what is the order of first and last names? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Last name first name⟯
<span class="hide-5">In japanese, how are</span> foregin names <span class="hide-5">ordered?</span> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;how they would normally be ordered in that language (First name last name for en)⟯
When inverting japanese sentences, what is most often / at minimum moved to the front? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The verb <span class="aside">and SFPs</span>⟯
If the verb starts a longer japanese clause, what has probably happened? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It was moved to the front⟯
What words are not 　自（じ）　立（りつ）　語（ご）, besides 助詞? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;助動詞⟯
What words are not 　自（じ）　立（りつ）　語（ご）, besides 助動詞? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;助詞⟯
What words are not 　自（じ）　立（りつ）　語（ご）, besides 助動詞 and 助詞? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;all other words are 自立語⟯
What kind of words are 助動詞 and 助詞? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　付属語（ふぞくご）⟯
⟮c1;　数（すう）　詞（し）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Numeral (grammar)⟯
⟮c1;　副（ふく）　詞（し）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;adverb (japanese grammar)⟯
⟮c1;　接（せつ）　続（ぞく）　詞（し）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;conjunction (japanese grammar)⟯
⟮c1;　感（かん）　動（どう）　詞（し）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;interjection (japanese grammar)⟯
⟮c1;　侮蔑語（ぶべつご）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;degrading language (opposite of 敬語)⟯
謙譲語 and 尊敬語 are both forms of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;敬語⟯
What is the relationship between 謙譲語 , 尊敬語 and 敬語? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;謙譲語 and 尊敬語 parts of 敬語⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > in some extremely limited sense, they might be considered the things making up 敬語 exclusively, but most people would include 丁寧語, 丁重語 should be included if 謙譲語 is and we're distingishing them, and 美化語 is sometimes also included </div> </div>
What language family is Japanese a part of? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The japonic languages⟯
What is the other undisputed japonic language, besides japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Ryukyuan⟯

In general in japanese, the ⟮c1;longer⟯ a phrase is, the ⟮c2;politer⟯ it is.
田中さんは先生では⟮c1;polite (丁寧語)::ありませんでした・なかったです⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Mr. Tanaka was not a teacher. </div> </div>
それはコーヒーでは⟮c1;polite (丁寧語)::ありませんでした・なかったです⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > That wasn’t coffee. </div> </div>
小田さんは住民では⟮c1;polite (丁寧語)::ありませんでした・なかったです⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Mr. Oda was not a resident. </div> </div>
な-adjectives are also often called&nbsp; ___ ___ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;adjectival nouns⟯
⟮c1;　主格（しゅかく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;nominative case⟯
<div class='c2-f'> Kanji for? </div><div class='c1-f'> Kana for? </div><br/>⟮c1;なぜ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;何故⟯
Transforming mediopassive into active sentence.<br/><pre><code data-codetype="text">電気がついた。 ジェイムズ⟮c1;が⟯電気⟮c1;を⟯つけた。</code></pre>
Transforming active into mediopassive sentence.<br/><pre><code data-codetype="text">ジェイムズが電気をつけた。 電気⟮c1;が⟯ついた。</code></pre>
Transforming active into mediopassive sentence.<br/><pre><code data-codetype="text">雄太がビールを冷やした。 ビール⟮c1;が⟯冷えた。</code></pre>
Transforming active into mediopassive sentence.<br/><pre><code data-codetype="text">ビールが冷えた。 雄太⟮c1;が⟯ビール⟮c1;を⟯冷やした。</code></pre>
机⟮c1;が⟯売れる。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Intrans verb -&gt; が </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The desk sells well. </div> </div>
机⟮c1;を⟯売る。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> 自動詞 verb -&gt; を </div><div class="sub all-b"> In the case of が, the desk would do the selling. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > To sell a desk. </div> </div>
What kind of feeling does を bring with it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A feeling of volition⟯
When を is used as a transition marker, what sort of verbs is it used with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;both transitive and intransitive verbs⟯
When を is used as a transition marker, what case does it (not) mark? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It doesn't necessarily mark the accusative for these uses⟯
The use of を for motion through a place can more generally stated as を being... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a transition marker⟯
When を is acting as a transition marker, what semantic field do the verbs have to have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Related to motion⟯
What does 沸かす take as an object when it means 'to boil water'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;お湯⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> not 水 </div> </div>
When used as a transition marker, how might be を translated? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Along, through, across⟯
When used as a transition marker, besides space and degree, what can を transition through? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;time⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>((h:1;::<img src="sm_paste-a0b142f2d4490dc2dc83e1b5c2791eb85e61b20e.jpg">))日本橋を渡りました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Someone crossed the Nihonbashi Bridge.⟯

<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>空を飛びました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I flew through/across the sky. ⟯
彼は下り坂⟮c1;を⟯走った<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > He ran downhill.  </div> </div>
公園⟮c1;を⟯走りました。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> transition marker </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I ran through the park.  </div> </div>
アユは川⟮c1;を⟯下った。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> transition marker </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The sweetfish descended the river.  </div> </div>
⟮c1;　下（くだ）り　坂（ざか）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;downhill⟯
⟮c1;　上（のぼ）り　坂（ざか）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;uphill⟯
What is sometimes used to help を create the meaning of 'torward' for the direction of action grammar? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;の　方（ほう）⟯
When using の　方（ほう）を, what interpretation of を does it make more likely? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;を as torward (direction of action)⟯
With what kind of verbs can を as direction of action be used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;both transitive and intransitive⟯
Uses of を include ⟮c1;direct object (acc) marker⟯, ⟮c2;transition marker⟯, ⟮c3;direction of action⟯, ⟮c4;origin of action⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div><br/>角を曲がった。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Acting the marker of direction of action⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I turned the corner. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > arguably this could also be transition marking </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div><br/> 岐阜のほうを眺めました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Acting the marker of direction of action⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > Which is just a specialization of marking the direct object </div> </div>
翔平は先生のほう⟮c1;を⟯向いた。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Shohei faced the teacher.  </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > marker of direction of action </div> </div>
Due to the varied uses of を, what can theoretically happen? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;There could be two or more を in a single sentence⟯
Why are there rarely actually two or more を in a single sentence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because one of the を will be left out⟯
Why will a を often be left out if there are two or more? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because it's generally discouraged to double case particles⟯
If a を or other case particle was left out, how does the grammar act? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;as if it was still there⟯
When indicating the origin of departure, which particle is を often though not always interchangeable with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;から⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div><br/>電車を降りました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Acting as a origin of departure marker⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div><br/>家を出ました <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Acting as a origin of departure marker⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is を doing here? </div><br/>妻は７時にうちを出ました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Acting as a origin of departure marker⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > not just acc marker, because 出る is intransitive </div> </div>
What can を as the departure marker do, that から can't? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Be used for leaving for non-physical locations⟯

What conjugations can be placed before NPs to modify them? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;almost all non-polite ones⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div><br/>食べないです <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;There is no problem, this is casual, but legal (!)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > <a href="https://japanese.stackexchange.com/questions/29889/do-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99-and-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%AA%E3%81%8B%E3%81%A3%E3%81%9F%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99-have-the-same-level-of-politeness-as-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%BE%E3%81%9B%E3%82%93-and-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%BE%E3%81%9B%E3%82%93%E3%81%A7%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F-h">https://japanese.stackexchange.com/questions/29889/do-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99-and-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%AA%E3%81%8B%E3%81%A3%E3%81%9F%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99-have-the-same-level-of-politeness-as-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%BE%E3%81%9B%E3%82%93-and-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%BE%E3%81%9B%E3%82%93%E3%81%A7%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F-h</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://www.imabi.net/regularverbsi.htm">https://www.imabi.net/regularverbsi.htm</a> </div> </div>

<div class='c2-f'> How do you create this? </div><div class='c1-f'> What form is this? </div><br/>⟮c1;Alternative casual spoken polite past negative verb version⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;未然形なかったです⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> <a href="https://japanese.stackexchange.com/questions/29889/do-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99-and-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%AA%E3%81%8B%E3%81%A3%E3%81%9F%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99-have-the-same-level-of-politeness-as-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%BE%E3%81%9B%E3%82%93-and-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%BE%E3%81%9B%E3%82%93%E3%81%A7%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F-h">https://japanese.stackexchange.com/questions/29889/do-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%AA%E3%81%84%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99-and-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%AA%E3%81%8B%E3%81%A3%E3%81%9F%E3%81%A7%E3%81%99-have-the-same-level-of-politeness-as-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%BE%E3%81%9B%E3%82%93-and-%E9%A3%9F%E3%81%B9%E3%81%BE%E3%81%9B%E3%82%93%E3%81%A7%E3%81%97%E3%81%9F-h</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://www.imabi.net/regularverbsi.htm">https://www.imabi.net/regularverbsi.htm</a> </div> </div>
How can you create negative forms of verbs, besides the ません＆ませんでした versions? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ない・なかった＋です⟯
U verbs are called what in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　五段（ごだん）(　動詞（どうし）)⟯
　一段（いちだん）(　動詞（どうし）) are the verbs I usually call what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;る verbs⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-afb57d72cc9342d3e533d01286ca16e97433f570.jpg">))⟮c1;アニソン⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Anime song⟯
<div class='c1-f'> ます-form </div><br/>待つ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;待ちます⟯
<div class='c1-f'> ます-form </div><br/>死ぬ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;死にます⟯
<div class='c1-f'> ます-form </div><br/>呼ぶ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;呼びます⟯
<div class='c1-f'> ます-form </div><br/>会う <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;会います⟯
<div class='c1-f'> past simple </div><br/>巻く <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;巻いた⟯
<div class='c1-f'> past simple </div><br/>叫ぶ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;叫んだ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> how is this sometimes read, besides いう? </div><br/>言う <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ゆう⟯
When 言う is read ゆう, what is the past tense? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ゆった⟯
Where does ゆった come from, most of the time? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Past tense of いう read as ゆう⟯
Why is 言う sometimes read as ゆう? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because ゆう is easier to say⟯
Casual polite negative of する <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;しないです ⟯
+cas-pol +neg +past する <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;しなかったです⟯

<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>レンタルも5000円します。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Rentals also cost 5,000 yen.⟯
When in combination with (esp. list) price, what does する mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To cost⟯
What very common verb means to cost when in context of transactions, esp. the list price? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;する⟯

To sense/feel/feel that sth<br/>Something⟮c1;が⟯⟮c1;する⟯

To be/work as<br/>Occupation+⟮c1;を⟯+⟮c1;して⟯⟮c1;いる⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>料理人をしています。  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I am a cook. ⟯
銀行員を⟮c1;polite::しています⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I am a bank clerk.  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>X顔をform of する <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Wear a X look, make a X face, have a X face⟯

<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>X振りをform of する <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Pretend to be/do X⟯

<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>X目付きをform of する <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To have a x expression in ones eyes⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>X形をform of する <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;To be shaped like x, to take the form of x⟯
Wear a X look, make a X face, have a X face<br/>X⟮c1;顔⟯⟮c1;を⟯⟮c1;form of する⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > Whole face </div> </div>
Have X (e.g. brown) eyes<br/>X⟮c1;目⟯⟮c1;を⟯⟮c1;form of する⟯
Pretend to be/do X<br/>X⟮c1;振り⟯⟮c1;を⟯⟮c1;form of する⟯
To have a x appeareance<br/>X⟮c1;2 kanji::格好⟯⟮c1;を⟯⟮c1;form of する⟯

To be shaped like x, to take the form of x<br/>X⟮c1;形⟯⟮c1;を⟯⟮c1;form of する⟯
What verb is used for playing games/sports? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;する/やる⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-dfb889f221b1036bb3185e7fe14ea063e765a5c6.jpg">))⟮c1;アメフト⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;american football (short)⟯
⟮c1;バスケ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;basketball (short)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is the verb used here する? </div><br/>アメフトをします <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because する (or やる) is used for playing sports⟯
パチンコを⟮c1;しましょう・しよう⟯よ<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> する/やる is used for playing sports and the like </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Let's play pachinko. </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-022e8fbd4f6aff80c0c5270f233c87effb59684b.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-9fc0fd0a0632290d8e282567ed2fd18d962d052b.jpg">))⟮c1;　生（い）け　花（ばな）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;flower arrangement⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> lit. making flowers come alive </div><div class="sub all-b"> The tradition dates back to Heian period, when floral offerings were made at altars. Later, flower arrangements were instead used to adorn the tokonoma (alcove) of a traditional Japanese home.  Ikebana reached its first zenith in the 16th century under the influence of Buddhist tea masters and has grown over the centuries, with numerous distinct schools extant today.  Ikebana is counted as one of the three classical Japanese arts of refinement, along with kōdō for incense appreciation and chadō for tea and the tea ceremony. </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-7f10279fd4393d2482be8543692adb9017cfb8e4.jpg">))⟮c1;　華・花（か）　道（どう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;flower arrangement⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> lit way of the flowers </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji </div> </div>
冷たい⟮c1;目をする⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > To have cold eyes.  </div> </div>
鋭い⟮c1;目付きをする⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > To have a sharp look in ones eyes </div> </div>
あの子は可愛い⟮c1;顔をして⟯いますね。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > phrasal construction </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > That kid has a cute face, doesn’t he/she?  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>彼はラフな格好をしていますね。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;He looks rough/is dressed rough, isn't he?⟯
アメフトを｛⟮c1;します⟯・⟮c1;やります⟯｝<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (polite) I'll play american football. </div> </div>
How do we indicate a question, besides by adding some particle or other part of speech? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;rising intonation⟯
What does adding だ to a question word such as 何, 誰, etc. do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Increase its forcefulness as a question⟯
How can you increase the forcefulness of a question word (often used at the end of a sentence)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;add だ⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> even stronger: だよ </div> </div>
誰⟮c1;だ⟯！？<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Forceful question </div> </div>
鍵はどこ⟮c1;だ⟯？<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > forceful </div> </div>
When using か with non-polite questions directed at other people, how does it sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;forceful, rude⟯
When using か with non-polite y-n questions, like what situation does it sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Like an interrogation⟯
To what group of people is か as y-n non polite question marker usually restricted? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;casual male⟯
大丈夫⟮c1;か⟯?<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > rough casual male </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > You alright?  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it か here? </div><br/>あんた、行くか? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Rough casual male y/n question⟯
<div class='c1-f'> How does this sound? </div><br/>君はあほか? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Rough, male⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it か here? </div><br/>さ、行くか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Rethorical question to self⟯
雨、降った⟮c1;か⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Rethorical question to self </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>もう時間（です）か。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It's already time, huh...⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>違いますか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Am I wrong? / Is it wrong?⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>座席はどこがいいですか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;What seat(s) is/are good?⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>日本のどこが好きですか？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;What part of Japan do you like (the most)?/What do you like about Japan?⟯
When used as a question, what does neg (polite or not) + か sound like, in comparison to the same construct with の・ん? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;rougher, more presumptive⟯
When used as a question, what does neg (polite or not) + の・ん&nbsp;+ か sound like, in comparison to the same construct without&nbsp;の・ん? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;less presumptive, softer⟯
When used as a solicitation, what does neg (polite or not) + の・ん&nbsp;+ か sound like, in comparison to the same construct without&nbsp;の・ん? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;less like a solicitation, and more like a question after intensions⟯
When used as a solicitation, what does neg (polite or not) + か sound like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Like a solicitation (let's)⟯
What does pos/neg + の? sound like? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;A soft-ish question⟯
As somewhat of an exception to the rules, what is one expecting when one asks 'ないのか'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a negative answer⟯
As somewhat of an exception to the rules, how does 'ないのか' sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;very rough⟯
In what situation might one use 'ないのか'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;when feelings are flaring⟯
Where does じゃん originally come from (and sometimes still act as a short version of)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;as a short version of じゃないか⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/> いいじゃん <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;That's good/great/sounds great!, It's okay, right?⟯
<div class='c1-f'> <br>What does this gloss as? </div><br/>あれはタヌキじゃん! <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Well is that not a tanuki!⟯
Weirdly, what can one add e.g. to <b>ん</b>じゃない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;の⟯
<div class='c1-f'> <br><br> </div><br/>How does ないの sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Relatively soft⟯
<div class='c1-f'> <br><br> </div><br/>How does ないのか sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Very harsh⟯
<div class='c1-f'> <br><br> </div><br/>How does ませんか sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;reasonably neutral, like a solicitation⟯
How does んですか? sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;reasonably neutral, interested⟯
<div class='c1-f'> <br><br> </div><br/>How does ないですか? sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a little harsh, but mostly like a solicitation⟯
<div class='c1-f'> <br><br> </div><br/>How does ないんですか? sound? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;reasonably neutral⟯
What can happen to particles (among others を, が, は and に) sometimes in casual speech? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;they can be dropped⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why no を?<br><br> </div><br/>キャンディー、食べない？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It was dropped⟯

ある・いる can take what type of objects (are what type of verb)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;with が (are intransitive=自動詞)⟯
When used for ownership, for いる・ある, with what particle is the thing owned marked? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;が⟯
When used for ownership, for いる・ある, with what particle is the owner marked? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;には・は⟯
私たち⟮c1;（に）は⟯十分なお金⟮c1;が⟯あります。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > We (for one) have enough money.  </div> </div>

<div class='c1-f'> Why is 友達 marked with が? </div><br/>私（に）は友達がいません。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Because いる is intransitive⟯
The thing needed by 要る is marked by what? (what kind of verb is 要る) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;が (要る is intransitive)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > は is also possible, as always, of course </div> </div>
Between いる and 必要+copula, what is the difference? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;必要+copula is more objective⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > and also more broad </div> </div>
For expressions of skill such as 上手, うまい, 苦手 etc., what is the skill marked with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;が⟯
私は料理⟮c1;が⟯得意です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I’m good at cooking.  </div> </div>
英語が苦手です⟮c1;が⟯、頑張ります。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I’m bad at English, but I’ll try.  </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 1 kana </div> </div>
 彼女はメイク⟮c1;が⟯下手だ。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > She’s bad at makeup.  </div> </div>
 子供⟮c1;が⟯欲しいです。
What is the thing you want marked with for 欲しい? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;が⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is 相手 marked with が? </div><br/>話し相手が欲しいです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Cause 欲しい takes が for the thing thats wanted.⟯

What main function does は have, besides being the topic marker? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;It acts as the contrast marker⟯
What might the topic marker function of は be subsumed under (according to some theories)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The contrast marker⟯
Since は often (perhaps actually always) acts as the contrast marker, what can happen in a given sentence, as regards the frequency of は ocurrence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;There may be multiple は in any given sentence⟯

<div class='c1-f'> Is this legal, and why? </div><br/>私は昨日は昼食は取らなかったんです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;は as contrast marker⟯

　美化語（びかご） is adding the honorific prefixes (ご、お、。。。）to words in what situation? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a non-尊敬語・謙譲語 situation⟯
　美化語（びかご） is doing what in a non-尊敬語・謙譲語 situation? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;adding the honorific prefixes (ご、お、。。。）to words⟯
Apparently, using the term 先生 for yourself is considered what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;immodest⟯
Apparently, using the term 先生 for whom is considered immodest? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;yourself⟯
Besides as a name-suffix for ⟮c1;teachers⟯, 先生 is also used as a suffix for ⟮c2;doctors⟯, ⟮c3;lawyers⟯, and some other professionals
Besides in school, 先輩・後輩 are used for what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;senority in other organizations, e.g. companies⟯
<div class="cloze-group-children hide-if-inactive-children"><p>If <code>an <span class="c3-cloze">object belongs to someone</span> who <span class="c4-cloze">you are 尊敬語</span></code> or <span class="c5-cloze"><code>you are using 美化語</code>,</span>&nbsp;you <span class="c2-cloze">add 御 as a prefix</span>.</p> <p>in <span class="c6-cloze">some words</span>, <span class="c7-cloze">御</span> has become  <span class="c1-cloze">lexicalized (and thus unremovable)</span>.</p> <p>In situations where <span class="c8-cloze">other words would</span> get 御 prefixed, <span class="c9-cloze">外来語 only sometimes do</span>. </p> <div>the <span class="c10-cloze">御 prefix</span> can be read:   <table>   <thead>     <tr>       <th>Reading</th>       <th>Context</th>       <th>Conditions</th>     </tr>   </thead>   <tbody class="cloze-group-children hide-if-inactive-children">     <tr>       <td><span class="c11-cloze">お</span></td>       <td><span class="c12-cloze">in front of 和語 (native japanese words)</span></td>       <td><span class="group-before-hide">(generally) <span class="c19-cloze">not used</span> if <span class="c20-cloze">the words starts with お</span>, or <span class="c21-cloze">if it is long</span></span></td>     </tr>     <tr>       <td><span class="c13-cloze">おん</span></td>       <td><span class="c14-cloze">in front of 和語 (native japanese words)</span></td>       <td>if <span class="c22-cloze">the word is more honorific than w/　お</span> (generally <span class="c23-cloze">rare</span>)</td>     </tr>         <tr>       <td><span class="c15-cloze">ご</span></td>       <td><span class="c16-cloze">in front of 漢語 (sino-japanese words)</span></td>     </tr>         <tr>       <td><span class="c17-cloze">み</span></td>       <td><span class="c18-cloze">Religious/grand importance (I think only in front of 和語, but not sure)</span></td>        <td><span class="group-before-hide"><span class="c24-cloze">more fancy versions</span> include <span class="c25-cloze">おみ</span> and <span class="c26-cloze">おんみ</span></span></td>     </tr>   </tbody> </table></div> </div> <span class="cloze-dump">⟮c1;⟯⟮c2;⟯⟮c3;⟯⟮c4;⟯⟮c5;⟯⟮c6;⟯⟮c7;⟯⟮c8;⟯⟮c9;⟯{{c10::}}{{c11::}}{{c12::}}{{c13::}}{{c14::}}{{c15::}}{{c16::}}{{c17::}}{{c18::}}{{c19::}}{{c20::}}{{c21::}}{{c22::}}{{c23::}}{{c24::}}{{c25::}}{{c26::}}</span>

Most 和製漢語 refer to what kind of concepts? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Concepts pertaining to the modern era / imported from the west⟯

⟮c1;(日本の)　伝統芸能（でんとうげいのう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Japanese traditional performing arts&nbsp; is a general term for the arts and skills that have existed in Japan since ancient times. It refers to the tangible and intangible arts and crafts that have been passed down or discontinued in a particular form, either as an incidental part of the culture, entertainment, rituals, or festivals of a particular class or mass of people, or as a systematic part of an event. It includes poetry, music, dance, painting, crafts, and geido.&nbsp;⟯

((h:2;::<img src="sm_Eu8R8pEVcAAlPaW.jpg">))⟮c1;　序（つい）で⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;occasion, opportunity⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> Noun (!) </div> </div>
