Besides indicating the ⟮c2;progressive⟯ aspect, ている can also indicate the ⟮c1;habitual⟯ and the ⟮c3;stative⟯ aspect
ている・てある are fundamentally concerned with what linguistic feature? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;aspect⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What aspect is ている indicating here? </div><br/>教師をしています <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stative⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What aspect is ている indicating here? </div><br/>A学校に行っています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;habitual⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > not stative, as you are not always going to school </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What aspect is ている indicating here? </div><br/> 古着を着ています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stative⟯
For motion verbs, what aspect does ている always indicate, if not habitual? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stative⟯
For motion verbs, what kind of stative is the stative that ている indicates? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the one after the motion has been completed⟯
For motion verbs, the state after the motion has been completed is indicated how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ている⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/> 彼はもう帰っている <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;He's already gone home.⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > ている + motion verb stative </div> </div>
how do you combine the aspectual functions of ている with the 'without' meaning of ないで? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ないでいる⟯
ないでいる is a combination of which two forms? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ないで＝Without,　ている = aspectual functions⟯
how do you express without -ing (or without + stative/habitual)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ないでいる⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > contains a d sound </div> </div>
How is the ず form used, grammatically (in relation to the sentence)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;as an AdvP⟯
One kana AdvP -making without form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Xず⟯
A more formal variant of ず is? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ずに⟯
ずに relates how to ず? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;more formal (according to imabi)⟯
how do we merge ている and ず(に)？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ず（に）いる⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > yes, this is correct, the て form is dropped, cf. https://www.imabi.net/teiru.htm </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Read how? </div><br/>NG <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;エヌジー⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Means what? </div><br/>NG <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;no good; not allowed; not acceptable, outtake⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Gloss? </div><br/>決して病気にならないでいることは不可能だ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;      It is impossible to never get sick.   ⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > without-form + ている aspectual (here stative) </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > literally: certainly sick become without STAT NOM TOP impossible COP </div> </div>
In some dialects, what is used instead of ている？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ておる (yes, even in non-formal speech)⟯
In some dialects,&nbsp;<span style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">ておる is used instead of</span>&nbsp;ている even in which situations？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;even in normal (non-formal) situations⟯
The dialectal とる、ちょる for ている are derived from which form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ておる (as a replacement for ている)⟯
Dialectal forms of て(い)る are ⟮c1;とる⟯、⟮c2;ちょろ⟯
てある indicates what aspect (only)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stative⟯
te + what indicates stative (always)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;てある⟯
What specific, common verb cannot use てある？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;来る⟯
The state resulting from てある has to be what, now? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;currently true⟯
Who must have caused the てある state? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;&nbsp;a voluntary actor⟯
How was the てある state caused (related to the agent that caused it)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;purposefully⟯
What class of verbs can the てある state <b>only</b>&nbsp;be used with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;transitive verbs⟯
&nbsp;てある can&nbsp;<b>only</b>&nbsp;be used with transitive verbs, but what is up with the particles? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;を cannot be used⟯
窓が⟮c1;開け⟯てあります。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">てある needs transitive verbs</div> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b">  The window is open (and this was caused by someone). </div> </div>
アンケートは集めて⟮c1;ある⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     The questionnaires have been gathered. (and are now gathered, by a human) </div> </div>
ストーブ⟮c1;が⟯つけ<b>てあります。</b><br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The heater was turned on (by someone) and has been kept that way. </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What must be true about how the tree ended up on the ground? </div><br/>木が倒してある。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;by voluntary action⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What must be true about the tree and the ground? </div><br/>木が倒してある。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;it must still be there⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why the dinner&nbsp; marked with が？ </div><br/>晩ご飯が作ってある。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because てある doesn't accept を, and thus always uses が⟯
The functioning of てある is kind of similar to which form/voice? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;passive form voice⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_1200px-LocationEurasia.jpg">))⟮c1;ユーラシア⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;eurasia⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> rarely also ユーラジア </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_fa76f8fc.jpg">))⟮c1;　国名（こくめい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;name of a country⟯
Besides かたかな spellings, what do foreign countries also have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a kanji (almost always 当て字) spelling⟯
Which spelling is most often used for foregin country names, languages? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;カタカナ<br>⟯
⟮c1;アジア⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Asia⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_300px-Continental_models.gif">))⟮c1;　大（たい）　陸（りく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;continent, continental asia, esp. china (you can imagine how that specialization happened)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2nd kanji starts r </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_b01dbaf3aff31a5be5c424d050e63964_w.jpeg">))⟮c1;　大州（たいしゅう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;continent (including surrounding islands)⟯
What happens sometimes, although rarely, when listing with と？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;there also is a と after the last item⟯
Having a と after the last item in a と list is how common/allowed? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;uncommon but fine⟯
と as 'and' can be only used with what words/phrases? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;nouns/NPs⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is this で and not と, given it seems to be connecting two nouns? </div><br/>私は日本人で医者です。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because it actually isn't, it's connecting two predicate phrases, since it really is short for "I am japanese and I am a doctor"⟯
これ⟮c1;と⟯それは同じです。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     This and that are the same.   </div> </div>
What could be here?<br>日本語のクラスにはアメリカ人と、イギリス人と、カナダ人⟮c1;と/Ø⟯がいます。<br><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b">     There are Americans, English, and Canadians in (my) Japanese class.  </div> </div>
と can mean what, e.g. 彼氏と一緒に宿題をした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;with⟯
父と母⟮c1;と⟯公園に行きます。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　　　 I'm going to the park with my father and mother.  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> what does the と gloss as here? </div><br/>友達と散歩に出かけた。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;with⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_1016347.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_product_1032792.jpg">))⟮c1;　共（とも）に⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;together; with​⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> often collocation with と (as Xと共に) </div><div class="sub all-b"> similar to 一緒に </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div><div class="sub c1-f" > starts t </div> </div>
共に and 一緒に often take what to specify with whom they are doing the action? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;と⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
⟮c1;x　共（とも）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;both, all (suffix, can be added to other words)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> e.g. 二人共 </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kanji of 2 kana </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/> 彼女と時々けんかする。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;      I sometimes argue with her. ⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
車⟮c1;と⟯ぶつかった。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I collided with a car. </div> </div>
If something is being compared, what is one of the comparands often marked with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;と⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
What does と used for comparison sometimes gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;as⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> trans? </div><br/> 彼と同じ考えです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;      That is the same idea as his. <br><br>⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is the と here doing? </div><br/>その子はお父さんと似ている。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;comparing ('as')⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
Besides と, how is the thing being compared with 似ている also often marked? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;に⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_202002270115_top_img_A.jpg">))⟮c1;みぞれ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;sleet⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_caption.jpg">))⟮c1;　小雨（こさめ, more rarely しょうう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;light rain, drizzle⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_11531863.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-8668cadaee8774bed64824482a1a359c2ab33f58.jpg">))⟮c1;　大（おお）　雨（あめ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;downpour, heavy rain⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
in contrast to になる, となる indicate a change that is what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;discrete (in one thing)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
A sudden change to something uses what particle? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;と<br>⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
と cannot be used for what changes? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;changes from a continuous process⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
と for change often sounds what, as regards tone/formality? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stiff/formal⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it 'と' here? </div><br/>いよいよ運動会の日となりました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;sudden/discrete change⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp; </div> </div>
小雨⟮c1;となった⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > &nbsp;It became a drizzle (suddenly). </div> </div>
Why do many intransitive verbs end in -aru? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because they evolved from old japanese verbs via the 未然形&nbsp;⟯
if they evolved from old japanese verbs via the 未然形 (and many did) <b>intransitive</b> verbs... <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;end -aru⟯
because they evolved from old japanese verbs via the izenkei(no longer exists), many transitive verbs... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;end -eru⟯
&nbsp;many transitive verbs end -eru because? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because they evolved from old japanese verbs via the izenkei(已然形, no longer exists),⟯
 みぞれが雪⟮c1;と⟯なりました。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       The sleet turned to snow. (all of a sudden) </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_AdobeStock_191708038-1024x745.jpg">))⟮c1;　多勢（たぜい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;great numbers, numerical superiority⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_745295d6b804638cfb71a26f9be01d21_400.jpg">))⟮c1;　無勢（ぶ/むぜい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;numerical inferiority; being outnumbered⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it に? </div><br/>　多勢（たぜい）に　無勢（ぶぜい） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;に for deep connection&nbsp;⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this pattern gloss as? </div><br/>AをBにする <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;to make/have A be a B way (into a B)⟯
to make/have A be a B way: ⟮c1;Aを⟯⟮c2;B(に/と)⟯⟮c3;する⟯
for the to make/have A be a B way pattern, what can you use, instead of に? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;と⟯
for the to make/have A be a B way pattern, using と instead of に emphasizes what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the substance of the result⟯
⟮c1;いよいよ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;more and more; increasingly, finally, indeed⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > starts i </div> </div>
殺害事件⟮c1;を⟯小説⟮c1;に⟯する。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     To make the murder case into a novel.  </div> </div>
What can adverbial+する&nbsp; mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;just to make something something, like you'd expect⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > にする can also mean to choose, but that's not what I mean </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>彼は彼女を幸せにした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;     He made her happy. ⟯
the pattern AをBにする is actually what, if B is a 形容詞? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;AをB(adverbial)する⟯
the pattern AをBに/adverbialする also works in what reduced state? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;leaving out the Aを⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>ボリュームを高くする。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;to turn up the volume⟯
In general, with what is the に to tell time not used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;time words such as 去年, 今日、明日 etc.⟯
学校は毎朝８時１５分⟮c1;に⟯始まります。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > not nothing </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　　　School begins every morning at 8:15.  </div> </div>
に can also sometimes do what, when placed between two things (probably NPs)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;act as 'and' (similar to と)⟯
When acting as and, what nuance does に carry (according to IMABI)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;of a deep connection⟯
Instead of と 'and' especially to indicate a deep connection, what is sometimes also used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;に⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kana </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is に being used here? </div><br/>新郎に新婦 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;に for and with deep connection⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>待ちに待った <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;waited and waited, long/eagerly awaited⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>赤ちゃんは泣きに泣いた。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;The baby cried and cried⟯
the stem に verb pattern (e.g. 待ちに待つ) has what tone? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;somewhat literary⟯ Very / strongly verbing: ⟮c1;Verb stem⟯ + ⟮c2;に⟯ + ⟮c3;same verb⟯ Verb stem + に + same verb creates what meaning? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;that the verb is being done to a large/strong extent⟯
（こ・そ・あ）ちら can be used as a politer version of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;（こ・そ・あ）れ⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > contains an e-sound </div> </div>
（こ・そ・あ）ちら can relate how to （こ・そ・あ）れ? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;politer version⟯
Politer version of こ・そ・あ）れ is? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;（こ・そ・あ）ちら⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it こちら here? </div><br/>こちらは新製品でございます。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;politer version of これ⟯
⟮c1;polite::そちら⟯はお買い得ですよ<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > That is a good bargain.  </div> </div>
（こ・そ・あ）ちら can be used as a politer version of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;（こ・そ・あそ）こ⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > contains an o-sound </div> </div>
（こ・そ・あ）ちら can relate how to （こ・そ・あ）こ? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;politer version⟯
Politer version of こ・そ・あ　れ is? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;（こ・そ・あ）ちら⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it こちら here? </div><br/>こちらは昨日、酷い雨でした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;more polite version of ここ⟯

こちら can be used as an indirect way to refer to whom? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;oneself (first person)⟯
こちら can be a personal pronoun for which two grammatical persons? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;first person and third person⟯
こちら can be used to refer to oneself (1st person) with what feeling? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;indirectly⟯

こちら⟮c1;様⟯にお水を差し上げてください。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Very high status </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it そちら here? </div><br/>そちらはもう寒くなりましたか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;more polite version of そこ⟯
そちら can be a personal pronoun for which grammatical person? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;second person⟯
そちら is used to refer to others (2nd person) with what formality/status? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;polite/formal⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Which function is&nbsp; そちら assuming here? </div><br/>そちらのご意見を聞かせてください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;2p polite reference⟯
The っち contractions of こそあ ちら have what kind of formality? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;they are casual⟯
あちら can be a personal pronoun for which grammatical person? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;third person⟯
あちら is used to refer to others (3rd person) with what formality/status? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;formal, polite⟯
あちら is used to refer to others (3rd person) formally/politely, but is different from こちら how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;あちら is distal⟯
<div class='c1-f'> In japanese? </div><br/>That's my line <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;それはこっちのセリフだ⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > or variants </div> </div>

こちら、そちら etc are abbreviated how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;こっち、そっち etc⟯
 そちら⟮c1;様⟯のお  電話番号をいただけますか。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > much status above wow </div> </div>
⟮c1;　疑問詞（ぎもんし）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;interrogative (word)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> like なぜ、どこ、なになど </div> </div>
Where (as relates to medium) is の reduced to ん？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;in spoken speech⟯
In general, where can question words appear in the sentence in japanese (provided the sentence supports it)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;pretty much anywhere⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > Isn't this probably only true for adverb-like question words, </div> </div>
Generally, what construct do&nbsp;question words colligate with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;(explanatory) の・ん...⟯
Seemingly using a conceptual metaphor of space, what can you sometimes use instead of なに？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;どこ⟯
日本の⟮c1;どこ⟯が好きですか。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > starts d </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What about japan do you like? </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> used like which word class？ </div><br/>いつ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;adverb⟯
<div class='c1-f'> used like which word class？ </div><br/>なぜ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;adverb⟯
<div class='c1-f'> used like which word class？ </div><br/>なに、どこ、だれ。。。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;nouns⟯
⟮c1;Xいつになる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;When will X happen? / when x will happen⟯

(っ)つ(う)か、(っ)てか are short versions of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;というか⟯

てゆうか is a version of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;というか⟯

⟮c1;　節（せつ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;clause⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> linguistics terminology </div> </div>

((h:2;::<img src="sm_aaf678198feef60a56d95171609c7a9a.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_DqiunN3XcAES5JW.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_1-c869caf0570af3d8d222d48bb29fa078b470e735.jpg">))⟮c1;　巨大（きょだい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;huge; gigantic; enormous⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is の doing here? </div><br/>きのう山を登ったのは、健太君でした。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;の as nominalizer⟯
A verb phrase placed in front of a NP to modify it is what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a relative clause⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > specifically japanese definition </div> </div>
A verb phrase placed in front of what to modify it is a relative clause?a <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a NP⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > japanese-specific definition </div> </div>
Since 形容詞 contain the copula within themselves, when in front of NPs what might one say they are equivalent to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;relative clauses⟯
Why might we say 形容詞 are equivalent to relative clauses when in front of NPs? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Since 形容詞 contain the copula within themselves⟯
besides as adjectives (predicative adjectives, etc), 形容詞 are sometimes analyzed as ⟮c1;intransitive⟯ ⟮c2;stative⟯ ⟮c3;verbs⟯.
What does japanese fairly frequently use where english might use an adjective? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a relative clause⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > (contains more words) </div> </div>
In general, what particle does not appear in a relative question (the ones marked with か)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;は⟯
In general, if は appears in a embedded/relative question, that is a clue that... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;you are not actually in the embedded clause, and if you are, it’s not being used to mark the topic.⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is どれがおいしいかまずいか here? </div><br/>どれがおいしいかまずいかさっぱりわかりません。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a relative/embedded question⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>この生物は何か教えてください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Please tell me what creature this is. ⟯
どの宿題が難しかった⟮c1;か⟯教えてください。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Please tell me which homework was difficult.  </div> </div>
かどうか glosses as what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;whether or not⟯
How do you mark a relative/embedded question? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;with か⟯
What does XかYか gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;(whether) X or Y⟯
whether X or Y is the case is something we might express how in japanese? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ｘかｙか⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What would adding a どうか to the か change the translation into? </div><br/>お風呂が十分に熱いか確かめてください。= Please check if the bath is hot enough.   <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Please check whether or not the bath is hot enough. ⟯
彼女が虫が嫌い⟮c1;かどうか⟯わかりません。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I don't know whether or not she hates bugs.&nbsp; </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>夫が本当に幸せかどうか分かりません。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I really don’t know whether or not my husband is really happy. ⟯
If after a relative/embedded question there is a quantifier, what does the quantifier refer to? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the relative/embedded question⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is the 大体 referring to? </div><br/> 山口さんは誰が歌ったか<b>大体</b>知っているでしょう。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the relative/embedded question in front of it⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since 大体 is a quantifier </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is the 全部 referring to? </div><br/>私は何が届いたか<b>全部</b>知っています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the relative/embedded question in front of it⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since 全部 is a quantifier </div> </div>
In general, like what phrase/word class do embedded/relative questions work? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;like nouns/noun phrases⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does the を here prove? </div><br/>警察は誰が犯行現場にいたかを調べています。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;that rel/emb questions act a lot like like nouns/noun phrases⟯
古いかどうか⟮c1;を⟯調べる方法 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Method of investigating whether or not it’s old  </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not necessary, but possible </div> </div>
爆発するか⟮c1;が⟯知りたいです。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I want to know if it will explode. </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not necessary but possible </div> </div>
In general, in embedded/relative questions, what can you put before the か? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;similar particles as in actual questions⟯
By extension from 'somehow or other', what does どうか also mean? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;please⟯
Please <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;どうか⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > starts w d </div> </div>
things like の・ん、だ、の・んだ add what to embedded/relative questions? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;more uncertainty/weight⟯
According to IMABI, in ⟮c1;embedded/relative questions⟯, in order of uncertainty: ⟮c2;ん・のだか⟯＞⟮c3;だか⟯＞⟮c4;ん・のか⟯＞⟮c5;か⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>この辺は何だか静かですね。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;This area is rather/kinda quiet, isn't it?  ⟯
⟮c1; 何だか⟯眠い。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'm kinda/sorta/somehow sleepy. </div> </div>
...か...か (or derivatives like ...のか...のか) can be used how, besides a whether x or y? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;just as a general list of options⟯
When ...か...か (but not derivatives) are being used to list options, what can happen to the final か？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;it can be left out⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it か here? </div><br/>水かミルクを飲んでください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;か pattern for listing options⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is it か here? </div><br/> すしか刺し身を注文してください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;か pattern for listing options⟯
 すし⟮c1;か⟯刺し身を注文してください。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Order either sushi or sashimi.  </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 1 kana </div> </div>
公園に行くか、デパートに行く⟮c1;か or nothing⟯ですね。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Either go to the park or go to the department store, right?  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What is the　んだか pattern being used here for? </div><br/>もう誰が死ぬんだか、みんな死ぬんだかわからない。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;&nbsp;listing options⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why is there no final か here? </div><br/>水かミルクを飲んでください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;'cause it can be left out⟯
In a way, how can the relationship between な (if it's not being used to disambiguate の・ん) and である (or similar copula) be seen?&nbsp; <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;な being a form of である/ the copula⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not the particle </div> </div>
How might we say <q>from x to y</q>? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;XからYまで⟯
What might から gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;from⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > when as a 'postposition' </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> If we said this marked a case, which case would that be? </div><div class='c1-f'> If we said this was marked by a particle, which particle would that be? </div><br/>⟮c1;から⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Ablative case⟯
<div class='c2-f'> If we said this marked a case, which case would that be? </div><div class='c1-f'> If we said this was marked by a particle, which particle would that be? </div><br/>⟮c1;へ・に⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;lative case⟯
When recieving, から can be used for what, に for what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;から for anything, に for people only⟯
When recieving, what particle can be used for anything, and what for people only? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;から for anything, に for people only⟯
 When から is used to show the place of transit or departure, it may be replaced by what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;を :: 1 kana⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>子犬から育てたよ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　　 I raised it from (since it was) a puppy. ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>これらのコンピューターは各種５万円からです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　　 These computers start at 50,000 yen.<br><br>⟯
What tense can you not use まで with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;past tense⟯
 僕は9歳⟮c1;まで⟯ローマで育ちました。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     I was raised in Rome until I was nine.   </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>いつまでここにいるのか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;    Until when are you going to be here?  ⟯
What does まで gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;    to/until/till&nbsp;&nbsp;⟯
までに is generally used with what semantic field? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;    time⟯
<div class='c1-f'> generally uses what construction? </div><br/>By the time... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;までに ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>零時までに三冊読む。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;      To read three books by midnight.  ⟯
 日が出る⟮c1;まで⟯寝る。 <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     To sleep until the sun rises. <br><br> </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> Roughly translated? </div><div class='c1-f'> Roughly translated? </div><br/>⟮c1;一時までに⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;by one o clock⟯
<div class='c2-f'> Roughly translated? </div><div class='c1-f'> Roughly translated? </div><br/>⟮c1;死ぬまでに⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;before one dies⟯

すこしく is rare, but the (only) adverbial of what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;少し⟯

Between よい＆いい, which is more polite? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;よい⟯

⟮c1;9月中旬⟯に出張することになりました。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I am to go on a business trip in mid-September.  </div> </div>
クリスマスは⟮c1;12月25日⟯ですね。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Christmas is on December 25th, right? </div> </div>
僕の誕生日は⟮c1;11月16日⟯です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > My birthday is on November 16th.  </div> </div>
In general, if you're specifying datetimes, what is the order, left-to-right? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;more general to more specific⟯
In general, if you're specifying datetimes, how are the different elements (that is, the date parts and time parts) connected? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;just plainly listed after each other⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What kind of thing are we specifying here, specifically? </div><br/>　１月（いちがつ） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;month (of the year)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What kind of thing are we specifying here, specifically? </div><br/>一ヶ月 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;month (duration)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>3ヶ月（間）友達に会っていなかった。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I hadn’t met my friends in three months. ⟯
When read with native numbers for 1-4, what does number+　月（つき） express? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a duration (not a specific month, as it normally would be, lacking ヶ月)⟯
When read with what kind of numbers for 1-4, number+　月（つき） expresses a duration? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;native⟯
When read with what native numbers for which numbers, number+　月（つき） expresses a duration? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;1-4⟯
When read with what native numbers for 1-4, number+what expresses a duration of months`? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　月（つき）⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Why does this gloss as <q>It’s 3,000 yen a month!</q> and not e.g. <q>In january, it's three thousand yen</q>? </div><br/> 一　月（つき）3000円です！ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;native number つき pattern⟯
日付は⟮c1;2017年4月22日⟯です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The date is April 22nd, 2017.  </div> </div>
What does ヶ年 gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;over ... years⟯
In what contexts is ヶ年 used, most often? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;legal/business⟯
What number is generally not used with ヶ年? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;一⟯
⟮c1;5ヶ年⟯計画を実施しました。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > We implemented a five-year plan.  </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > notice the businessness </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> what does this gloss as? </div><br/>10ヶ年の戦略を実現しました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;We actualized a 10-year strategy. ⟯
In what grade... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;何年生⟯
The 12 years of school in japan are divided into ⟮c1;６⟯ of 小学校、⟮c1;３⟯ of 中学校、⟮c1;３⟯ of 高校
彼女は今ハーバード大学の⟮c1;4年生⟯です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > She is now a senior at Harvard.  </div> </div>
How do you count academic years? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　学年（がくねん）⟯
⟮c1;1学年⟯で何漢字くらいを習うのは普通ですか？<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > <br>How many kanji do you usually learn in one school year? (self-written sentence, might not be perfect) </div> </div>
昨夜は久しぶりに⟮c1;8時間⟯寝ました！<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Last night, I slept eight hours for the first time in a while!  </div> </div>
⟮c1;14時⟯に起こしてください。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Wake me up at 14:00. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > じゅうよじ </div> </div>
今、⟮c1;何時⟯ですか。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What time is it now?  </div> </div>
⟮c1;何時⟯に開店しますか。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > At what time do you open?  </div> </div>
⟮c1;20分（間）⟯待ちました。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I waited for twenty minutes.  </div> </div>
試合は明日の⟮c1;朝/午前10時45分⟯です。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > The game is tomorrow morning at 10:45. </div> </div>
what can you use as an alternative to 午前　when specifying that a time is in the morning <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;朝⟯
When specifying a time is at a certain point in the day (morning, night, etc.), where does that go, relative to the time? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;in front of it⟯
If present, what is the first thing specified in a <b>time</b> specifier? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the time of day,&nbsp; 例えば午後や夜など⟯
Where do specifiers such as 半 go, relative to the time in question? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;after it⟯
一分でも⟮c1;一秒⟯でもいいから。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I don’t care if it’s just for a minute or even a second.  </div> </div>
What kind of nights does 晩 count when it counts nights? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;nights as in stays⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > not sure if true </div> </div>
When counting nights, up until how many nights is 晩 usually used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;2-3 nights⟯
⟮c1;　三日三晩（みっかみばん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;three days and three nights (idiomatic)⟯
穴の底で⟮c1;5夜⟯過ごした<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I spent five nights at the bottom of a hole. </div> </div>
⟮c1;　昨（さく）朝・晩・夜⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Last morning/evening/night⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > (uses 音読み: ちょう、ばん、や） </div> </div>
⟮c1;　明（みょう）　朝（ちょう）・　晩（ばん）・　夜（や）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;next/tomorrow morning/evening/night⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > uses 音読み </div> </div>
⟮c1;　一昨（いっさく）x⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;2 ｘ ago⟯
⟮c1;　一昨昨（いっさくさく）x⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;3 x ago⟯
⟮c1;この　前（まえ）の⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;last...⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > &nbsp;kanji+kana expression </div> </div>
⟮c1;この　次（つぎ）の⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;next...⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > 1 kanji+ 3 kana expression </div> </div>
Grammatically, ので is probably derived from what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;のだ⟯
Since ので is probably derived from のだ, what should theoretically be forbidden to be use in front of it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;polite forms, forms of the copula⟯
Despite ので being derived from のだ (prob), in general, what can you still use in front of it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;polite forms (including です)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > no, you can't use だので </div> </div>
Because ので is prob derived from のだ (prob), what can you not use in front of it, unless you're speaking dialect? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;だ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What was this before being slurred? </div><br/>んで <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ので⟯
Because it is weaker, what kind of verb forms can you not use ので with? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;any kind of imperative (or similar)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> How is ので funcitoning here? </div><br/>すまない、もう先約があるんで。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;basically adding explanatory tone just as のだ or similar might⟯
犬⟮c1;な⟯のだ<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >  It's a dog. (explanatory tone) </div> </div>
静か⟮c1;な⟯ので僕がなにか言いたかった<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > It's been quiet, so I wanted to say something. </div> </div>
In general, how correct is だのに? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;dialectal⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>新しいのに <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;even though its new⟯
 犬⟮c1;な⟯のに        <br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > Even though he's a dog. </div> </div>
 彼はとても年を取っている⟮c1;のに⟯元気ですよ。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >     Although/even though he's very old, he's healthy!  </div> </div>
食べないの? せっかく作った⟮c1;のに⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kana </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > You're not going to eat it? Even though I went through all the trouble of making it?<br><br> </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> What does this generally translate as? </div><div class='c1-f'> How might we say this in japanese? (4 kana) </div><br/>⟮c1;...いいのに⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;I wish that... (or should...)⟯
いいのに as in "I wish/if only" is often preceded by what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the conditional (たら・ば)⟯
conditional(たら・ば) + いいのに generally implies what about the thing in the conditional? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;that it isn't the case⟯
conditional(たら・ば) + いいのに can be translated as <q>⟮c1;I wish⟯</q>, <q>⟮c2;if only⟯</q>, <q>⟮c3;you should⟯</q>, <q>⟮c4;why don't you⟯</q> (and similar, of course)
In general, if you use のに, the outcome is how, value-/desirability-wise? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;negative (althought not always)⟯
In general, if you use のに without a second clause, what is said to be regrettable? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;reality⟯
The conditional + いいのに pattern is actually just a slight specialization of which pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;conditional + いい⟯
In the conditional + いい pattern, what may the いい be replaced with, esp. if at the end of the sentence? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;なあ・ねえ⟯
What does the conditional + いい generally gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I wish...,&nbsp; should...⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>すみません、どこで 降りればいいですか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Excuse me, where should I get off?⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>どのボタンを押せばいいかわからなかった。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I didn't know which button to push.⟯
besides should or I wish, what does conditional + いい&nbsp; also sometimes gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;may (as in you may take off your shoes)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Roughly translates as what </div><br/>X癖に (Most often spelled in kana as くせに)</span> <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Even though X⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Is similar to what? </div><br/>X癖に (Most often spelled in kana as くせに) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Xのに⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Is different to のに how? </div><br/>X癖に (Most often spelled in kana as くせに) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;X is implied to be way more negative⟯
男⟮c1;の⟯くせに<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >  Even though you’re a man…  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss&nbsp; as? </div><br/>女のくせに <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;even though you’re a woman⟯
何だ、自分がミスした⟮c1;くせに⟯･･･<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What? Even though you yourself have messed up…  </div> </div>
あんた、戦争の経験もない⟮c1;くせに⟯べらべらしゃべてるなんて<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > k... </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > You've never been in a war before, and yet you talk and talk and talk. </div> </div>
<div class='c2-f'> More extreme alternative of? </div><div class='c1-f'> More extreme alternative? </div><br/>⟮c1;くせして  ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;くせに⟯
あの山の小さ⟮c1;な/い⟯町に住んでいます。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I live in the small town on that mountain.  </div> </div>
<div class='c1-f'> Why couldn't it be な here? </div><br/>耳が小さい猫がいるんだ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;predicative -&gt; 連体詞 impossible⟯
between 小さいと小さな (and 大きい・大きな), which can you use for money? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;-い⟯
between 小さいと小さな (and 大きい・大きな), which can you use for age? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;-い⟯
&nbsp;小さい and 大きい are variants which you can use for which semantic fields, but which you can't use their な cousins for? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;money, age⟯
in the adnominal position おかし⟮c1;い⟯ is generally used for something ⟮c2;funny⟯, and おかし⟮c1;な⟯ is generally used for something ⟮c2;suspicious/weird⟯
in the adnominal position 新⟮c1;たな⟯ is generally used for something ⟮c2;subjective/cool⟯; 新⟮c1;しい⟯ is generally used for something ⟮c2;objective⟯
in the adnominal position&nbsp;&nbsp;柔らか⟮c1;な⟯ is can be used for something ⟮c2;figuratively soft⟯, while 柔らか⟮c1;い⟯ is generally only used for something ⟮c2;that is literally soft⟯
In general, where are compounds using 前 read ぜん mostly used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;in the written language⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > true for most 音読み compounds </div> </div>
In general, how is 前 mostly used in the spoken language? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;standalone and read まえ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>食べる前に、手を洗います。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;I wash my hands before I eat. ⟯
彼は3年⟮c1;前に⟯死んだ。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > He died three years ago. </div> </div>
In general, as what part of speech is 　前（まえ） used? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;noun/の-adj⟯
most of the time, what is 前 followed by? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;に⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_348675.jpg">))⟮c1;　帰京（ききょう） (often used as a する verb)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;returning to (one's home in) Tokyo⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_maxresdefault-d2e324eaa920dce47ce0d5aba1a4cef3b84a2d00.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_im-272848.jpg">))⟮c1;　直前（ちょくぜん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;directly in front, directly ahead, just before⟯
車の⟮c1;直前⟯に人が突然飛び出してきた。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > A person suddenly jumped out right in front of the car. </div> </div>
爆発直前⟮c1;に⟯ガソリンが気化したような臭いがしていた。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > There was a smell of gasoline vaporizing right before the explosion.  </div> </div>
　後（あと）, has a ⟮c1;spatial sense ('behind')⟯, a ⟮c2;temperoral sense ('after')⟯, a sense of ⟮c3;the remainder⟯, ⟮c4;the aftermath⟯, and something like ⟮c5;'what's more'⟯.
⟮c1;後⟯は任せて。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I'll take care of the rest. </div> </div>
跡 is read as あと when it refers to what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;traces/tracks/marks/signs/remains⟯
&nbsp;あと is written how when it refers to traces/tracks/marks/signs/remains <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;跡⟯
when it refers to traces/tracks/marks/signs/remains, how is 跡 read? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;あと⟯
痕 is read as あと when it refers to what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a scar⟯
&nbsp;あと is written how when it refers to a scar <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;痕 or 跡⟯
when it refers to a scar, how is 痕 read? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;あと⟯
((h:2;::<img src="sm_s292082007a.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_8a7b4c9ef3af5bab399c2c67f17cd6a2-728x527.jpg">))⟮c1;　傷（きず）　跡/痕（あと）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;scar&nbsp;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > 2 kanji </div> </div>
後ろAnd後 both can refer to after, but only 後ろ can refer to... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the rear part of something⟯
車の⟮c1;後ろ⟯にくまがいます<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > There's a bear in the back of the car. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > not 後 because the back part is 後ろ only </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_379381.jpg">))⟮c1;クモ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;spider⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > kanji are 蜘蛛 </div> </div>
((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-007df44e6238de09cea3a7f4053eb66e9a327cea.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_e4f4bc9571536f20f2baa6824ac140f2.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_jellyfish_JFIUIpc.jpg">))⟮c1;くらげ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;jellyfish⟯
if you're using VP + 後, what must the tense be? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;past tense⟯
大変⟮c1;だった⟯後は、良いことがあるのかな<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > copula </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >   　I wonder if there can be anything good after things being so terrible.    </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > must be past tense because of 後 </div> </div>
Besides general sentence function&nbsp; particles, 後 seems to mainly occur with ⟮c1;に⟯・⟮c2;で⟯・⟮c3;から⟯ or alternatively with ⟮c4;no particle⟯
In contrast to あと, which nuance(s) does のち only have? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;only the temporal nuance⟯
What does verbてから gloss as? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;after doing...⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>別れてから会っていない <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　　 I haven't met her since we split up. ⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is てから indicating here? </div><br/>よく考えてから答えます。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;doing something after doing something else&nbsp;⟯
日本に来⟮c1;てから⟯もう10年になります。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > 　　 It has already been ten years since I came to Japan.  </div> </div>
as readings of 後, when standalone, ⟮c1;のち⟯ and ⟮c2;ご⟯ are used ⟮c3;pretty similarly⟯ (in relation to each other).
お⟮c1;後⟯は何にしますか。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > a... </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > What will you be having next/after?  </div> </div>
僕は、ペルシャ軍の⟮c1;後⟯を追いかけた。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I chased after the Persian army.   </div> </div>
In general, what do we use when we want to indicate the time when something happens? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　時（とき）⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > e.g. When others are talking, when beginning an examination, when running etc. </div> </div>
The tenses in the structure something時something decide what, besides the event's relation to the present? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the events (temporal) relation to each other⟯
The tenses in the structure something時something decide what, besides the events temporal relation to each other? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the events temporal relation to the present⟯
What governs the tense when the time of the clause before 時 becomes irrelevant for whatever reason? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the final verb⟯
&nbsp;when the time of the clause before 時 becomes irrelevant for whatever reason, what does the final verb do? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;govern the tense fo the clause⟯
According to IMABI, when you use a 時 construction, if ⟮c2;both events⟯ are seen to be ⟮c1;instantaneous⟯ and be happening ⟮c3;at the same time⟯, or when the event is ⟮c4;reoccurring/habitual⟯, the ⟮c5;tense before 時⟯ becomes irrelevant.
If the second clause in clause時clause is ている, it happens when? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;while the first clause is happening⟯
<div class='c1-f'> When are you buying the radio? </div><br/>私は日本に行くとき、ラジオを買います。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;in the future, right when you are going to japan⟯
<div class='c1-f'> When are you buying the radio? </div><br/>私は日本に行くとき、ラジオを買いました <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;in the past, right when you are going to japan⟯
<div class='c1-f'> When are you buying the radio? </div><br/>私は日本に行ったとき日本製のテレビを買う <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;after you will have gone to japan⟯
<div class='c1-f'> When are you buying the radio? </div><br/>私は日本に行ったときテレビを買いました。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;after you will have gone to japan⟯
When using clause1時clause2, the verb in clause 2 (v2) determines what (which v1 does not)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the time in relation to the present⟯
When using clause1時clause2, the time in relation to the present is determined by what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the verb in clause 2⟯
When using clause1時clause2, if c1 is present, and c2 is past, which happend first? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;c2⟯
When using clause1時clause2, if c1 is past, and c2 is present, which happend first? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;c1⟯

things like 毎whatever trigger what meaning for ていた? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;habitual meaning⟯
In general, ものだ(or other forms, e.g. である) either expresses ⟮c1;a strong opinion that something just is/should be a way⟯, or ⟮c2;expresses strong emotion⟯
When ものだ(or other forms, e.g. である)  expresses a strong opinion, that is often either that something ⟮c1;is a fact⟯ or something ⟮c2;should be a certain way (based on custom, common sense, etc.)⟯
When ものだ(or other forms, e.g. である)  is preceded by the past tense, it generally implies what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;reminiscence / recollection⟯
When ものだ(or other forms, e.g. である)  implies reminiscence, what comes in front of it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;past tense⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What is ものだ doing here? </div><br/>留学したいものだ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;expressing strong emotion⟯
Transitivity and intransitivity in japanese are generally realized how? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;in different verb pairs⟯
Verb pairs (e.g. 落ちろ、落とす) differ in what respect? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;transitivity⟯

The fact 女言葉・女性語 contains some kind of prohibition against strong expletives can be seen by what (related to letters 2 the ed)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Letters to the editor complaining about younger women using stuff like ふざけるなよー and うるせー⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > In 1988, a 41-year-old housewife wrote a letter titled, “My daughter said <br>‘Fuzakerunayoo (Go to hell),’” and said: “I was very shocked to hear such vulgar <br>and rough language from my own daughter” (Asahi shimbun, March 23, 1988). <br>Still, in 2006, a 37-year-old housewife wrote another letter titled, “Why does my <br>daughter use dirty speech,” describing the confusion she felt on hearing her daugh-<br>ter say, “Urusee (Shut your trap)!” and wondered, “what is happening in this society?” (Asahi shimbun, July 1, 2006). Responding to the 2006 letter, a 29-year-<br>old female worker wrote, “Parents should scold their children’s dirty speech,” be-<br>fore wondering “what is happening in this society?” (Asahi shimbun, July 4, 2006).  </div> </div>

What is the advantage of using 音 and 字 for couting things in japanese poetry? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;They are unambiguously defined⟯
In japan, what concept is most often used to count equal-timed units? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　音（おん）⟯
Most often, ⟮c1;1 kana⟯ = ⟮c2;1 　音（おん）⟯, except for ⟮c3;拗音⟯. 
The unit we should really be counting 俳句、短歌、長歌 etc. in is? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　音（おん）⟯
<div class='c1-f'> How many 　音（おん）? </div><br/>東京 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;4 (と；う；きょ；う）⟯

　音節（おんせつ） most closely translates to which english concept? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;syllable⟯
When counting the units that are 5 or 7&nbsp; long in japanese poetry, what do you use (for the units of 5 or 7, not for the individual sounds, which are 音)? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　句（く）⟯
　句（く） counts what, related to poetry? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the lines of 5 or 7 characters⟯
The possible lengths of 句 japanese poetry are ⟮c1;5⟯ or ⟮c2;7⟯
In a ⟮c1;短歌⟯, the first set of ⟮c2;5-7-5 lines⟯ is called the ⟮c4;　上（かみ）の　句（く）⟯, the second set of ⟮c3;7-7 lines⟯ is called the ⟮c4;　下（しも）の　句（く）.⟯

When is the transitivity of a compound verb not (just) determined by the first verb in the clause? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;lexicalized transitive verbs⟯
In lexicalized compound verbs, what is different to normal compound verbs, as regards transitivity? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the second verb (more often than not) matches the first⟯
In which compound verbs does the transitivity of the second verb (more often than not) match the first? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;lexicalized ones⟯
in compound verbs, which form of the general verb meaning to begin do you almost always use? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;始める⟯
Why is it stem+始める and not +始まる？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because of an arbitrary rule, and the second verb doesn't matter for transitivity anyway⟯ Whether you use stem+　終（お）える or stem+終わる, is what in relation to the general rule of how the transitivity of compound verbs is determined? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;somewhat of an exception⟯ Whether you use stem+　終（お）える or stem+終わる depends on what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the kind of tone you want to convey⟯ Between stem+　終（お）える or stem+終わる, stem+終<b>え</b>る conveys what nuance and&nbsp; is usually used for <span style="">intentional actions with a purpose</span>? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a literary nuance⟯ Between stem+　終（お）える or stem+終わる, stem+終<b>え</b>る conveys a literary nuance and is usually used for what kind of actions? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;intentional actions with a purpose⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div><br/>食べ出してください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stem+出す generally not with commands⟯

<div class='c1-f'> Why is this 始める and not 出す? </div><br/>食べ始めてもいいですか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　連用形（れんようけい）+出す generally not for requests/commands or similar⟯
⟮c1;stem⟯+⟮c2;かける⟯ most often glosses as ⟮c3;"to be on the verge of verbing"⟯, ⟮c4;"to start verbing and stop in the middle (doing something halfway)"⟯, or ⟮c5;"to do something towards someone"⟯ (but this is only used ⟮c6;with select verbs⟯) Why does 笑いかける mean "To smile at someone"? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;stem+かける as "verb being directed towards someone"⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>壊れかけのオルゴール <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Half-broken music box⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Can gloss either as what or what, due to かける? </div><br/>　話（はな）しかける <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;to address/accost someone or to begin to talk⟯
<pre><code>見知らぬ人に話し⟮c1;かけ⟯てはいけない。</code></pre><br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       Don't talk to strangers!  </div> </div>

連用形+か<b>か</b>る shares&nbsp; which meaning with +かける? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;to be about to (verb)", "to almost (verb)", "to initiate the action of (verb)ing", etc.⟯ 連用形+か<b>か</b>る shares the 'to initiate action, to almost/be about to verb' meaning of +かける, but... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;none of the other meanings⟯ 連用形+か<b>か</b>る is used how often, compared to + かける? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;less often⟯ 連用形+? to mean'to initiate action, to almost/be about to verb' besides +かける? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;+ かかる⟯ 連用形 + what (starts w k) means to start sth? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;かける・かかる⟯ Why can 呼びかける mean "To address/appeal to someone"? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;because 呼ぶ is one of the verbs that can be used in the 連用形＋かける as directing an action towards someone form.⟯ <div class='c1-f'> What meaning of 連用形かける allows this to mean half-broken music box? </div><br/>壊れかけのオルゴール <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the one where it means stopping midway⟯

毎セット毎セット is proof that the 毎X毎X pattern is what? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;pretty generalizable⟯ The 毎X毎X pattern has what kidn of tone? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;negative (irritated, bored, or otherwise suffering)⟯ counter ごとに is similar to 置きに but ... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;takes n instead of n-1 for every n counter in front of it⟯ ⟮c2;the amount of counter⟯ is rendered as ⟮c1;counter　数（すう）⟯&nbsp; ⟮c1;第somecounter目&nbsp;⟯ when used for counting with ⟮c2;日⟯ seems to ⟮c3;loosen the rules for which readings to use for the numbers&nbsp;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> (so both e.g. だいさんにちめ as well as だいみっかめ would be fine for 第三日目) </div> ⟮c1;个⟯ is the ⟮c2;most generic/common⟯ counter in ⟮c3;chinese⟯, it is a simplified form of ⟮c4;個⟯・⟮c4;箇⟯. This is related to the japanese ⟮c5;ヶ⟯ for counting. with 　置（お）きに, if you want to say it happens every n+1 counters, what do you use? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;n+counter in front of it⟯ with 　置（お）きに, if the counter phrase in front of it features a number n, how often does it happen? <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;every n+1 times ⟯ with 　置（お）きに meaning every other..., what goes before it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;a counter prhrase⟯ When used as a counter,&nbsp;&nbsp;　度（たび）&nbsp;can count up until where? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;up until 3 (then use ど)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > beware the reading </div> </div> When used as a counter,&nbsp;&nbsp;　度（たび） counts what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;times (as does ど)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > beware the reading </div> </div> When used as a counter, what numbers does this use 　度（たび）? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;japanese numbers (ひと、ふた、み）⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > beware the reading </div> </div> What kind of numbers does 晩 use as a counter? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;japanese more than that.  </div> </div> <div class='c1-f'> What kind of counter for what? </div><br/>⟮c1;General counter for nights⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;　夜（や）⟯ while you're ⟮c1;prescriptivley⟯ ⟮c2;not supposed to⟯ ⟮c3;combine 第 and 目⟯&nbsp;as in ⟮c3;第somecounter目⟯, it ⟮c4;does still often happen⟯ <div class='c2-f'> Counter for? </div><br/>⟮c1;　騎（き）⟯  <span 第somecounter目　seems to loosen the rules when counting with 日 </div> in theory, ⟮c1;羽⟯ as a counter is pronounced ⟮c2;は⟯, but it shifts to ⟮c2;わ⟯ (due to ⟮c3;historical sound shifts⟯) or ⟮c2;ば⟯・⟮c2;ぱ⟯ (due ⟮c3;to 連濁⟯) The thing that is similar to 置きに but takes n instead of n-1 for every n counter in front of it is... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ごとに⟯ For many counters, the ⟮c1;和語 numbers (even if they are used)⟯ are ⟮c2;not used all the way through⟯, but ⟮c2;only for the first⟯ ⟮c3;2⟯ or ⟮c3;3⟯<br/><div class="sub"> excluding of course 4 and 7, for which native numbers are often used 雪が降り積もって、⟮c1;出かけるに出かけられない⟯。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       The snow piled up, and we were unable to go out (though we wanted to).  </div><div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > to go out = 出かける </div> </div> 出来る can mean, besides 'to be able to', to ⟮c1;be finished/ready⟯, to ⟮c2;be made⟯ (⟮c3;of⟯), to ⟮c4;grow⟯, to ⟮c5;have sex⟯, to ⟮c6;be pregnant⟯ ゴルフ⟮c1;ができない⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" > I can't play golf. </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > https://www.imabi.net/dekiru.htm </div> </div> ことができる is similar to the potential form, but the nuance is... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;more that you are technically able to do it⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > en you ask "can you do this for me" and your witty friend replies "yes, I can" but doesn't do it, that's this meaning of potentiality that he chose to understand.  </div> </div> ことができる is an alternative to which form? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the potential form⟯ ことができる extends to することができる, which is seen by some as what and by some as what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;by some as more polite and by some as ungrammatical⟯ ことができる extends to what, seen by some as more polite and by some ass ungrammatical? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;することができる⟯ which construction would you more translate as 'to be able', and which as 'can'? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ことができる as to be able and the potential form as can⟯ alternative to the potential form that emphasizes that you are technically <b>able</b> to do it? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;ことができる⟯ If you asked your smartass friend "Can you pass me the salt?" and they answered "Yes, I <i>can</i>" and then don't do it, which potential construction would this rather be? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Vことができる⟯ How often do ことができる and the potential form differ in nuance? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;sometimes but not always⟯ Generally, when talking about ability, the pattern is: ⟮c1;noun⟯+⟮c2;が・も・。。。・ø⟯+⟮c3;出来る⟯ For ability to do a thing, what do you use with 出来る? Prices rose on average roughly sixfold over 150 years. This level of inflation amounts to 1–1.5% per year, a relatively low inflation rate for modern-day standards, but rather high given the monetary policy in place in the 16th century.⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > k... ⟮c1;　空耳（そらみみ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;mishearing, feigned deafness, homophonic translation of song lyrics for comic effect ⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> An example of "soramimi" humor confined to Japanese can be seen in the song Kaidoku Funō by the rock band Jinn, in which the lyrics "tōkankaku, hito no naka de" ("feeling of distance, amongst people"), which are considered hard to make out by Japanese listeners, are intentionally misinterpreted as "gōkan da, futon no naka de" ("it's rape, in a futon") for comedic reasons. </div><div class="sub all-b"> Soramimi applies to dialogue as well as song lyrics. For example, in the 2004 film Downfall, when Adolf Hitler says "und betrogen worden", it is misrepresented as "oppai purun purun" ("titty boing boing"). </div> </div>
time nounなtime nounな creates the meaning... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;every &lt;time-noun&gt;⟯ time nounなtime nounな creates the meaning every time noun, but... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;is limited to very few words⟯ the 〜な〜な pattern, even when rarely used with non time nouns seems to imply what? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;that there is a lot of the thing in question⟯ the 〜な〜な pattern seems to be used with what, besides time nouns, but very rarely? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;other words⟯ Pattern to create the pattern "every x" (select nouns only): ⟮c1;time noun⟯⟮c2;な⟯⟮c1;time noun⟯⟮c2;な⟯

⟮c1;　盆栽（ぼんさい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;is a Japanese version of the original traditional Chinese art penjing or penzai. Unlike penjing, which utilizes traditional techniques to produce entire natural sceneries in small pots that mimic the grandiose and shape of real life sceneries, the Japanese "___" only attempts to produce small trees that mimic the shape of real life trees. Similar versions of the art exist in other cultures, including the miniature living landscapes of Vietnamese Hòn non bộ. It was during the Tang dynasty, when penjing was at its height, that the art was first introduced into Japan.`⟯

when using ⟮c3;方⟯ (⟮c3;the way to⟯) with ⟮c2;する verbs⟯, instead of noun+⟮c1;し方⟯ it is noun⟮c1;の仕方⟯・⟮c1;の方法⟯など<br/><div class="sub"> although it's not inconcievable that the particle の would be dropped, thus making it the same pronunciation, although kanji and origin would be different </div>
<div class='c1-f'> what's the problem here? </div><br/>運転し方 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;should be 運転の仕方 or similar. の might be dropped, but in that case the reason and kanji are still different⟯

<div class='c1-f'> Glosses as? </div><br/>海外への電話の仕方を教えてくれませんか。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;     Could you tell me how to make overseas phone calls? ⟯
Besides meaning "⟮c1;please⟯", ⟮c2;どうか⟯ can also mean ⟮c3;somehow/thing⟯ (via <span class="c2-scr c3-scr">⟮c4;どう⟯+⟮c4;か⟯=⟮c4;somethingifier⟯</span>)
⟮c1;どのように⟯(starts d) is a more polite version of ⟮c2;どう⟯・⟮c2;どうやって⟯・△⟮c2;どうして⟯・など<br/><div class="sub"> I think this holds true for the whole こそあど series, but can't find any evidence rn </div>
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/>どうか許してください。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;please forgive me⟯
Extended from its general meaning of how, ⟮c1;どう⟯ can be used ⟮c4;by itself⟯ as a ⟮c2;casual greeting⟯ ("⟮c2;what's up?⟯") and as a ⟮c3;casual question⟯ ("⟮c3;is it OK?⟯"/"⟮c3;How is it?⟯")
⟮c1;どう⟯ in sentences such as あなたは⟮c1;どう⟯ですか can also mean something like "⟮c2;What about⟯"/"⟮c2;How about⟯" (often used for ⟮c3;suggestions⟯)
A: どう？B: まあまあ is what use of どう？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;the one where it means "how you doing?"⟯
A: どう？いいんじゃない is what use of どう？ <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;"How is it"&nbsp;⟯
⟮c2;なんとかなる⟯ means something like "⟮c1;to manage somehow or other⟯"
い⟮c1;かが⟯ is a ⟮c3;more formal⟯ version of ⟮c2;どう⟯ (and similar words ofc) 
⟮c1;いかん⟯ when from the kanji ⟮c2;如何⟯ may be derivative of ⟮c1;いかに⟯ and either mean the same as ⟮c3;いか（が）⟯ or ⟮c4;however/whysoever⟯
⟮c1;いか⟯、⟮c1;いかん⟯、⟮c2;いかが⟯ and even ⟮c2;どう⟯ may be spelled in kanji as&nbsp;⟮c3;如何⟯
⟮c1;いか⟯ (Kanji: ⟮c3;如何⟯) means "⟮c2;what kind of⟯"
⟮c1;くらい⟯ for asking ”⟮c2;how much?⟯” is often prefixed by ⟮c3;どれ⟯ or ⟮c3;どの⟯
⟮c1;何ぼ⟯ is ⟮c2;関西弁⟯ for ⟮c3;いくら⟯ or ⟮c3;いくつ⟯
The easiest way to think about ⟮c1;いくつ⟯: ⟮c1;いくつ⟯ is the way to ask about things ⟮c2;you would count with つ⟯
⟮c1;いくら:: question word⟯ is most often used for ⟮c2;money⟯, but can also be used to ask about ⟮c3;other quantities⟯
⟮c1;Question word⟯ + X + ⟮c1;(で・て)も⟯ glosses as "⟮c2;no matter...⟯"
<div class='c1-f'> What does this gloss as? </div><br/><u>何度</u>見<u>ても</u>面白いです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;      No matter how many times I see it, it's funny.  ⟯
⟮c1;どこに行っても⟯僕は君の側にいるよ。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       No matter where you go, I will be by your side.  </div><div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > or similar </div> </div>
⟮c1;僕は何を食べても⟯、太らない。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       No matter what I eat, I don't get fat.  </div> </div>
⟮c1;　手（て）を　焼（や）く⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;have difficulty with, not know what do with&nbsp;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> similar to sich die finger verbrennenn an </div><div class="sub c1-f" > T... 2 kanji 2kana </div> </div>
⟮c1;　何（なに）も　彼（か）も⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;everything (emphatic)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Glosses as? </div><br/>きっと誰の恋も、叶わない <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;No one's love will ever be fulfilled.⟯
⟮c1;Nobody's x⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c2;誰のxも⟯ <div class='c1-f'> in JP? </div><br/>somebody's&nbsp; car <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;誰かの車⟯ <div class='c1-f'> in JP? </div><br/>Nobody's car <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;誰の車も⟯
⟮c1;誰か⟯がおいしいクッキーを全部食べた。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >    Somebody ate all of the delicious cookies!  </div> </div>
私の英語の講座は⟮c1;どれも⟯文法を扱った。<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f c2-b" >       Every one of my English courses dealt with grammar.  </div> </div>
⟮c1;　消火器（しょうかき）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;fire extinguisher⟯

Generally ⟮c3;nominalizer の⟯ + ⟮c3;posessive の⟯ = ⟮c4;のの⟯ is ⟮c2;proscribed⟯, but ⟮c1;may rarely happen⟯
Using ⟮c1;の⟯ instead of ⟮c1;が⟯ in relative phrases may give more of a feeling of ⟮c2;belonging⟯ in some cases.
the cause marked by て/で is generally not... <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;caused by anyones volition⟯ <div class='c1-f'> what is で doing here? </div><br/>彼は心不全で死んだ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;marking the cause&nbsp;⟯ <div class='c1-f'> what is で doing here? </div><br/>喜びで我を忘れました。  <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;marking the cause⟯ <div class='c1-f'> what is the て form doing here? </div><br/>彼は愛の足りなくて死んだ。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;marking cause⟯
the ⟮c1;か⟯&nbsp;of かも（しれない）may also become ⟮c2;や⟯ How is かもしれない conjugated? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;As a negative ru verb (but there is no positive)⟯ How is かもしれない sometimes written with Kanji? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;かも知れない⟯ What is the hypermasculine version of かもしれない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;かもしれん⟯ What is the polite present form of かもしれない? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;かもしれません⟯ What is かもしれない abbreviated to in casual speech? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;かも⟯ What do you attach to the end of the clause to express uncertainty (at the level of 'possibly')? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;かもしれない⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-b c2-f" > since it's based off 知る </div> <div class="sub c1-f" > Long ver </div> </div>
⟮c1;ひょっとして⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;by any chance; (should) it happen (that); by some chance⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > H... </div> </div>
これ・あれ・それ are pluralized using ⟮c1;ら⟯, ⟮c2;but relatively rarely.⟯
⟮c1;頂く⟯ is ⟮c2;謙譲語⟯ for ⟮c3;食べる⟯ or ⟮c4;もらう⟯
⟮c1;頂く⟯ ⟮c2;non-humbly⟯ means ⟮c3;to place on or above ones head⟯
<div class='c1-f'> What use of てもらう is this? </div><br/>自分で出したゴミが、自分で持って帰ってもらいます。 <span class="divider">-&gt;</span> ⟮c1;to have someone do something⟯

<div class='c1-f'> What's the problem here? </div><br/>セスは日本での生活が懐かしいです。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;we can't just say what someone is feeling, we need to use 〜がる⟯

When talking about the ⟮c1;feelings (and feeling-adjacent things)⟯ of ⟮c2;other people⟯ (or ⟮c2;oneself⟯ as ⟮c2;seen from the outside⟯, e.g. the ⟮c3;past⟯) you use ⟮c4;がる⟯ (at least for ⟮c5;adjectives⟯)

⟮c1;only some⟯ adjectives are frequently/ever used with がる

<div class='c1-f'> What's the difference in nuance here, vs. just あなたが好き？ </div><br/>あなたのことが好き <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;adds a feeling of liking everything encompassing the person (scope-widening) and of this being the exact person one likes (focusing)⟯

⟮c1;stem⟯ + ⟮c1;込む⟯ can mean ⟮c2;to verb in/into⟯ (e.g. ⟮c2;to blow in, to jump in⟯), ⟮c3;to verb fully/deeply/intensly⟯, or ⟮c4;to verb and then continue in the same manner⟯ 　黙（だま）り　込（こ）む uses what meaning of the stem + 込む pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;to fall silent -&gt; to do an action and then stay that way⟯ 　飛（と）び　込（こ）む uses what meaning of the stem + 込む pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;Jump in/Dive. -&gt; to verb in/into⟯ 　思（おも）い　込（こ）む uses what meaning of the stem + 込む pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;be convinced, have one's heart set on -&gt; intensification meaning&nbsp;⟯ 　吹（ふ）き　込（こ）む uses what meaning of the stem + 込む pattern? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;to blow in -&gt; verbing in/into meaning⟯
　教（おし）え　込（こ）む means what why? <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;to teach thoroughly, instill, inculcate (連用形 + 込む pattern)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Verb for? </div><br/>to push into (using pattern) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;押し込む⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Verb for? </div><br/>to read thoroughly; read into, read into memory (using pattern) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;読み込む⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Verb for? </div><br/>to promote, to do a hard sell, find a market for (using pattern) <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;　売（う）り　込（こ）む⟯

⟮c1;　倭（わ）　寇（こう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;pirates from a mixture of ethnicities but said to be japanese who raided the coastlines of China and Korea from the 13th to 16th centuries⟯
the ⟮c1;わ⟯ (⟮c1;wo⟯ in chinese) meaning ⟮c2;Japan⟯ was originally written ⟮c3;倭⟯ meaning ⟮c3;midget⟯. Since ⟮c4;the japanese didn't like referring to themselves using a pejorative term⟯, in the ⟮c5;700⟯s they looked for a kanji with ⟮c6;the same reading⟯ but ⟮c6;a different meaning⟯ and hit on ⟮c7;和⟯.
in general where possible japanese will prefer long compound terms to be ⟮c1;four-character⟯ compounds

⟮c1;余り⟯, besides the kanji spelling of the adverb ⟮c2;あまり・あんまり⟯, means the ⟮c3;remainder⟯, an ⟮c7;excess of⟯, and after ⟮c4;a number⟯ may mean "a ⟮c5;little more than⟯", and archaically would have ⟮c6;connected the parts of a number large than the base (10 and 5, 100 and 30 and 7)⟯

⟮c1;　暴走族（ぼうそうぞく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;young motorcycle-riding delinquents⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The first appearance of these types of biker gangs was in the 1950s. Popularity climbed throughout the 1980s and 1990s, peaking at an estimated 42,510 members in 1982. Their numbers dropped dramatically in the 2000s with a reported number of under 7,297 members in 2012.[1]  Bōsōzoku style traditionally involves boilersuits similar to those of manual laborers or leather military jackets with baggy pants, and tall boots. This uniform became known as the tokkō-fuku (特攻服, "special attack clothing") and is often adorned with kanji slogans. Typical accessories to this uniform are hachimaki, surgical masks, and patches displaying the Japanese Imperial Flag. </div> </div>

⟮c1;　旧（きゅう）　暦（れき）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;the old lunisolar Japanese calendar (used until 1872)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> The lunisolar Chinese calendar was introduced to Japan via Korea in the middle of the sixth century. After that, Japan calculated its calendar using various Chinese calendar procedures, and from 1685, using Japanese variations of the Chinese procedures. But in 1873, as part of Japan's Meiji period modernization, a calendar based on the solar Gregorian calendar was introduced.[2] In Japan today, the old Chinese calendar is virtually ignored; celebrations of the Lunar New Year are thus limited to Chinese and other Asian immigrant communities. </div> </div>

⟮c1;　我慢汁（がまんじる）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;precum⟯
⟮c1;　出（だ）し or 　出（だ）　汁（し） (cooking context)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;) is a family of stocks used in Japanese cuisine. Dashi forms the base for miso soup, clear broth soup, noodle broth soup, and many simmering liquids to accentuate the savory flavor known as umami. The most common form of dashi is a simple broth made by heating water containing kombu (edible kelp) and kezurikatsuo (shavings of katsuobushi – preserved, fermented skipjack tuna or bonito) to near-boiling, then straining the resultant liquid; dried anchovies or sardines may be substituted.⟯
⟮c1;　研（と）ぐ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;sharpen, whet an ax or knife;  wash rice; polish, clean a surface を⟯

⟮c1;　語句（ごく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;words; phrases⟯
⟮c1;　節句（せっく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;seasonal festival⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Appears to be a Japanese coinage using Middle Chinese-derived components, possibly derived as a portmanteau or contraction from 節 (setsu, “season”) + 供御 (kugo, “offering of food or drink”). Compound of 節 (setsu, “season”) +‎ 供 (ku, “offering”), in reference to offerings of food and drink made by the nobility to shrines and temples for the seasonal celebrations.  The use of 句 to spell the ku portion is an example of ateji. </div> </div>
⟮c1;子供の日⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Children's Day, a festival held in Japan on 5 May to celebrate children; part of the Golden Week series of holidays in May⟯

⟮c1;　俳優（はいゆう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;actor; actress; player; performer⟯
((h:2;::<img src="220px-Basho_by_Kinkoku_c1820.jpg">))⟮c1;　俳（はい）　画（が）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2; a simple painting with wash and India ink, often associated with haiku⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Haiga (俳画, haikai drawing) is a style of Japanese painting that incorporates the aesthetics of haikai. Haiga are typically painted by haiku poets (haijin), and often accompanied by a haiku poem.[1] Like the poetic form it accompanied, haiga was based on simple, yet often profound, observations of the everyday world. Stephen Addiss points out that "since they are both created with the same brush and ink, adding an image to a haiku poem was ... a natural activity."[2]  Stylistically, haiga vary widely based on the preferences and training of the individual painter, but generally show influences of formal Kanō school painting, minimalist Zen painting, and Ōtsu-e, while sharing much of the aesthetic attitudes of the nanga tradition. Some were reproduced as woodblock prints. The subjects painted likewise vary widely, but are generally elements mentioned in the calligraphy, or poetic images which add meaning or depth to that expressed by the poem. The moon is a common subject in these poems and paintings, sometimes represented by the Zen circle ensō, which evokes a number of other meanings, including that of the void. Other subjects, ranging from Mount Fuji to rooftops, are frequently represented with a minimum of brushstrokes, thus evoking elegance and beauty in simplicity. </div> </div>
