⟮c1;　利（り）　己（こ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;selfishness, self-interest⟯
⟮c1;　自己中心（じこちゅうしん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;selfishness, egocentrism⟯
⟮c1;　自己愛（じこあい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;narcissism; self-love⟯
⟮c1;　保身（ほしん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;self-protection⟯
⟮c1;　集（しゅう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;collection, compilation⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> suffix </div> </div>
⟮c1;　集合（しゅうごう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;meeting up, gathering, assembly, set⟯
⟮c1;　集団（しゅうだん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;crowd, group, mass⟯
⟮c1;　集会（しゅうかい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;meeting; assembly; gathering; congregation; convention; rally⟯
⟮c1;　集計（しゅうけい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;totalization; totalisation; aggregation; tally (e.g. of votes); adding up; summing up⟯
⟮c1;　集積（しゅうせき）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;accumulation⟯
⟮c1;　集約（しゅうやく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;intensiveness, collecting, summarizing⟯
⟮c1;　集落（しゅうらく）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;settlement; village; (bacterial) colony⟯
⟮c1;　集荷（しゅうか）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;collection of cargo (esp. produce, etc.); cargo booking​⟯
⟮c1;　集大成（しゅうたいせい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;large compilation, culination of hard work⟯
⟮c1;　集散（しゅうさん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;collection (gathering) and distribution⟯
⟮c1;　全集（ぜんしゅう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;complete works; complete collection; complete series⟯
⟮c1;　収集（しゅうしゅう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;collecting; accumulating; gathering⟯
⟮c1;　詩集（ししゅう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;poetry anthology; collection of poems; collected poems⟯
⟮c1;　画集（がしゅう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;artbook, book of art⟯
⟮c1;　結（けっ）　集（しゅう） or 　集（しゅう）　結（けつ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;gathering⟯
⟮c1;　広場（ひろば）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;public square; square; plaza; clearing⟯
⟮c1;　漏（も）れる or 　漏（も）る⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;leak out, escape, find expression, be disclosed, be left out が⟯
⟮c1;　漏（も）らす⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;reveal, let leak, omit, leave out を⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > M... </div> </div>
⟮c1;　漏（も）れ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;variant of 俺⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class='sub f'> online slang </div> </div>
⟮c1;お　漏（も）らし⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;wetting oneself, The sexual fetish of arousal from having a full bladder or a sexual attraction to someone else experiencing the feeling of a full urinary bladder., (informal) information leakage⟯
⟮c1;　聞（き）き　漏（も）らす ::k...⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to fail to hear; to miss (also in a metaphorical sense)⟯
((h:2;::<img src="250px-Forest-sun_01.JPG">))⟮c1;　木（こ）　漏（も）れ　日（び）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;sunlight filtering through trees ⟯
words that contain ⟮c1;も⟯ as ⟮c2;漏⟯ may also spell it ⟮c3;洩⟯
⟮c1;Final vowel sounds of morphemes⟯ in ⟮c2;compounds⟯ may sometimes ⟮c3;change to a different vowel⟯ compared to their more common readings, most commonly either due to ⟮c4;ancient readings or patterns being preserved⟯, ⟮c5;assimilation⟯, or ⟮c6;casual/local readings becoming fossilized&nbsp;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> e.g. あまぞら (vs *あめぞら), さかや (vs *さけや), こもれび (vs *きもれび) </div>
the ⟮c1;copula⟯ in ⟮c2;文語⟯ was/is ⟮c3;なり⟯
the ⟮c1;文語 copula なり⟯ would only be ⟮c2;なり⟯ (instead of ⟮c2;なる⟯) in the ⟮c3;終止形⟯, where it could have been spelled ⟮c4;也⟯
the ⟮c1;文語 copula なり⟯&nbsp; evolved from even older ⟮c2;に+あり⟯
One of the about five million options for ⟮c1;listing either ... or options⟯ is ⟮c2;〜なり〜なり⟯ (contains an n)
often when using the ⟮c1;〜なり〜なり⟯ (contains n) pattern, the ⟮c3;final element⟯ is ⟮c2;a question word⟯ implying ⟮c2;some....⟯
⟮c1;なり⟯ after ⟮c2;a single option⟯ implies ⟮c3;there might be other options, as in giving an example⟯
<div class='c2-f'> what pattern are we using here for what meaning? </div><div class='c1-f'> What might be an example for this pattern? </div><br/>⟮c1;楽天なりどこなりで買い物をする⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;〜なり〜なり for listing options⟯
<div class='c2-f'> what pattern are we using here for what meaning? </div><div class='c1-f'> What might be an example for this pattern? </div><br/>⟮c1;労働局になり相談したらどうですか⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;なり：or something, for example⟯
⟮c1;verb (dictionary form)⟯ + ⟮c2;なり⟯ = ⟮c3;as soon as⟯
⟮c1;verb (past tense)⟯ + ⟮c2;なり⟯ = ⟮c3;while⟯
<div class='c1-f'> means what why? </div><br/>彼は帰るなり、トイレに行った。 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;He went to the bathroom <b>as soon as</b>&nbsp;he got home (なり: as soon as pattern)⟯
<div class='c1-f'> means what why? </div><br/>帰るなり座った <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;sat down as soon as I got home (v+なり: as soon as pattern)⟯
⟮c1;　並木（なみき）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;roadside tree, row of roadside trees⟯
⟮c1;　並木道（なみきみち）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;avenue; boulevard; tree-lined street⟯

⟮c1;っぱ⟯ may be short for ⟮c2;っぱなし⟯

⟮c1;　透（す）かす ::1 Kanji 2 kana⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;be slightly apart, be separated by a thin space; look through, look into; thin, become thin を⟯

⟮c1;　透（す）き　通（とお）る⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to be transparent; to be see-through; to be clear (also of sound) が⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > compound verb </div> </div>
⟮c1;　透（す）く⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to be transparent, can be seen through (such as thin, sparse objects such as a fence); to be or become thin and sparse; to make a room or gap inbetween objects が⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> basically the same as 透ける </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kanji 1 kana </div> </div>
⟮c1;　透（す）ける⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to show through が⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> both this and 　透（す）く are both が </div><div class="sub c1-f" > 1 kanji 2 kana </div> </div>
⟮c1;(新年)　明（あ）けましておめでとう(ございます)⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;Happy New Year, used on and after New Year's Day.⟯

⟮c1;　有（あり）　明（あけ）(の)　月（づき）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;the moon still in the sky at the hours around dawn or sunrise⟯
⟮c1;　薄明（うすあ）かり⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;dim light; faint light; half-light of early morning; twilight⟯
⟮c1;　夜明（よあ）け⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;dawn, daybreak⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > y..., 2 kanji (+ sometimes 1 送り仮名） </div> </div>
⟮c1;　夜明（よあ）かし⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;staying up all night; all-night vigil⟯
⟮c1;　解（と）き　明（あ）かす⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;explain clearly⟯
⟮c1;泣き明かす⟯ = ⟮c2;to cry the whole night⟯ (due to grammar)

⟮c1;連用形⟯＋⟮c1;暮らす⟯ is to ⟮c2;go through the whole day doing something⟯<br/><div class="sub"> man, notice the exact parallel between this and -明かす, its exactly like the くろ - あか distinction! </div> ⟮c1;連用形⟯＋⟮c1;明かす⟯ is to ⟮c2;go through the whole night doing something⟯ ⟮c1;泣き暮らす⟯ = ⟮c2;to cry the whole day⟯ (due to grammar) ⟮c1;　暮（く）れる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;for night to fall (prob. original meaning), season ending, be lost in/overwhelmed by an emotion/thought が⟯ ⟮c1;　暮（く）れ　泥（なず）む⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to become twilight, (of a sunset) to linger⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji 2 kana </div> </div> ⟮c1;　暮（く）らす⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;spend (the daytime of a day, or a long time); by extension: lead a life を⟯ ⟮c1;　暮（く）らし ::1 kanji 2 kana⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;life; living; livelihood; life circumstances⟯ ⟮c1;　日（ひ）　暮（ぐ）れ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;sunset, sundown, dusk, evening, nightfall⟯ ⟮c1;　日（ひ）　暮（ぐ）らし⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;from morning to evening, all day⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > 2 kanji 2 kana, h... </div> </div> ⟮c1;　夕（ゆう）　暮（ぐ）れ⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;evening twilight, evening when the sun goes down⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > y..., 2 kanji 1 kana </div> </div> ⟮c1;　一（ひと）　人（り）　暮（ぐ）らし⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;living by oneself; living alone⟯ ⟮c1;　途方（とほう）に　暮（く）れる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to be at a loss⟯ ⟮c1;　暮（く）らしを　立（た）てる⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;to make a living⟯ ⟮c1;　日（ひ）　暮（く）れて　道（みち）　遠（とお）し⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;arduous is the race against time as one grows old.⟯ ⟮c1;くろ⟯ probably became '⟮c2;black⟯' as a consequence of its '⟮c3;darkening after sunset⟯' meaning ⟮c1;あか⟯ probably became '⟮c2;red⟯' as a consequence of its '⟮c3;brightening at dawn (think morning glow)⟯' meaning the ⟮c1;four⟯ colors that exist as ⟮c2;1⟯-kanji ⟮c2;い⟯adjectives: ⟮c1;黒⟯、⟮c1;白⟯、⟮c1;赤⟯、⟮c1;青⟯ can also be used as ⟮c3;のadjectives⟯ in ⟮c4;highly restricted⟯ circumstances the colors that have existed in japan since ⟮c2;ancient times⟯ are ⟮c1;黒⟯、⟮c1;白⟯、⟮c1;赤⟯、⟮c1;青⟯ (they are, not coincidentally, also ⟮c3;the only ones that you can use as 形容詞⟯). The others have either been ⟮c4;repurposed⟯ far more ⟮c5;recently⟯ from ⟮c6;plants, materials⟯ or ⟮c7;borrowed from languages such as english⟯ Under the assumption of the 4-color ancient japanese color system, the pairs of ⟮c3;opposites⟯ probably would have been (!) ⟮c1;あか⟯ - ⟮c1;くろ⟯ and ⟮c2;あを⟯ - ⟮c2;しろ⟯ It is argued that in ⟮c3;ancient japan⟯, there was a ⟮c4;color system (not a technical term)⟯ where ⟮c1;bright colors⟯ would have been ⟮c2;あか⟯, ⟮c1;dark colors⟯ would have been ⟮c2;くろ⟯, ⟮c6;indistinct and vague colors⟯ would have been ⟮c5;あを (today あお)⟯, and ⟮c6;distinct colors⟯ would have been ⟮c5;しろ⟯ It is argued that the color word ⟮c1;赤⟯（⟮c1;あか⟯）is etymologically related to ⟮c2;朱⟯（⟮c2;あけ⟯, '⟮c3;crimson⟯'） and ⟮c4;明ける⟯・⟮c4;明るい⟯・など, originally having a meaning such as '⟮c5;brightening at dawn⟯' It is argued that the color word ⟮c1;白⟯ （⟮c1;しろ⟯）is related etymologcially to ⟮c2;印⟯（⟮c2;しるし⟯, '⟮c3;mark⟯'）、⟮c4;白白⟯（⟮c4;しらしら⟯, ⟮c5;'obvious speech⟯' (originally)） It is argued that the color word ⟮c1;くろ⟯（⟮c1;黒⟯）is etymologically related to ⟮c2;　暮（く）れる⟯&nbsp;(and related words) and ⟮c3;暗い⟯ （⟮c3;くらい⟯） (and related words) and meant something such as '⟮c4;darkening after sunset⟯' ((h:2;::<img src="250px-2016_1010_1119_dsc07615.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="Indigo_plant_extract_sample.jpg">))⟮c1;　藍（あい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;indigo (plant, color)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> clearly related with あお via the older reading あを </div> </div> ⟮c1;しるし⟯ may mean ⟮c2;mark/sign/badge/crest/flag/symbol/emblen⟯ (then often spelled ⟮c3;印⟯ or ⟮c4;徴⟯ or ⟮c5;標⟯) or ⟮c6;evidence/proof⟯ (then often spelled ⟮c7;証⟯ and also read ⟮c8;あかし⟯)<br/><div class="sub"> hey look, a connection between しろ and あか </div> ⟮c1;あか⟯ meaning ⟮c1;red⟯ is less commonly also spelled ⟮c2;朱⟯ ⟮c1;　赤裸（あかはだか）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;stark naked; nude; bare; unvarnished (e.g. truth); plain (e.g. fact); frank; candid; outspoken⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> uses the あか as bright, exposed original meaning </div><div class="sub c2-f c1-b" > may also be read as せきら and also be realized as&nbsp; To refer to an ⟮c1;inbetween-shade of color⟯, ⟮c2;list the two colors after each other⟯. the resultant compound can be read with ⟮c3;either 訓読み or 音読み⟯, but ⟮c5;the former⟯ is ⟮c4;more common⟯.
⟮c1;黄緑⟯ means ⟮c2;yellow-green⟯, and may be read either ⟮c3;きみどり⟯ or ⟮c3;おうりょく⟯ (due to grammar)
⟮c1;light/pale⟯ colors are indicated either by adding the adjectives ⟮c2;　淡（あわ）い⟯&nbsp;or ⟮c3;　薄（うす）い⟯&nbsp;or by ⟮c4;prefixing 　薄（うす）.⟯
<div class='c1-f'> Means? </div><br/>((h:2;::<img src="sm_104664.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_d686f03cbdc53941c5eade04cbae15e9_3.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_0b3b995a2f01131626e5bd6118017fb4.jpg">)) ((h:2;::<img src="Indigo_plant_extract_sample.jpg">)) ((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-3724edd0b4b2c47c27c98cec7da085b18cf13409.jpg">)) ((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-345d7620ba356953cdc28fe35150e01c34bc36ce.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-cd9b6c74bb8e5440771ddaffb320cd113939a6fc.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-c8ced5a1b796e7e41166705f347ac9f2c4a4574d.jpg">)) ((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-bb9cec524b1694bf55f0cb6ecb3f236233538bb8.jpg">))((h:2;::<img src="sm_paste-810b4dbb70d0190fbf2a54ca78b4be6c7982cbb1.jpg">))　淡（あわ）い黄色 <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;pale yellow⟯ 　薄（うす）い　色（いろ） <span class="divider">-></span> ⟮c1;light/pale color⟯ of the ⟮c4;color words⟯ that are ⟮c3;compounds⟯ that ⟮c3;end in 色⟯, depending on ⟮c1;the color⟯ (and the grammatical / conversational situation) it may be ⟮c1;more or less acceptable⟯ to ⟮c2;leave the final 色 out.⟯ ⟮c1;<ruby> 茜色 <rp>(</rp><rt>あかねいろ</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;⟯ ⟮c1;　渋色（しぶいろ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;tan (color)⟯ ⟮c1;　灰色（はいいろ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;ash color, gray⟯ ⟮c1;　緑色（みどりいろ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;green⟯ ⟮c1;　色名（しきめい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;color name, color term⟯ ⟮c1;　茶色（ちゃいろ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;light brown⟯ ⟮c1;　藍色（あいいろ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;the color indigo⟯ ⟮c1;　金色（きんいろ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;gold (color)⟯ ⟮c1;　顔（かお）　色（いろ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;complexion, the appearance of one's face due to skin color or blood flow; to express that a color is ⟮c1;deep/dark⟯, use ⟮c2;　濃（こ）い⟯
⟮c3;　青（あお）⟯ is today mostly described as '⟮c2;blue⟯', however in ⟮c4;the past⟯ it would have also included ⟮c1;green⟯, as seen in ⟮c5;many compounds::type of word⟯. Even ⟮c6;today⟯, it encompasses part of what english speakers would&nbsp; call ⟮c1;green⟯.
besides ⟮c1;blue⟯ and ⟮c1;green⟯, ⟮c2;あお⟯ in the past might also have included other colors, e.g ⟮c3;black⟯ and ⟮c4;indigo⟯ (whence ⟮c5;　藍（あい）⟯)
⟮c1;青⟯ gathered a connotation with ⟮c2;youth and freshness⟯, probably via ⟮c3;青春⟯
⟮c1;青⟯ has been retained as ⟮c4;green⟯ more commonly in ⟮c5;fixed expressions⟯, esp. in relation to ⟮c2;plants⟯ and ⟮c3;traffic lights⟯

((h:2;::<img src="220px-Japanese_Buddhist_altar_001.jpg">)) <br/>⟮c1;　仏壇（ぶつだん）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2; is a shrine commonly found in temples and homes in Japanese Buddhist cultures.[1] A ___ is either a defined, often ornate platform or simply a wooden cabinet sometimes crafted with doors that enclose and protect a Gohonzon or religious icon, typically a statue or painting of a Buddha or Bodhisattva, or a calligraphic mandala scroll. Its primary use is for paying respects to the Buddha, as well as to family members who have died.⟯

⟮c1;　交際（こうさい）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;association; relationship; dating, going out with someone⟯
⟮c1;　援助交際（えんじょこうさい） often shortened to 　援（えん）　交（こう）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;dating with compensation (payments, financial support, etc.); schoolgirl prostitution.⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c2-b c1-f" > A 1997 poll in the Japanese TV Asahi program Asa Made Nama Terebi [ja] showed that 70 percent of respondents opposed enjo-kōsai involving sexual interactions, while 30 percent approved of it.[6] Typically, it is perceived as an extension of Japan's growing focus on materialism, much of which is what critics claim is the cause of enjo-kōsai. Critics worry that girls involved in enjo-kōsai will grow up to be unfit wives and mothers. This perception arises from suspicions that when these girls are adults, they will quickly abandon their loyalties and commitments to their family for offers of money and material benefits.[6] However, certain feminist groups[which?] and critics regard enjo-kōsai as an empowering way to "undermine patriarchal models of propriety used to evaluate and control women".[This quote needs a citation] Control over their bodies and means to support themselves is a new kind of independence for these girls. Good women in Japan are supposed to be sensible, modest, nurturing and respectful, yet girls participating in enjo-kōsai clearly reject such virtues of female restraint and modesty in Japan. Feminists such as Chizuko Ueno point out that the accidental access of girls to this dating market was not a matter of ethics, but of probability.[6] Sooner or later, these girls and young women would, in a desire for financial independence, tap into this market for their own empowerment. However, Ueno points out that while engaging in enjo-kōsai may appear beneficial for young women in the short term, it also reinforces patriarchal power structures by leaving the notion that women's bodies exist to serve male desire unchallenged.[7] </div> </div>

in the case of ⟮c1;破⟯, the ones with ⟮c2;k as the first letter of the okurigana⟯ (that is, ⟮c2;く and ける⟯)&nbsp; ⟮c3;are (generally) semantically restricted to tearing⟯, while those with ⟮c2;r as the first letter of the okurigana⟯ (that is, ⟮c2;る and れる⟯) ⟮c3;can either have a tearing meaning, but also a meaning of breaking or defeating⟯. The ones ⟮c4;ending -u with one kana⟯ (that is, ⟮c4;く and る⟯) are ⟮c5;intransitive (が)⟯, the ones ⟮c4;ending -eru⟯ (that is, ⟮c4;ける and れる⟯) are ⟮c5;transitive (を)⟯
⟮c1;十一日⟯ is pronounced ⟮c2;じゅういちにち⟯&nbsp;&nbsp;<br/><div class="sub"> for day counting, beyond 10 readings become pretty normal, except that 四日 is still read よっか and 九 is generally read く </div>
for day counting, ⟮c1;beyond 10⟯ readings become ⟮c2;pretty normal⟯, except that ⟮c3;四日 is still read よっか⟯ (but mostly ⟮c5;only for calendar days⟯, it generally becomes ⟮c5;regular after 30⟯) and ⟮c4;九 is generally read く⟯
while counting ⟮c1;days⟯ ⟮c2;ordinally⟯ with ⟮c3;<span style="color: rgb(55, 58, 60);">第somenumber</span>日⟯&nbsp;⟮c4;forces the whole thing into 漢語 numbers⟯, ⟮c3;somenumber日目⟯ ⟮c4;leaves them as-is (compared to their normal readings, i.e. 2-9 will be read with か etc.)⟯
⟮c1;第六日⟯ is read ⟮c2;だいろくにち⟯        <br/><div class="sub"> because&nbsp;<span style="color: rgb(55, 58, 60);">第 forces the whole thing into kango for 日</span> </div>
⟮c1;四日目⟯ is read ⟮c2;よっかめ&nbsp;⟯<br/><div class="sub"> since 目 doesn't change the reading </div>
&nbsp;⟮c1;四十九日⟯ is normally read as ⟮c2;よんじゅうくにち⟯. However, when it means "t⟮c3;he forty-ninth day after someone's death for the 49 Day Funeral Ceremony⟯", it is read as ⟮c4;しじゅうくにち⟯. 
the ⟮c1;和語 reading⟯ for ⟮c2;八⟯ is generally ⟮c3;や⟯, but for ⟮c5;8日⟯, which ⟮c6;over time turned into⟯ ⟮c4;よう⟯
more ⟮c6;rare⟯ readings for ⟮c1;一日⟯ as "⟮c2;one day⟯" include ⟮c3;いちじつ⟯ and ⟮c4;ひとひ⟯ (⟮c4;archaic⟯); for ⟮c1;一日⟯ as "⟮c2;the first day⟯" ⟮c5;いっぴ⟯ (mostly ⟮c5;business⟯ contexts)

Distilled by simple distillation.⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b"> Originally a compound of 粟あわ (awa, “millet”) + 盛もり (mori, “lots of, pile of, ample portion of”). ⟮c1;　愛（あい）　国（こく）　心（しん） ::3 kanji⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;patriotism (love of one's own country)⟯ ⟮c1;　愛（あい）　国（こく） ::2 kanji⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;patriotism⟯
⟮c1;　SF（エスエフ）⟯  <span class="divider">&lt;-&gt;</span> ⟮c2;science fiction⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub c1-f" > short ver </div> </div>
Counting with つ<br/> <table> <tbody><tr> <th>Numeral</th> <td>How many</td> <td>1</td> <td>2</td> <td>3</td> <td>4</td> <td>5</td> <td>6</td> <td>7</td> <td>8</td> <td>9</td> <td>10</td> </tr> <tr> <th>Reading</th> <td><span class="c1-cloze">いくつ</span></td> <td><span class="c2-cloze">ひとつ</span></td> <td><span class="c3-cloze">ふたつ</span></td> <td><span class="c4-cloze">みっつ</span></td> <td><span class="c5-cloze">よっつ</span></td> <td><span class="c6-cloze">いつつ</span></td> <td><span class="c7-cloze">むっつ</span></td> <td><span class="c8-cloze">ななつ</span></td> <td><span class="c9-cloze">やっつ</span></td> <td><span class="c10-cloze">ここのつ</span></td> <td><span class="c11-cloze">とお(e.g. 十日)</span></td> </tr> </tbody></table> <span class="cloze-dump">⟮c1;⟯⟮c2;⟯⟮c3;⟯⟮c4;⟯⟮c5;⟯⟮c6;⟯⟮c7;⟯⟮c8;⟯⟮c9;⟯{{c10::}}{{c11::}}</span>
In order of politeness: ⟮c1;けど⟯ &lt; ⟮c1;けれど⟯ &lt; ⟮c2;けれども⟯
⟮c1;　新製品（しんせいひん）⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c2;new product; new line (of products)⟯
⟮c1;　清貧（せいひん）⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c2;honorable poverty⟯

⟮c1;お　凸（でこ）⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c2;brow, forehead⟯ ⟮c1;　凸（でこ）　凹（ぼこ）⟯ = ⟮c2;bumpy, lumpy, irregular, unequal, uneven⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">may also be read とつおう</div> </div>
⟮c2;　凹凸（おうとつ）⟯ = ⟮c1;uneven, bumpy⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">anagram of 凸凹 but never read with those readings</div> </div> ⟮c1;　電凸（でんとつ）⟯ = ⟮c2;flooding a company, organization etc. with phone complaints (usu. loosely organized on anonymous online message boards)⟯<br/><div class="sub"> <div class="sub all-b">from 　電話突撃（でんわとつげき）</div> </div> ⟮c1;　凸面（とつめん）⟯ = ⟮c2;convex surface⟯ ⟮c1;　凸（とつ）⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c2;convex (wenn der bauch...)⟯
⟮c2;　凹（おう）⟯ = ⟮c1;concave⟯ ⟮c1;　凹（おう）　面（めん）⟯ = ⟮c2;concave surface⟯
⟮c1;　巡（めぐ）る⟯ (may also be spelled <span class="c1-scr c2-scr">⟮c3;廻る⟯ or ⟮c4;回る⟯</span>) = ⟮c2;go around, circle, return, repeat, concern を⟯
⟮c1;　堂々巡（どうどうめぐ）り⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c2;going round in circles (do the same thign without progress)⟯
⟮c1;　堂々（どうどう）⟯&nbsp;= ⟮c2;magnificent, grand, impressive, dignified, fair, square, open, unreservex⟯
⟮c2;　巡（めぐ）らす⟯ = ⟮c1;enclose, build a barrier around, turn (e.g. one's head), work out を⟯
